151408976.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an interesting journey through north mythology, which was always quite intriguing for me. After seeing the rather mysterious trailer back then, i thought that i needed to try it out and it was a good decision to do so.

Playing as Senua, you will get yourself into an arduous trip full of dangers, uncertainty and the problem to keep reality and imagination apart. The protagonist you are playing as, suffers from a heavy psychosis, so you will often sit in front of your computer and will ask yourself, what is even going on here? Senua will perceive whispering voices and suffer from vivid hallucinations that turn a rather calm situation into a nightmarish one from one moment to the other. The way the story is being told is the games biggest strength. I also have to praise the great facial animations, they did a top notch job in this department. 

Gameplay-wise you shouldn't expect something too groundbreaking. The combat mechanics are a little bit rough around the edges and can feel repetitive after some time. You will mostly fight the same enemies and there isn't much variety to it, which definitely feels a little bit uncreative and is a minus point. There are also some puzzles that you have to solve. These puzzles are not that challenging but are meant to represent a part of her psychosis and fit the narrative of the game pretty well. However, they are also going to slow down the gameplay, which some people may dislike. 

All in all, a very decent title with an interesting way of storytelling. People who are into mysterious and opaque settings will surely enjoy it. 

Have fun!

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice was recommended to me by multiple people, and it's been not just a captivating game but an experience.

The game is a dark but very intriguing exploration of mental illness backed by a Norse mythology theme. The game features amazing music and sound design and the graphics "updated for PC" look amazing. 

The game is not too long and certain gameplay elements can feel a little repetitive. However, in my opinion, the story and experience make up for it.

150939337.review:
It is an incredible journey through darkness and resilience. Set in a hauntingly beautiful world, it masterfully intertwines Norse mythology with an intimate portrayal of mental health. Senua's quest to save the soul of her loved one takes you on an emotional rollercoaster, where the line between reality and illusion blurs. The game's stunning visuals, immersive sound design, and captivating storytelling create an experience that's both haunting and awe-inspiring. Combat feels visceral and challenging, mirroring Senua's inner battles. But what truly sets this game apart is its raw portrayal of psychosis, offering a rare and profound glimpse into the complexities of the human mind. "Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice" is not just a game; it's a visceral, thought-provoking odyssey that stays with you long after the credits roll.

Overall Rating: 10/10

150301650.review:
I wanted to play this game for a long time because I read about it and the idea behind it seemed quite interesting. I finally played it. It has no tutorial, no HUD and it's relatively short. But all those things contribute to its greatness. 
I could write an essay about it but to keep it short-ish: This game has something that many games are missing: Focus!
It has no side quests, no thousands of collectables (only the runestones which are easy to find on your way), no open world shenanigans, no inventory or level ups etc. It wants to deliver an experience and that it delivers 100%.
Yes, if you died too often, you have to start from the beginning. But that only adds to the intensity of the experience.
In my opinion this game is a piece of art, dedication and focus. I recommend you to play it if you're looking for something different or special.
Hopefully the sequel will not forget what makes this one great and perhaps even build up on it.

149932033.review:
I'm not a fan of walking sims but I did enjoy Plague Tale Innocence. Like Plague Tale, this game is absolutely beautiful. The character and enemy designs are some of the best I've seen. The atmosphere is also really good.

So why didn't I like this?

The puzzles took me out of the psych aspect of the game. In my opinion, the psychological condition of Senua should have been the focus. They should have made the reward for the puzzles as clues to reality since the game is 90% puzzles.

I expected the voices in my head to be far more oppresive & varied. Most of the time, it felt like someone is just gossiping about me.

There's so much mention of the word "Darkness" that I started finding it funny/edgy/cool. The writing seems to make you want to be afraid of it or take it seriously though. They should have replaced it with another word.

Why gimp the sprint in a game where you run back and forth to solve the puzzles to progress the story? Senua can sprint during combat and in one story segment when you run away from something.

The combat also doesn't add much. It's very basic and the lock on system is annoying. Yeah you can shift focus on who you're fighting but you can't freely move the camera. Majority of the difficulty in combat is because of the camera. You will get attacked out of nowhere given how the enemies appear in this game

There's no baseline to this psychological story so you don't know what reality is. You can argue that is really set during the viking age with myths and I can argue that she is a little girl in modern times whose night light went out so she started imagining things. Both are equally valid.

149677863.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice isn't just a game; it's a haunting and deeply moving journey through the human psyche. From the moment I stepped into the shoes of the tormented Senua, I was utterly captivated. The game's unique blend of storytelling, combat, and psychological exploration is a true masterpiece that left an indelible mark on me.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Hellblade is its storytelling. Senua's personal journey through a world plagued by her own mental health challenges is nothing short of profound. The game tackles the subject of mental illness with incredible sensitivity and respect. I found myself empathizing with Senua's struggles, fears, and determination. The way the story unfolds, with Senua's inner voices providing both guidance and torment, adds layers of complexity to the narrative that I've rarely encountered in gaming.

The game's audio-visual design is nothing short of breathtaking. The stunningly detailed visuals, combined with a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack, drew me deeper into Senua's troubled mind. The use of binaural audio is a stroke of genius, creating an immersive and unsettling soundscape that left me feeling truly immersed in her world.

The combat in Hellblade, while challenging, is beautifully integrated into the narrative. Every encounter felt intense, and I was constantly pushed to improve my skills. The way the game blurs the line between reality and delusion during these moments added to the sense of unease and made every victory feel incredibly rewarding.

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is more than a game; it's a powerful and emotional experience that I won't soon forget. It takes you on a journey into the darkest recesses of the mind, exploring the complexities of mental illness in a way that's both respectful and thought-provoking. If you're looking for a game that offers a deeply personal and emotional experience, Hellblade is an absolute must-play. It's a rare gem that left me contemplating its themes long after the credits rolled, and it's an experience that I wholeheartedly recommend to anyone seeking a unique and moving gaming experience.

149239298.review:
A truly captivating artistic masterpiece. The level of passion and dedication poured into making a masterpiece such as this cannot be beaten by no other publishers I have encountered thus far. It is a journey towards darkness and the madness that comes along with it. 

[u][b]Conceptual Design.[/b][/u] As an artist, it satisfies me greatly for design to be so well placed and enveloped within a world where it can thrive to its absolute beauty. It is remarkable how a good design can make a linear world feel so dynamic. The state of ruin and decay is present throughout the levels. The design in each levels are much so dynamic and unique each time, it's refreshing.

[u][b]Audio Design.[/b][/u] It can never be too good for sound to complement the visuals. It tells a story unseen and it can reach through the audience deeply. The audio dynamics is stunning. The placement of the sources within a three-dimensional space is well demonstrated and implemented in the game. 

[u][b]Theme.[/b][/u] The theme is something that I give special attention to in most cases. It shows a horrifying depiction of one's own darkness. The battle that we all have fought in our personal lives. However, some have it worst and I felt as if I was in that scenario in the game, immersive is an understatement. Mental disturbance is one of my favorite point of focus in a game or any story driven content. It can be truly scary to have one's reality become so twisted.

[u][b]Humane Aspects.[/b][/u] If you value the embodiment of human expressions. This hits a bullseye. The presentation of emotion is very real. The voice is well complementary to the visual showcasing of emotions. At one point I felt as if the character's anxiety were transferred onto me.

Thank you for making such a great game.

149222741.review:
The developers heavily invested in the game's visual presentation, sound design, and narrative. While I was intrigued for a few hours and even completed the game, I primarily did so to justify my purchase.

Several aspects left me disappointed. The game's attempt to offer an experience through the lens of mental illness is novel, but the charm quickly faded, resulting in moments of frustration and annoyance. I empathize with those who endure such experiences due to genuine mental challenges. However, I've come to realize that crafting an entire game around this perspective may not have been the best approach. Games should primarily provide enjoyment, and this aspect felt overlooked. 

The combat mechanics showed promise but fell short in execution. The absence of a practice mode outside of combat means many players might not even discover certain features, like the melee button or specific combos. The combat's movement design was limited—while it's functional in a one-on-one scenario, the inability to move laterally becomes glaringly evident when facing multiple opponents. Players are either constrained to continually switch lock-on targets, risking blindsided hits, or resort to a constant dodging tactic. With a better movement system and opportunities for out-of-combat practice, the combat could've been the game's highlight.

Lastly, the story felt overly pretentious. It seems to strive to create a deep connection with Senua, but it missed the mark for me. By the midpoint, my engagement waned, and my primary motivation to continue was having invested money in it.

149158627.review:
I just finished Hellblade and I feel compelled to write a review for it. Games rarely have good stories--even in cases where a game's main focus is its narrative. Even more rarely, games have stories that are both good and could only be told in the medium of videogames. When talking about stories in videogames, the interactivity of the medium in relation to its narratives is only explored in the lenses of branching paths leading to different narrative outcomes/different endings. It's easy to forget that even in a game with a linear narrative, the road to get to the end is still paved by the player's interactions with the game. Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice understands that well. This is an entirely linear game, but its story of pain, loss and self-acceptance would have never resonated with me in the same way if I had watched it on a screen or read it on a page instead of sharing the journey with the titular character. The game is honest with its depiction of mental health. I don't suffer from psychosis but I know that it tends to be sensationalized for the sake of plot in most stories. Even when Hellblade uses Senua's mental health as a narrative tool, it does so fairly and without placing moral judgment on it, instead merely recognizing that it exists and that it affects her in many ways. The setting is Norse mythology stuff, but the truth is that it's only set dressing to Hellblade's story of loss: the gods and monsters of the Vikings are well-intertwined with the narrative, but a similar effort with any given mythology would have worked just as well. Norse mythology might have been chosen due to its eschatological narratives, since Senua often catastrophizes and her thoughts can end up veering to the idea that the world is ending, but this is only a vague parallel.

On the more "gamey" side of things, I went in expecting a walking simulator and I got that, kind of. There is combat in this game, with a clear FromSoftware inspiration, but in terms of difficulty the game will adapt to your ability, and there is an option to make things easier or harder if you wish to. There are puzzles and narrative sequences throughout the game, as well as some horror segments (which have some of the most terrifying moments I remember experiencing in a game). A somewhat major problem I encountered was the subtitles not working once in the 8 hours it took me to complete the game, though I will say that if you're comfortable without them, you should keep them off anyway: everything in Hellblade is completely diegetic, and subtitles might detract from immersion.

I have plenty more to say, but it's better to go in knowing less than more. This game touched me deeply like only a handful others ever have. If we're doing number scores, this might be a 10/10.

149086405.review:
Senua is an excellent story about vikings, love, loss, all coated with a thick layer of psychosis and myriad of mental health issues, neatly packed in the form of a puzzle adventure with some light  but satisfactory combat elements. 

It's not a long game, nor it is particularly challenging, but it's a 6-7 hour adventure with full voiced dialogue, absolutely excellent visual effects, a smashing soundtrack and a smashing sound direction, to the point that they had to make an entire blind segment just as a victory lap just because it was that good. 

Everything in the game surrounds Senua's mental health and how it transformed her live, and it is a big question if anything of what is currently happening is actually happening or it's just an allegory to her fight against her many inner demons. And I think it's just fine like that. 
Few games touch mental health with the depth and complexity as Senua does - most of them indies, and I love them for it - but it's great to see a big title delve into what is essentially a gamble from a marketing standpoint, and one that could have been handled very poorly to booth, as we have seen in many other productions that take a more hollywood approach to what pop culture believes is stress, trauma, psychosis, deppression, anxiety, etc. 

All in all, Hellblade achieves everything it set out to achieve, and I was never disappointed. I can't say the same about many other games.

For the most part the game is outstanding.
In my few hours experience with the game, I loved the atmosphere, the story was super intriguing. It looks breathtaking with a very immersive sound design. I even liked the gameplay - the combat was satisfying, and the puzzles were interesting enough.
Unfortunately, the camera sway completely ruins the experience for me and I get horrible motion sickness after 30 minutes or so of playing to the point that I want to throw up. I get the artistic design choice behind it and completely support it, but not including motion sickness accessibility settings where head bobbing can be turned is unacceptable.
I will gladly change my review to positive if the developers add option to turn off camera sway. Until then unfortunately I can not recommend it.

148528042.review:
This was an experience more so than a game. The gameplay on offer is a little rough around the edges at times, but serves well enough to allow you to enjoy the experience. In terms of length, I think the game is about right - it doesn't overstay its welcome nor does it leave you wishing there was more. 

The story itself is not revolutionary, but one that presents itself greater than it is thanks to the sum of all the game's parts. The visual design is excellent, with near flawless presentation; I can't recall any time where I was upset or pulled out of the game thanks to a visual bug. The audio differentiates this game from many others, offering a unique, and from what I understand, well researched glimpse into what it might be like to experience psychosis. 

I could go on, but to keep it short: this is an audio/visual experience well worth your time if the setting seems at all appealing to you. A small disclaimer too: this game is certainly not for everyone. If you struggle to find yourself interested by the trailers, then perhaps it's not for you, and that's fine too. 

If you do pick it up, absolutely wear headphones to get the most out of it and strap in for the ride. Not many games sit with me after I finish them and goad me into writing reviews, but this was one of the few that have.

148515324.review:
Well, I finally gave this one a try. The story setting and game type honestly didn't interest me much but the various positive reviews pushed me to try anyway. I do like story heavy games but not when it's more story than game, in that case I would get a better experience just reading a novel or book or watching some tv, movie or anything else. This game, in my opinion, would be more immersive and good in book format in my opinion, I can really see in front of me how it would play out and how moving it would be.

Instead, we have an "unique" game that tries something not perhaps new but unusual. I respect the attempt at showing psychosis to people and that it might help some people understand more and those who have issues relate and perhaps feel some comfort, but to me, as a game, this failed pretty badly.

From the start, we have very clunky mechanics. It's simply not fun to run around or do stuff. The "puzzles" aren't interesting or fun to complete, when you do complete them you just feel hollow because there's nothing special about them. There's little to no "reward" to our "effort". The combat is pretty bad, just a few boring actions where you probably end up just spamming one or two buttons and dodging like crazy, it's not as if you need to or should get good at "fighting" in this game, it's far too short and the combat simply doesn't matter much. The auto-lock feature was decent when you faced 1-2 enemies, but above that and it just locked onto the wrong enemies even when you were closer to other enemies. While it's meant to be that way for "immersion" and "creating the mood", it's frustrating to have no clue about her health, how many more hits she can take and so on. 

We're interrupted all the time with the game rudely stealing control of our camera to do some cutscenes. It's simply bad game design overall in this game. All the while, there's no real feeling of dread or terror from losing control or facing the challenges, as you feel comfortable enough knowing that you're going to be just fine if you ignore everything around you. 

The voices quickly become a nuisance, repeating themselves over and over and being disruptive. The protagonist, in my mind, is very unlikable, sad story and all that but the whining, screaming and monologue is something I dislike.

It's MEANT to be like that, yes. To show mental illness, or more specifically psychosis. Trying to get people who haven't got these issues to experience what they go through, perhaps trying to evoke feelings of sympathy. To me, that doesn't change how bad of an experience it was and not in a "oh, I feel like I'm walking with her on this road of madness" kind of way but rather just plain dull, boring and frustrating at best.

So... As an educational game, yeah, maybe, give it a try. But the story it tells is pretty basic, the visuals go for shock value, there's shockingly little "game" in this game (not only little to do but also minimal control) and everything outside the cut scenes are just overall so-so quality. I never enjoyed it or felt immersed from start to end, after an hour or two, I started to just want it to end, after finishing it I felt relief, I'm probably going to forget this game in a short while as it left little impression. The lore was pretty good though.

Fail as a game, kind of a pass as an educational game, good potential as a basis for a book, though it needs to be greatly fleshed out and taken step by step.

148473447.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is not merely a video game; it's an emotional journey, a psychological exploration, and a work of art that demands your attention and introspection. After spending 8.6 hours in the harrowing world of Senua, it's evident that this game is a unique and profound experience.

Set in a hauntingly beautiful representation of the Viking age, Hellblade places you in the shoes of Senua, a Celtic warrior suffering from psychosis. The narrative revolves around her quest to rescue the soul of her deceased lover, Dillion, from the Norse underworld. However, it quickly becomes apparent that the real journey is into the depths of Senua's mind.

The game's portrayal of mental illness is unprecedented in the gaming world. Through the use of binaural audio, visual distortions, and intense storytelling, Hellblade provides players with a visceral understanding of Senua's struggles. As you guide her through her personal hell, you'll witness her debilitating hallucinations, inner torment, and wavering grip on reality.

The heart of Hellblade is its storytelling and character development. Senua is not merely a protagonist; she is a fully realized, empathetic character, brought to life through the remarkable performance of Melina Juergens. Senua's journey is as much an exploration of her psyche as it is a physical quest. It's a testament to the power of video games as a medium for immersive storytelling.

Gameplay in Hellblade balances action, puzzle-solving, and exploration. The combat, while not overly complex, is satisfying and visceral. The puzzles are cleverly integrated into the narrative, representing Senua's inner battles. The game's world is dark and foreboding, and every nook and cranny is filled with lore and atmosphere.

Hellblade's audio design deserves special mention. The game recommends the use of headphones, and for a good reason. The binaural audio is a masterstroke, creating an unsettling and immersive soundscape that directly contributes to the player's understanding of Senua's mental state.

The 8.6 hours you've spent playing Hellblade may feel like a mere glimpse into Senua's story, but it's a testament to the game's power that it leaves a lasting impact long after you've put down the controller. The game's poignant conclusion will stay with you, prompting introspection and discussion.

In conclusion, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an exceptional work of art, transcending the boundaries of video games. It's a powerful exploration of mental illness, personal struggle, and the human spirit. With its unforgettable character, innovative audio design, and intense storytelling, Hellblade is a unique and profound experience that pushes the boundaries of what games can achieve. It's a masterpiece that will leave you with a newfound appreciation for the medium's potential as a tool for empathy and understanding.

148382320.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a rare game, one that try to tackle mental health issues and manages to do so in a remarkable way. The sound design is spectacular. Be sure to use headphones to make use of the binaural recordings. The game isn't very long count 8 to 12 hours... intense hours...

This game takes you on a journey through trauma and the shadow self where you battle psychosis and a troubled past. Be it from a mystical viewpoint (celtic/viking "shamanism" lore) or a mental health one (hearing voices, fragmenting mind, hallucinations), the game succeed to engage you with Senua in a unique way. The combat is meaty and pretty tense at times, the puzzles well implemented, but the real star of the show for me are the graphics, the sound design and the narration. There is no hud so the immersion is total, the atmosphere heavy and thick. 

It has been a pleasure from start to finnish to follow Senua into the wild in her search for answers and salvation. We need more games like this, the effects of psychosis are spot on and it raises awareness for mental health issues and shows what they truly are and where they can come from. The historical/lore setting is spot on to take on these issues. 

It's original, beautifull, scary and enganging, well recommended!

148075274.review:
Story - 8.9

Graphics - 9.0

Sound Design - 8.1

Voice Acting / Mo-Cap - 9.8

Game Mechanics - 7.9

I nearly gave up at the start of the game, I feel like it dragged on a bit with the slow movement between puzzles - but as the game went on, the story kept me there with the great voice acting and motion capture. Clearly a lot of effort was put into this game and isn't meant for a casual play-through, though I question the idea to make it perma death as the only mode, this should have surely been a new option for a 2nd play-through? Hoping there is a few improvements to the flow and combat in the 2nd game. Combat wasn't terrible, but could feel a bit janky at times with the camera and groups of enemies surrounding you.

Dealing with mental health issues within myself and various friends, it was quite harrowing at times to play-through, but was pretty cathartic in some ways. Just be wary if you're currently struggling with psychosis or other serious mental illness.

Definitely worth playing at least once.

148013702.review:
Title: Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice - A Haunting Journey of Letting Go

Rating: 4/5

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice offers an eerie and deeply unique experience that dives into the depths of psychosis while delivering a compelling story about love, loss, and the power of letting go. While it may not be everyone's cup of tea, if you're looking for an unforgettable and distinct gaming experience, Hellblade is definitely worth a try.

From the moment you step into Senua's twisted world, you are immediately captivated by the game's haunting atmosphere. The developers' attention to detail shines through, creating a stunning visual representation of the protagonist's warped perception of reality. The combination of eerie sound design and unsettling visuals creates an immersive experience that keeps you on edge throughout the entire journey.

What sets Hellblade apart is its masterful storytelling. The game delves into themes of mental health, delusion, and inner demons with a sense of authenticity rarely seen in video games. Senua's battle with her own psychosis is depicted in a raw and emotional manner, enabling players to empathize with her struggles. The narrative unfolds gradually, weaving together a tale that's as dark and unsettling as it is thought-provoking. As players guide Senua through her own personal hell, they become invested in her journey of self-discovery and acceptance.

The gameplay mechanics perfectly complement the sinister atmosphere and the themes at hand. As players navigate through the twisted reality of Senua's mind, they encounter challenging puzzles, intense combat sequences, and mind-bending illusions. These elements are seamlessly intertwined, allowing players to experience, firsthand, the chaos and torment that Senua battles within herself. The integration of binaural audio techniques adds an extra layer of immersion, creating a deeply unsettling sensation as whispers and voices envelop your ears, contributing to the overall eerie atmosphere.

It's important to note that Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice may not be for everyone. The game's themes and presentation can be disturbing and overwhelming for some players. However, if you are willing to step outside your comfort zone and embrace a unique and unconventional experience, Hellblade offers a journey that is immensely rewarding. The storytelling and exploration of mental health issues demonstrate the potential for video games as a medium for deep emotional resonance and understanding.

In conclusion, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is not your typical gaming experience. It's an unsettling, dark, and deeply introspective journey that explores the uncharted realms of psychosis and self-discovery. With its superb storytelling, haunting atmosphere, and thought-provoking themes, Hellblade stands as a testament to the incredible potential of video games as a means of immersive storytelling. While it may not cater to everyone's taste, those seeking a unique and unforgettable experience should not miss it.

146808309.review:
[h1]From Orkney to Helheim[/h1]

Departing Orkney bearing towards the boundaries of the sea drawn by the glutinous mist, it’s said that the lands of Hel can be approached. Bodies stay in solitude, whose shrieks fade into the breadth of a dark and foggy world. Beings in soreness, slew in a dishonourable and ignominious manner, Senua will hike a path through the winding land of Helheim.

I won't expose you its whole story, nor will I give you crumbs of analysis. Just know that Senua, a Pict warrior from Scotland, Dillion was murdered. She involuntarily espoused Norse customs, so she believes her beloved is confined in Hel. She decides to make a journey to those dark lands to bring him back in exchange for a sacrifice, soul for soul. This is how the quest begins.

[h1]The purification journey of a geilt[/h1]

One of the essential topics is a conception of [i]visions[/i] from a double point of view developed in the game: psychosis and Celtic-Nordic religiosity. If a person suffers a vision or outburst of ecstasy, at that time they were considered a possible aspirant for an oracle or sibyl. In our epochs, that person is understood as someone who suffers from a mental illness, whose vision is nothing more than a distortion of reality. Maybe one day I'll talk about it, for now this is the backbone for the happening of the plot.

We must comprehend the game from double point of view: a journey of purification of a mystical form and, at the same time, a path that offers a feeling from a character with a case of severe psychosis. To appreciate this, the plot script is well composed and written in the style of the Nordic sagas. Although it also has the Greek theatrical structure, where the drama in Senua is emphasized by the choirs, in this case, the voices in her head. It has a discursive duality, an external and internal sphere. The plot achieves to be complete by bringing together both spheres. In this way they’re not altered worlds, or different realities, but reality itself, although amplified or dilated to the point of longsighted something more than the others. Or at least it gives me that impression.

However, I loved their mode of speaking, voicing and expressing; the tone and rhythm of the discourses, the characters does so with a poetic tone. Furthermore, the story is revealed as the narrative layers of Senua and her journey unfold. Along the pathway she uncovers her past, context and quest. The actors behind the characters do their performance amazingly, mainly that of Melina Juergens. Her act is staggering, whose expressions manage to transfer and tense diverse feelings to the player. And with the camera shots, where sometimes she seems to dialog to the spectator, she bring about to agitate the player, also giving a feeling of stupor in the dramatic scenes of the plot.

[h1]Mystical hallucination[/h1]

Exceptional exertion was put into finding a way to represent her visions and voices in Senua. This bring out the drama of the story, as well as connects to the gameplay. The exterior was represented through artistic and well-lit locations with a combination of nature, settlements and Celtic-Nordic art. The film events take place as a photomontage in real time, in which the game and a scene with a real image are coalesced, as happens in the game [i]Control[/i]. But when Senua experiences from visions, the scenery changes in addition to distorting the image. A good job is done with illumination and image effects, awareness and double exposure. What it does is only open paths where apparently they weren’t there without altering reality. All of this will play an important role in the gameplay in addition to the plot.

On the other hand, I recommend playing it with headphones. In this way, you’ll be able to appreciate its binaural sound, since the sounds have an effect as if you were hearing Senua's voices that are speaking around you. The voices are an essential detail, they concoct part of the narrative layer along with constantly nattering with the protagonist. Sometimes it is a bomb of sounds where, at least for me, they try to grab you and pull you to in the end persuade, confuse or help you out on some occasions. I didn't know who to listen to, and I wanted to say, enough, shut up! Which, the game attains its purpose of performing the effect of hearing voices in the head.

Another notable point is its delicious soundtrack. It was composed by David Garcia and Andy LaPlegua. Although I listened to most of it during moments of battle, it contains a rich theme in narrative terms. The music mainly expresses Norse mythology. It and the steles both tell us the mythology of the northerners. Since the music expresses such a northern world, it uses dark and Nordic folk music. Although sometimes the music comes with elements of electronic pieces. However, this still gives vigorous, loud scenes, but at the same time it’s dark, beauty and cold. It’s undoubtedly a masterpiece where it concentrates the world to which Senua seems not to belong. However, she’s fighting against them towards her Ragnarök.

[h1]The skill of guiding paths[/h1]

The game frequently uses signs and symbols. Not only do they have implication to the story, but they’re also considered part of the gameplay. There’re three types of gameplay: exploration, battle and puzzle solving. Battle is a mode that’s simple, but is enjoyable in every encounter against opponents. Although it has few combinations with the sword, it’s still interesting to give a diverse rhythm to the story. These battles are important, since winning them will open the way. But if you die constantly, the game will be erased, as the darkness grows with each defeat until it reaches the head where the soul resides. So it's good to pay attention, since you’ll always receive advice from Druth, the Darkness or the voices. They’ll alert us when an enemy wants to attack us from behind.

Furthermore, solving puzzles has been its memorable gameplay. To do this, the game will use runes, symbols or images to make your way through perspectives and optical illusions. For example, there’s a locked door, I listen to the advice of a voice, I focus my attention to record the rune and look in the same scenario for an object that contains the perspective (or pareidolia) that forms the rune. There’ll always be a flashing indicator informing me that something is there so I can use my focus and capture rune, symbol or image. As the game progresses, the pace also changes, so it won't be all about solving puzzles all the time.

[h1]Senua’s saga[/h1]

I like to go through the game numerous times, the journey of which has been impressive and exciting. It's like watching a movie or reading an Edda poem or prose. The game has delightful content that’s enjoyed at all times, from its narrative to its modest gameplay. It’s quite lasting, especially if you die many times since the save game will be deleted if you be defeated constantly. If you haven't played it and you like games with good stories, I recommend this one. Above all, it’s at a good price during sales. Without the need for DLC, the game is complete.

[h1]Recommendation: 10/10[/h1]

I really want to finish this game because the story seems pretty good, and the atmosphere is also very appealing, but the gameplay is unbearably tedious. It's SO. MUCH. WALKING. It makes for a very unpleasant and annoying experience, just like the combat, which is always the same and gets old after the first three fights.

But one of the most obnoxious features is the background voices that are ALWAYS talking. It's like having a bunch of ASMR actresses backseating you the entire time. I eventually had to turn them off, which, thank God, you can. The graphics are very good, but there's always a weird motion blur that you can't turn off, and it honestly gives me headaches at times. That, and sudden FPS drops, which I don't know if that's my computer or the game, but I am able to run other graphically intensive games with no issues, so there's that.

Overall, it's a decent game for the price that I paid for it, but not one I would recommend.

146494063.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a tour de force in narrative-driven gaming, seamlessly blending psychological horror and Norse mythology. This masterpiece transcends traditional gaming boundaries, offering an immersive experience that's as emotionally haunting as it is visually stunning.

The game's most striking feature is its portrayal of mental health. Senua's psychosis is depicted with a level of authenticity rarely seen in any medium. Through exceptional sound design and meticulously crafted visuals, players are drawn into her tormented psyche, creating an unparalleled sense of empathy.

The combat system is both challenging and rewarding, demanding precise timing and strategic thinking. The dark, atmospheric world is brought to life with jaw-dropping graphics and a hauntingly beautiful score. The narrative unfolds organically, driven by Senua's journey and her internal struggles.

One area I can think of which can be worked upon is game-play speed. It feels a lil-bit slow by modern standards.

To summarise,  I'd definitely say go for it. I bet you'd find the story too appealing to pass and maybe, maybe you get a new perspective of seeing things xD.

146429738.review:
After letting Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice collect digital dust in my steam library for a few years after buying it on sale, I finally played it.

Have you ever finished a show, a movie, or a game that doesn't leave your mind after completing it until days or even weeks later because it had such a strong impact on you?

Well, this game left a mark on my soul. It will never leave me.

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice by NinjaTheory is a powerful & beautifully tragic story with one of the most raw & painfully real performances I have ever seen by Juergens Melina, who was born to play the role of Senua.

Senua's Saga: Hellblade 2 has now become my most anticipated game of 2024.

146427879.review:
La mente humana, un universo tan maravilloso como misterioso, siendo cada uno de nuestros cerebros un universo en sí mismo. Hellblade nos narra una historia desde la perspectiva de alguien que sufre psicosis, un punto de vista totalmente original en el mundo de los videojuegos.

El punto de partida precisamente es la visión tanto interna desde Senua, como externa desde su propia comunidad, la psicosis, y cómo está llena de estigmas y desprecio de tal forma que es desterrada por supuestamente provocar la maldición de su pueblo. El marco en el que nos encontramos son tierras escocesas, el pueblo picto, durante las invasiones vikingas; la mentalidad en muchos casos simple de estas sociedades hacía que el chamán de turno se erigiera como figura onmisapiente, y era muy fácil culpar a alguien con un padecimiento mental de los males que asolaban a los lugareños, como si tuviera alguna culpa. A grandes rasgos, de la lucha tanto interna como externa, la culpabilidad por la muerte de las personas queridas, entre ellas su amado Dillion, y todo el universo de viaje y redención por la mitología nórdica trata este juego, es mejor experimentar y seguir el pilar fundamental del juego, que es su historia.

Como buena parte del juego son secuencias cinemáticas en las que veremos la reacción de Senua frente a todo tipo de adversidades y retos, es muy importante hacer hincapié en esta sección, el juego ha contado en todo momento con personas que sufren de psicosis y profesionales que tratan este fenómeno, siempre poniendo especial sensibilidad en no estigmatizar, pues las causas y consecuencias son muy diversas y nadie está indemne a sufrirlas. Senua se nos presenta como una muchacha que sufre de delirios y oye voces contradictorias, y ha sido marcada como dije antes como causante de los males de su pueblo, se siente angustia por ella cuando está sufriendo algún episodio, cómo cae presa de la desesperación y el desaliento, mientras que en levísimos momentos somos testigos de briznas de esperanza en su vida, todo ello interpretado por la actriz Melina Juergens. 

Como comentaba el desarrollo de la historia, su personalidad, y cómo hace frente a su mal es el pilar fundamental del juego. Uno se siente partícipe del sufrimiento de Senua y siempre desea que pueda sobreponerse ante las adversidades tan crueles a las que se ve sometida.

La jugabilidad: nos movemos manejando a Senua por entornos lineales en tercera persona, con lugares ricos en detalles y con efectos gráficos espectaculares (los juegos de luces y sombras asombran así como los efectos climáticos) pero demasiado lineales, con un único camino a seguir, a veces son parajes naturales típicos del norte, auténticos paraísos, mientras que iremos alternando con lugares hostiles, zonas infernales y baldíos e incluso las propias pesadillas y mente de Senua. El juego es bastante corto pero intenso, en unas ocho horas podremos completarlo, hay puzzles que resolver pero son fáciles, buscar runas en las formas del entorno para abrir puertas y avanzar mediante el uso de la concentración y encontrar estelas que nos relatan pasajes de la mitología nórdica. En algunas ocasiones tendremos que luchar con enemigos e incluso algún jefe final, pero los combates están desaprovechados, no suponen un reto incluso en la mayor dificultad y son todos iguales con los mismos enemigos.

Cabe reseñar comprobado en varios equipos diferentes que la optimización no es buena, con muchas bajadas de frames y de rendimiento, en equipos que superan ampliamente los requisitos recomendados y con diferentes configuraciones.

Los efectos sonoros son buenos, con un doblaje en inglés profesional y que realzan muy bien los momentos más críticos de Senua, algunas melodías interesantes y muy relevante todos los sonidos que pueblan la mente de Senua ya sean las propias voces que la persiguen, la voz de su amado, la de sus enemigos o las de los propios dioses entre otras, resulta bastante impactante.

En definitiva lo que más llama la atención de este título y por lo que será recordado no es por la jugabilidad, sino por el trasfondo que presenta, algo que en otros videojuegos ha sido planteado pero como algo sutil y sin rigor, tan solo como parte de la historia, aquí se afronta desde un perspectiva adulta por parte tanto de personas que lo padecen como profesionales que lo estudian, teniendo en todo momento en cuenta sus opiniones, algo que puede comprobarse en un más que recomendable documental que acompaña el juego; si nos salimos del planteamiento inicial tenemos prácticamente un corto "walking simulator" con puzzles sencillos y escenas de lucha mediocres, pero con buena historia y entornos espectaculares.

NOTA 7/10

146372519.review:
Played through this in one go: an incredibly immersive and unforgettable experience. A few thoughts in no particular order that might help you decide whether this game is for you:

- The game play consists of puzzles and combat.
    - Puzzles were creative and fun if sometimes a wee bit tedious
    - The combat ended up being more complex than met the eye, and I enjoy games that don't hand hold the learning the curve.
- Soundscape is 11/10. Playing through with high quality headphones was such a rich experience.
- Thematically this is as much a horror game as it is anything else, in the best possible way. To me, good horror as a genre forces introspection into my own real issues. And while I don't suffer from psychosis specifically, many of Senua's experiences and struggles were frighteningly relatable.
- I love games that tell their story in exactly the amount of time required; this game doesn't need to be any shorter or longer in my opinion.

Overall, I loved this game a lot and will think about it often over the next decades of my life, I imagine.

Generally pretty good.

I would recommend but get it on sale. Got to counter balance the 'masterpiece' reviews. I don't want to be too negative because it is a well made game, the devs definitely deserve credit but..... it is tedious as hell.

The combat is atrocious, mainly consists of smashing LMB and dodging super predictable attacks. You could say it isn't a combat focused game, which I guess is true so stop throwing multiple enemies at me, especially with no target switch (i've read that mouse wheel does it subsequently but I completed before this information).

Plot is unique and it has a lot of cool features like the inner voices which are useful. 

You will have have to go back for the collectables... which is again, tedious. 

If this was a 40+ hour story line there is no chance I would have seen it through. But it is worth a go for sure.

Also, I had serious FPS issues around water... dropping to like 15FPS at times. There isn't enough flexibility in the settings to tweak graphic settings so I had to turn it way down, which really is a shame because you can tell at high settings it would look absolutely incredible (i7 & 1080).

Give it a go, it is good if not tedious at times, it is not a masterpiece.

146179573.review:
Los norteños dicen que algún día el mundo terminará en lo que llaman Ragnarok, el destino de los dioses. Primero, habrá un terrible invierno que durará tres años. Luego, la humanidad se enfrentará a sí misma. Los hermanos lucharán a muerte entre si, y la gente olvidará lo que le debe a su familia. Serán tiempos difíciles, llenos de crímenes. Será una era de hachas y espadas. El viento soplará entre casas abandonadas, los lobos caminarán por donde los niños jugaban. El mundo acabará en ruinas.

Los norteños dicen que los dioses librarán su ultima batalla en Ragnarok. Su vigía tocará un cuerno que se oirá en el mundo entero, y Odin hablará con la cabeza cortada de Mimir, que le dará buenos consejos. La tierra de los gigantes retumbará con el ruido de su ejercito en movimiento. Los dioses se reunirán, los enanos abandonarán sus piedras. Los gigantes de hielo vendrán del este, y la serpiente de Midgard agitará las olas. Las águilas chillarán y desgarrarán los cadáveres con sus picos amarillos. El barco de los muertos zarpará.

Los norteños dicen que, cuando llegue el Ragnarok, los dioses se enfrentarán a un barco lleno de enemigos, que Loki habrá dirigido hacia Asgard. El barco transportará a los gigantes de fuego, al lobo que engullirá el sol y a todo tipo de criaturas oscuras. Surt se unirá a ellos con su espada de fuego. Los acantilados se derrumbarán, los trols caminarán por la tierra, los hombres recorrerán el camino a Hel y los cielos se abrirán.

Los norteños dicen que todos los dioses librarán su batalla en Ragnarok. Odin luchará contra el monstruoso lobo y morirá, pero su hijo lo vengará y hundirá su espada en el corazón de la bestia. Freyr se enfrentará a Surt, pero habrá regalado su espada por amor, y sin ella, no podrá defenderse de las llamas. Thor atacará a la serpiente de Midgard en vano. El sol se volverá negro, la tierra se hundirá en el mar, las estrellas desaparecerán. El fuego y el agua se juntarán y el vapor se disparará y las llamas rivalizarán con el cielo. Los cielos y la tierra y todo el mundo arderá. Todos los dioses morirán, así como los guerreros del Valhalla y las personas de todas partes. Senua, prepárate para Ragnarok, porque se avecina.

146092994.review:
Puzzles sencillos, jefes finales poco desafiantes y una dificultad general moderada, cosas que en cualquier juego resultarían negativas aquí no implican un problema, no es lo que el juego busca resaltar y esta bien. Hellblade busca presentarnos una experiencia distinta, una experiencia enfocada en lo narrativo y en lo ambiental, un relato interactivo que te sumerja en el mundo en las primeras lineas y en algunos párrafos te resulte difícil despegarte y, para alegría de todos, tiene éxito.
Narrativamente es excelente, la música y la no-música están encajadas de manera precisa junto con la jugabilidad, ambos acompañan la tensión del jugador como componente activo dentro del mundo en ciertos escenarios o como protagonista en algunos otros. Todo dentro de un mundo lleno de emociones que, a pesar de que el juego nos muestre su muerte y abandono, se siente vivo, vivo y como si nos persiguiera durante todo el juego.
Lo único que podría resaltar como negativo son algunos bugs aleatorios y que la canción final es horrible, un desliz lamentable considerando que el ost general es brillante. Quitando esos detalles, es un juego que todos debemos experimentar. 

100% recomendado

145758888.review:
I hated the game. Watching a girl getting mentally tortured for more than 10 hours playtime was disgusting for me. Of course, it was clear from the beginning that the game is about mental illness and loss of the beloved. I also give the developers credit for wanting to deal with the complex and difficult topic of mental illness in a computer game, but the implementation was hard for me to bear. Perhaps this is not a good topic for an entertainment medium like computer games. Perhaps I’m not the right player for such a game. Maybe I'm too sensitive. 

In games that are supposed to do something to the player, I think there needs to be a strong emotional counterbalance to the emotional negative scenes. Something to take a breath, emotionally. That comes too short. The puzzles, at least, or the scenes where you just walk through the nordic underworld, don't do that.

The puzzles are cool, but because they are so repetitive they get boring quickly. You've got the trick down, but you have to solve it over and over again. The same goes for the fights and opponents. After the third wave against the same opponents, the battles are no longer exciting, just mechanical.

The graphics are great, but the game is technically not optimized. My RTX 3090 was at its absolute limit at 4K and I had to deal with FPS drops from time to time.

145702335.review: I LOVE THE HEAVY AND UPLIFTING SOUND OF THE VOICES AND THAT SOMETIMES THEY SPEAK ALL AT ONCE

145690598.review:
Truly impressive and innovating. Ninja Theory has done a great job at really fleshing out the personality of their characters and drawing the player into the world, epic mythology, and Senua's struggles both within and without. I felt like I was playing a fresh telling of Dante's Inferno through a new and mythic lens. 

The multiplicity of viewpoints/narratives give a true sense of Senua's inner struggle and the "story teller's" lore add even more to the feeling of a Dante re-telling as well as giving an overall vibe of other classic literature epics told in oral tradition.

The game-play mechanics itself were implemented very lightly in such a way to give a true realism to the adventure without any need for upgrade/crafting, skill trees, or endless item searching. This allows for full and realistic story immersion without any unnecessary added stresses. The mostly linear play-path also helps to alleviate the subconscious distractions of managing character mechanics and completionist OCD, giving full-immerse mental attention to Senua's mental state(s). I did enjoy the one "collectible" aspect which, although unnecessary for progression, provided and extra layer to the overall story.

The combat, though somewhat challenging at times but not truly punishing, is straightforward, realistically uncomplicated and adds the necessary edge (no pun intended) needed for the player to feel like they have a little control within the growing darkness of the overall experience. 

The perspective based puzzle system is amazing! Some were easy to solve, others took a while but in all it proved to be a mystically vivid and rewarding experience!!

The soundtrack is amazing!! The depth and precision to both music, world ambiance, and "aural effects" are what makes the entire experience so visceral and gripping! This is definitely a game to play with headphones in the dark, it will keep you on the edge of your seat!!!

In all, this game is definitely a labor of love. The real-life development process used really captures everything the developers were hoping for and more. The actors really gave their all to this project, knowing how to pull the right heartstrings at the right time.

I am still on the edge of my seat after this game, waiting with great anticipation for it's squeal. This will be one of the very few games to stay on my computer for as long as I have one as I feel it's more than just a game, this is truly an epic tale.

Thanks Ninja Theory, you have renewed my faith in "good" gaming, projects like this are the future.

145687199.review:
I HATE THIS GAME SO MUCH!!!! BUT ... YOU SHOULD BUY IT

FIrst and foremost let's give it a 10/10 for graphics. This game is beautiful and ahead of its time when first made and even better after the enhanced patch came through for the graphics that in 2023, it holds up very well and will continue to do so for years to come. But why will you also hate this game as much as I do? Because it simply will drive you nuts with the puzzles. These are not clever puzzles but simply simple puzzles but the way they are put together is: "Okay, here is the solution to solve this stage and open the door but now let's add a whole bunch of unuseful add ons in the scene to the puzzle itself to make it really frustratingly confusing so that you never want to play our game ever again. We already got your money so who cares." I never finished the game and probably never will because the puzzles are so frustrating. Then, I delete the game and wont touch it for a year or two. Then I redownload the game to realize why I hate it so much. This is a game if you do not play it constantly, you WILL forget everything. Absolutely horrible. The hours I put in is not because I love this game but simply me walking around trying to figure out the stupid puzzles. The game is a linear game but don't compare this to Tomb Raider's puzzles. Tomb Raider's puzzles are clever and designed in a way where you can always remember even if time has elapsed why I continuously play the Tomb Raider's series over the years because the games simply are fun and clever. This game, when I see other players on YouTube re-download it then I'm like gonna give it another shot to just realize myself why I play it then stop because the puzzles are horrible. Horrible as what you may ask? After you solve a puzzle you're like ... "Ahhh how stupid now that I solved this puzzle because it was so easy then you ask yourself why were all these dumb things in the way then?" You solve a puzzle and it doesn't make you proud, it makes you feel stupid to hate the game. And that's what I mean that these puzzles are not clever but simply not well thought through. if the graohics were horrible, I'd never recommend this game to anyone.

Should you buy it? Yes. Should you play it? Only if you are ready to hate this game as much as I do and also continue to play it constantly so you don't forget anything. Other than that, skip it entirely and go play Tomb Raider. And if part II has more clever puzzles then buy part II and just play it without never playing part I because part II will reference enough, you will know part I.

I am a counselor as is my profession and this game does represent well what happens to people who suffer from mental illness or trauma. The solutions are easy but it is all the unnecessary things one puts as purpuseful hurdles in their minds that they never get to the solution until they do. Or, never heal from mental illness or trauma. But, to the credit of Ninja Theory, if thatbis what they were going for then they succeeded at making me and millions of people hate their game. it's a game and not a counseling session that will be a lifetime. I just wished the puzzles were more clever and not fatigued from an individual who struggles with mental illness or trauma, and made the players fatigue with them. The graphics is amazing and the acting splendid. But, it is a game I will never complete unfortunately and that very much disappoints me as I want to play games to complete it.

All right, honest review and hopes it helps and hopes Ninja Theory reads it to go "Damn, point taken."

Probably one of the best intros to a game I've ever experienced. While the voices do get a little stale as the game goes on, the voice acting is excellent and I think the developers had a good feeling for how long they could stretch out the concept.

145609917.review:
Where do I even begin with this one? Let me get the rating out of the way first... an easy 10/10. 
This game deserves so much more love and attention from the gaming community. Meta-defining, genre-bending games such as these lead the path to bringing about massive change.

In this game, you play as Senua, a Celtic warrior with severe psychosis, as you navigate her view of reality and fight towards getting back your loved one. But beware, for your reality changes as does your perception as you slowly get consumed by the dark. This game does a masterful job at portraying some of the aspects of a psychotic mind and weaves a brilliant plot with you as the main plot thread. 

The elements of Nordic and psychological horror were displayed so well, it truly makes one think twice before taking the next step. The music/soundtrack rarely suits a game so well, as it weaves itself into the experience. The combat sections are fairly straightforward in nature, but can get really difficult at times which adds caution to the wind. Every element of this game ties well with the other elements creating this seamless experience that makes one question reality and makes the gamer more aware of psychosis and their victims.

I can walk away from this game saying that I am a changed man. This game leaves you with heavy, emotional and cerebral baggage as it should. I can only hope for this being the first step towards a more inclusive and exploratory gaming world, using the extremely flexible medium of games to retell stories that couldn't have been told otherwise.

Kudos to NinjaTheory!

Let me tell you, this is one of the darkest and most depressing experiences out there. After playing through the game, I felt absolutely crushed and in tears by the story that I have just witnessed. This is such a well crafted tale with a unique, dark and sinister atmosphere.

However, I also have to add, that this is not your classic video game. It is more of an interactive movie with no "real" gameplay. 145203707.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a great interactive story in itself that leaves a deep impression.
The graphics are stunning, with environments that are sure to make jaws drop and characters that seem to have walked right out of photos.
The sound design also deserves a big compliment: the intense soundtrack covers every nook and cranny of the emotional spectrum, while the voice/actors clearly play their hearts out.
It's also great how the game exposes a socially difficult theme such as psychosis in an adult and extremely entertaining way.

The game is otherwise very beautiful on the steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xyv5Yaoqk9Y

That psychic, narrative factor isn't just what sets Hellblade apart from many other action adventures, it's immediately what makes this game one of a kind.
Entertainment taboos are broken with the sometimes fragile Senua, in addition to the fact that this kind of mental malaise is also made insightful for those who have no experience with it.
Because while Hellblade is a story about a Celtic Pict who has a mythical adventure during the early Middle Ages, it is also a story about a woman who tries to live with psychoses.

The attractive appearance is partly due to the phenomenal graphic style, where the natural environments you visit look as simple as they are stylish. Because the camera hangs right behind the main character Senua, the adventure feels very intimate and the wide surroundings appear all the more grandiose. In addition; I'm not sure, but it seems like the visions and memories of other characters you see popping up all the time were shot on a real camera.
That is then combined with gameplay footage, resulting in a unique mix that I've never seen in a game before.

Hellbalde: Senua's Sacrifice is really a very special title. Admittedly, the puzzles are very well done.
This title revolves around Senua and her struggle with herself. You can see the entire game and the entire story as a metaphor.
All the difficulties she encounters can be traced back to her psychosis. This is also due to the voices she hears, and so do you as a player, and her very good acting very impressively portrayed.

145147748.review:
It is extraordinary how simple games, with well thought out and careful execution makes a game so awesome.
There's only a handful of voice actors, but they carry us through the game on their backs with excellent dramatic voices and emotional delivery.
I usually don't like cinematic games since they are usually presumptuous and limit player to obscene levels to have the player see what the devs want you to see. Not here. The loadings are seamless, the moments of player move or action limitation exist usually on beginning or end of chapters, and while it's certainly linear, I didn't feel the game was dragging me around.
I also am not a fan of puzzle games, but I've actually enjoyed the ones here. They are challenging, especially if you're solving the earlier ones and are not accustomed to what you can or can't do with the game mechanics, but nothing that can't be solved with some patience and perspective. No need for a PhD.

I regret having bought this on a recommendation and having forgotten it for years. 
Short, but worth every hour of gameplay!

This game does some fun things with its story telling, and the audio and voice acting is fantastic, but unfortunately they forgot to make an actual fun game. The gameplay consists entirely of (slowly) jogging through narrow corridor levels that might look pretty at first, but quickly become repetitive in their appearance, solving the occasional puzzle for toddlers, and fighting a few enemies here and there. And saying "enemies, plural" is being generous, because in terms of variety, there is no variety. There's Axe dude, mace dude, mace dude with shield, and bigger axe dude. And that's literally it, for the entire game. The combat controls are very basic, and function with a forced auto-lock on system that prevents you from moving around freely. Is there a second enemy behind you? Too bad, the only way you can turn around or reposition is by awkwardly shuffling around by spamming the evade button. You *can* sprint during combat, but only directly towards an enemy. Early on this isn't a huge problem, but by the end you'll be fighting large groups of enemies, with a combat system that just doesn't properly support fighting more than one enemy at a time.

If you're really interested in this game, just watch a playthrough on youtube. It's probably genuinly a better experience, because you can just skip the boring parts.

If you are looking for a visually appealing walking simulator, because 80 percent of it is you walking back and forth at a frustratingly low pace to activate various puzzles, then this is the game for you. Otherwise, give it a pass.

144755649.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a game tackling the difficult subject matter of mental illness, particularly psychosis and schizophrenia. As someone who dealt with the subject myself via a loved one, I can tell how much work went into this game to portray it accurately. There is even a small "Making Of" documentary in the game, showing the great lengths that were taken to make this game as accurately terrifying as possible, highlighting the depths of this illness while following Senua on a quest to save her loved one from Hel.

The game's audiovisual presentation is astounding, with voices talking to you every step, from every angle. It really immerses you in the game and in the condition it is portraying. The environments are gorgeous, the voice acting is great and you can never go wrong with Norse and Celtic mythology.

The game does, however, lack a bit in the gameplay department. The game essentially consists of walking, an occasional sequence where you have to run fast, fights and rune puzzles. The rune puzzles have you find objects in the environment that look like specific runes. It's fun at first, but gets old very quickly as you have to do it a lot. There are one or two other interesting puzzles, but they are just used once and then it's back to finding runes.

The fights are very one-dimensional, and while they're never too bad or hard, they are a bit frustrating in the control department. The camera locks onto seemingly random enemies, based on whether they are attacking or not, and so the fights lack a bit of control which makes some hits unavoidable. Later on, you unlock an ability to slow down time, which makes it a lot better. The bosses mix things up a bit with their own patterns and tactics.

Sure, the game is primarily a walking simulator; but there is gameplay to interrupt the walking, and it's a mixed bag as mentioned. Still, it's easily looked past; Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is one of the most impressive games I've played in years when it comes to presentation, the sensible tackling of a difficult subject matter and the evolution of games as a storytelling medium. I am eagerly awaiting the sequel!

144699399.review:

PROS:

The Psychosis effect is great, made me feel like one of the voices circling around her

CONS:

Quite demanding if you want to max out the graphics
Combat gets lack luster later on and more annoying than fun
some backtracking in areas
story doesn't really make too much sense unless you watch the video feature afterwards

144485266.review:
This game very vividly captures the emotional roller coaster that is psychosis. You get to see the world through the eyes of someone who suffers from severe mental illness represented as closely as possible through research and interviews of real people who have had these symptoms, and you'll get to explore very detailed and awesome environments that are all constructed on the mental plane of Senua.

Starting off, you'll feel uncomfortable with the voices in your head, but as the game progresses you'll feel more used to them and eventually grow to accept them as a part of yourself, really making you feel like you're in the mind of this character and feeling what they're going through in their everyday life. It's a very educational experience while also being a fun game with an amazing atmosphere.

Moving on to the gameplay aspects, the combat is very fun and intuitive. Kill your enemies and try not to get hit. You can make different combos, you have special moves such as lunge attacks, counters and kicks, and all the enemies are interesting enough to keep you on your toes a bit, weaving dodges, parries and charged attacks depending on the enemy you're facing.

Other than combat, you're mostly going around looking for runes in the environment. Some are hidden in plain sight, while others you have to traverse the intricately designed levels in order to find. Doing one thing to reach an area, unlocking a door to then undo the first thing so you can reach where you need to go. It's more fun that I made it sound, I promise.

144476656.review:
An amazing experience from almost all points of view and a pretty much AAA-quality game at half the price. Playtime is short and the game might lag a little bit even on higher-end set-ups, but these are really the only downsides I see. Not enough to make a difference. 
Don't play this game without headphones, you're doing yourself a disservice. Also, be aware that this is a story-focused and not a combat-focused game. Fights have their time and place, but they're far from the main attraction here. Senua's Sacrifice immerses you the way most games don't, with multiple voices going around, constantly discouraging or helping you, and visual effects and distortions that literally make you question EVERYTHING you see. I can't say enough good things about the visual side of this game, it just blew me away. The whole game in general made for an experience I won't forget and you probably won't either. Best one I've played in a while; I can't wait for the sequel to come out.

This was a beautifully dark game, and I was curious about it after really enjoying God of War. Hellblade draws you  i n t o  the vision quest with the main character Senua, and the cinematics through her journey were simply to die for. The story line was mesmerizing and I do believe I shed a tear here and there for Senua by the end. 

Combat was challenging enough but it was easy to just want to watch what was happening mid battle because it all just looked SO GOOD. This was a huge similarity to GoW for me, as well as being balanced between combat and puzzle solving. These are the main reasons I dove headfirst into this game. 

I will say this was a VERY short game but I enjoyed every minute of it. I've been hearing whispers of a sequel and if this is true... I will be on it the day it drops.

Hellblade is not "a game" it is a masterpiece made with love and dedication. That's something you can feel from the very beginning through all the story till the very last second.

Hellblade is story driven and focused on delivering a magnificent narrative and cinematic experience at all times. 143719771.review:
Hellblade has an amazing narrative, compelling story, strong atmosphere, and nurtures a very deep and intimate relationship between the player and the main character. Not to mention, the game is visually stunning (rtx 3080). Overall, I enjoyed this game.

While there are many aspects of this game that I like, I can't overlook the issues that hurt my experience while playing it. My biggest issue being the bugs. Multiple bugs while completing puzzles AND during fights that forced me to restart the game and lose progress. The Beast boss fight didn't even register fully so I stood there taking hits, unable to equip my sword or dodge (or die. I had to restart the game). Very clunky fighting style and the auto combat lock-on is just straight up irritating. On top of that, the camera angles would shit itself during a fight and I would be staring at a pillar until I died. I think the combat has a lot of potential if it was properly utilized for PC and overall far less annoying.

But even with all of these issues I experienced, I think the games holds up well mostly due to the story and visuals. I would without a doubt recommend Hellblade to anyone looking for a story driven, anxiety inducing game.

Agreeing with another review that says this is mostly in the walking simulator genre, which is not a great starting point for me.

The occasional combat bits are okay but nothing to write home about.

I can't really speak to the story because twice now I got frozen by activating one of the "lore stones"; the game went into a state where I could still do the video-zoom action and retrigger the lore stone, but no other action worked, so I had to just exit. Autosaves appear to occur only between puzzles, so if you get stuck like this in the middle of a puzzle you have to start the whole puzzle again, and the puzzles are so time-consuming and uninteresting that after this freeze happening twice I give up.

(This is specifically about the puzzles that involve passing through portals that make bridges appear or disappear - maybe there are more interesting puzzles elsewhere, but I'll never know.)

In case the developers want to try to reproduce the problem to fix it, I *think* what I did to get frozen the second time is go into over-the-shoulder-view mode slightly too far from the stone to activate it, then walk forward still in that mode until it activates.

143482751.review: Incredible graphics, a well-written story and fantastic storytelling.

143462642.review:
Overall the game can be completed by any skill level. There are two spots which can prove frustrating to complete as they are timed/chase sequences. Levels are linear with guardrails. So there is no ability to intentionally jump off cliffs, stairs, or platforms unless that is required to progress. Only the beam (balancing) crossings are where Senua can fall off. In various parts of the game there is no doubling back. Combat at times can get repetitive. But at least there are two categories of attacks - standing and running which helps keeps things interesting. Block timing and knowing when to dodge is important. There are no manual game saves, just event or location triggered saves. The good news the location triggered saves can be repetitively used.

Graphics are excellent. Two obvious spots will take away from the experience. Walking on puddles produces sound, but no visual effect. And on the cave level the torch can clip into the walls, which interacts in a way to remove the torchlight. There are other spots were light interaction and shadows are off, but one has pay attention to notice them. Completing all achievements are doable. All but one are for progression. The last, the Lorestones have to be actively sought out.

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an very atmospheric action adventure game settled in the pagan world of nordic god saga. The female protagonist tries fiercely in a nightmarish journey to save the soul of her deceased darling from a nordic variant of hell and has to stand multiple fights, puzzles and illusions.

Graphics, atmosphere and above all the story are excellent staged and compensate for the somewhat repetitive and only average fights and puzzles. 

In total a neat and impressive game with a fascinating love story a la Dante's Divina Commedia, beautiful dark game world and acceptable game mechanics and challenges.

In any case it's worth to playing it and therefore I can recommend it.

143376590.review:
It started off kinda promising, until you realize it is literally just you walking up and down through a map solving pretty boring puzzles. The combat is good, when it is there. This is a walking simulator as far as I'm concerned. I find that for most of the game I am walking up and down the map to solve some lame puzzle that I don't care about. I just want to have fun while playing a game, and this is definitely not the way to go about it.

The puzzles were really creative for the first chapter but it really gets annoying to play on the same concept of the same puzzle over and over again. Also, it would be a lot more enjoyable if the character didn't move at an absolute snail's pace even when "running". I love story based games and action games, but this is just utterly boring to me.

The absence of a motion blur toggle in the settings is a letdown. Adding to the frustration, the game frequently stutters, breaking immersion and disrupting gameplay.

The atmosphere, visuals, and story are all great with well-written narrative.
It looks amazing graphic-wise but it's so slow and boring that I won't wanna take up the game anytime soon.
Thumbs down for me personally but I can see why it resonates with a lot of people.

143364698.review: I bought this game when it first came out because of the early reviews, but got distracted and forgot it until now. Here are the ups; it is a beautiful game with a unique character that I wanted to love playing. However, the puzzles are mind-numbingly simple. The character moves at two paces; half the speed of an average walking simulation or alternatively "running" at about 25% more than that. This makes the process of solving the puzzles trudge on and on and on as you have to navigate the long way around insurmountable obstacles such as thigh-high walls or sticks that are a meter and an half apart. Imagine being told a child's riddle, instantly guessing the correct answer, but having to go up 17 flights of stairs to claim a prize. If someone created a speed mod that brought it up to a normal walking speed the game would be shorter than super hero movie, but still only slightly more interactive. Save yourself the time and watch a play-through... on triple speed.

143115094.review:
[h1] Hellblade [/h1]

Hellblade: Senua´s Sacrifice es en mi opinion, uno de los mejores juegos de la historia y de los mejores indies que hay. Se nos presenta a Senua, la cual considero como el mejor personaje femenino de los videojuegos, una chica que padece de esquizofrenia en busqueda de su amado.

Las influencias de la esquizofrenia se presentan durante todo el juego, incomodo para unos increible para otros pero tiene un increible trabajo de sonido los cuales le dieron un Game Award. Ayudaran en combate y aportaran mucho a la historia, generaran distintas sensaciones al jugador y crearan una diferente experiencia de juego la cual sera increible.

El juego aparte de una increible banda sonora y graficos que estan muy bien optimizados para que cualquiera pueda jugar cuenta con una excelente dificultad, haciendo que algunas batallas no sean tan faciles (algo importante e increible del juego es una mecanica de permadeath, a pesar de que el juego no es tan largo y no es muy facil morir, tendremos la posibilidad de perder la partida dependiendo de la cantidad de veces que nuestro personaje muera en el juego, no solo causando el miedo a morir sino tambien un cambio fisico que se hara presente en el personaje en base a cuanto pierdas) y unos puzzles entretenidos y con su complejidad.

Creo que no hay mucho de que hablar de este juego, es un trabajo impresionante para tratarse de un juego indie, fue galardonado por las criticas y gano premios bien merecidos, aunque por algun motivo no parece tener mucho valor por parte de los usuarios, si bien tiene grandes criticas por esa parte no es muy tenido en cuenta cuando se hablan de juegos indies o infravalorado al momento de hablar de juegos del estilo. Sus graficos y puzzles, ademas de un increible sistema de peleas (el cual lamentablemente no es tan aprovechado en el juego) son bastantes destacables.

La historia esta muy buena la cual queda abierta para siguientes entregas, un personaje increiblemente desarrollado y que (probablemente) sea mejor en las siguientes entregas. No tengo mucho para decir de esta joya, se convirtio de mis juegos favoritos y su duracion, graficos, historias, desarrollo, entretenimiento, etc...

[quote=Hakita] 10/10 [/quote]
