143087364.review:
I've been working my way through this for years on and off, I almost don't want it to end I'm a very casual gamer but i'm thoroughly enjoying it and have already wish listed the sequel.

I'm normally super chill and flexible and the game is totally stressing me out in all the right ways, The headphones are a must. I play in like small 20-60 minute bouts so I can let me blood pressure go back to  normal.

They capitalise on lighting, sound, weird angles and brain bending visuals. Senua as a character is a great example of a strong female lead done right, shes strong  and vulnerable at the same time, you often cant tell whats in her head and whats actually happening and you can feel her resolve to keep going  so you want to root for her.

The voice casting is top notch aswell, the eerie inner voices mixed with the narrator and her guides feels like a tug of war between her despair and  every one around her pushing her forward.

All in all a great game, highly recommend if you like psychological, shock horror puzzler type stuff.

142799628.review:
90% Score - Finished at 6 Hours

Gameplay (1.5/2): Much of your time is spent walking. I usually have problems with this such that Playstation games have a tendency to just w a l k for the sake of immersion. But here walking is used to the effect of the writing, where you're often digesting and taking in the world within the complexity of Senua as a character. When it comes to combat, I enjoyed most of it. Much of the combos felt rewarding and they're nicely evened out with the narrative to make them feel fun. However, the lock-on system it uses can get more frustrating as you fight more enemies toward the end. I'm not gonna say thematically whether or not it was designed to feel that way. But it would've been nice to have more control around switching targets.

Story (2/2): Story gets a 100. You feel like you never get to know Senua as she's continuously unpacking trauma, listening to ASMR voices talk all about you or history. It's interesting, and completely contrasts something of the new Marvel-esque God of War series. While those are much more active and action oriented, this is like A24. Senua is a grounded believable character with a broken world whose chasing the lost voices of her loved ones. Constantly being reminded of 'the darkness'. Turn off your lights and just take it in one night.

Writing (1.75/2): The writing, while structurally felt rewarding and enthralling, did sometimes bug me. I don't have all that much to gripe. It's mostly just 'the darkness' being a narrative element that is said probably 200+ times? Eh whatever.

Visuals (1.75/2): The visuals felt very mundane, hopeless, tragic, and at times terrifying. It successfully delivers on conveying this broken world. Graphics being very amazing for running on Unreal Engine 4, maybe as best as they ever would be? I ran them on the highest settings. Just find a guide and turn off motion blur- it makes the experience 10x better.

Audio (2/2): Ok the score and sound effects work brilliantly. Score is sparingly used but when it happens, you feel like shit is going down. Most of the time the sound used within the story's world- posses the same hopeless theme I talk about. It especially helped wearing headphones. I talk a lot about immersion- but this game does so through a well-done narrative, good gameplay, and its hollow soundscape.

142759474.review:
Incredible Masterpiece;
An enthralling story set as a cinematic novel through our confused, terrified psychosis entrapped character Senua. The design explores scenes of intense pain and sacrifice masked by the illusion and dissonance of the atmosphere while on the secondhand portraying strong beauty and innocence imagery. The aspect of control and freedom allow you to dictate your own path in which trials you overcome first. Rigorous, intense battle scenes that promote adaptation over mashing spread throughout, from typical 'minions' to boss fights, give satisfying completion feelings accompanied. The simplistic nature of the dodge and slice, with the accompanying block, allow a more consistent and continual grasp of the lore this game presents. You're also given a power, unique to you, allowing to sense, stop and distinguish patterns from combat to puzzles. The puzzles in hellblade are not hand fed to you as in other games. These puzzle involve depth and breadth, different in its own sense. It requires you absolving the environment to adhere to the runic gears which unlock doors in very unique and clever ways.
It's keen ability and portrayal of mental health, in the way the character experiences it, establishes an empathetic link between the player and character, getting lost in her story.
The only downside I would say this game has is it's replay-ability is sort of lacking, after you finish the story and complete the side lore story, that's sort of the end. 
Aside from that I absolutely love this game and its unique, emotional significance with mental health comprised inside an northern, viking lore.
Honestly 100% a worthy purchase!

142704704.review:
There is not much to say about this game. Though I will say a little. It is a third-person shooter in essence, narrating the story of a viking warrior who ventures into a semi-hallucinated Nordic hellscape, seeking to rescue her dead fiance's soul; if I understood that part correctly. The game has been heavily marketed on its portrayal of psychosis in the protagonist - the character that we play as - but for me at least, it did not leave any striking or lasting impression. I forgot about the game pretty quickly after I finished playing the story. 

The game-play is structured around two main elements. The first is solving visual puzzles with the help of ritualistic-looking portals that lets the player see different spaces around them, opening or closing up. One has to use these portals and the 'focus' mechanic to collect clues and open up spaces to move ahead to different areas, each of which takes the character closer to the final encounter with the Goddess Hela, in whose grasp, lies the soul of the protagonist's fiance. The second main element is the combat where the player encounters enemies of a few different kinds, all of whom have patterns of armed melee attacks that you can parry, dodge and attack back when you have the chance. It is not too difficult. Also, the 'focus' mechanic allows you to occasionally slow down time so that is a superpower of sorts to quickly dispatch off minor enemies and bosses as well. 

I found the voices that haunt Senua at most times helpful, funny and even annoying at times than distressing or disturbing. The brief cut-scenes of her frustration and tiredness in dealing with these voices really did not seem to match up with what they actually do and how they function in the game. I suppose that the voices are the central element of psychosis that the developers have tried to incorporate in the game but I found it neither compelling nor immersive. It is just a background annoyance for the most part. 

The story is okay; nothing special in my opinion and even though they have done a great job with the voice-acting and some of the characters - such as Druth and Senua's father whose dialogues are central to the narrative - it did not really pull me in, at least in terms of sympathizing with Senua's struggle with psychosis. They do tell a story but the game is more concerned with showing how she overcomes the voices rather than going deeper into the dynamism and struggles associated with psychotic experience. Senua's mutterings, dialogues and expressions of angst in the cut-scenes are barely passable in terms of an effort at portraying psychotic experience and I feel, are nothing more than the usual Hollywood fare. Also, I was not impressed with her facial expressions. Apparently a lot of work was put into it but it is unnecessary for the purpose of showing distress, suffering or struggle. Like the voices that she hears, her expressions were inadvertently comical in parts. Nevertheless, it is clear that they did put some effort so I wouldn't really want to be too harsh in that regard but it is what it is. 

The music is generic. Again, possibly more thought could have put into exemplifying her struggle than rushing to resolve it into a story of her (albeit partial I must note) triumph.

Overall, the game is not bad and a reasonable experience, although worth only if you get it on sale. I would not buy this for full price. I hope the second game is an improvement and if the psychosis is ultimately only a side-narrative or a minor part of the game, I suggest they be clear about that rather than making it seem like the game is primarily about a character dealing with psychosis. It is not. I think there are horror titles that can and have done much better in that department i.e. of simulating and portraying mental illness and neuro-divergent experiences. This was cute at best. But decent game.

142677006.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a captivating exploration of the Human's psyche, an investigation in which we are faced with uncertainty and even doubts on the identity of the characters, their intentions, and the elements included in the game's environment. 

The story is presented in a confusing, unclear way, which some may find unpleasant and disconcerting, but this is exactly what makes the game so immersive. It is an authentic representation of the very disordered state of mental health of the character we embody. [Spoiler-free] Senua, the main character, suffers from psychosis, which is perceptible right from the start, voices accompany us on our adventure from the very first scene (main reason why it is recommended to wear headphones during the entire game). 

Which brings me to the soundscape, and more specifically the voices in Senua's head, as this is one of the points that impressed me most in my playthrough: voice acting. It is like an additional immersion provided by the developers, putting yourself in the shoes of someone suffering from psychosis, hearing the voices as they would hear them, whether during combat and emotional moments, or even alone.. in the middle of apocalyptic landscapes. This adds an oppressive, distressing and uncomfortable atmosphere, in perfect harmony with the story, the characters' mentality and the scenery. 

The gameplay itself is immersive, thanks to the absence of HUD, which lets the player concentrate fully on the visuals (a delight for the eyes, the graphics are amazing!), and the combat mode, which I found satisfying if slightly repetitive. Collectibles are present and bring short stories to boot - nothing to do with the main quest - but I see it as bonus lore for mythology enthusiasts. Definitely worth seeking out and taking an interest in (each of them have a nightmarish, tragic side). 

Last but not least, the puzzles. These little trials and tribulations have put a lot of people off the game.. Personally, I had no problem with them - I've encountered this type of mechanic before in other games, and they're not complicated to get to grips with - but I have to admit that some areas can be frustrating and even ambiguous (it's hard to find your bearings at times). 

In short, Hellblade is perfect for fans of immersive, dark atmosphere games full of lore, mixing creatures referencing Norse mythology, Vikings, family ties and mental health.

142618943.review:
Really didn't know what to expect when I got this game the first time. You probably know what this game is about reading the description, watching trailers and reading other reviews, so I'll share my personal thoughts on my experience.

I was expecting a very narrative experience and this nails it. The game is beautiful to look at and hyper realistic, with just a few things here and there breaking the illusion. I liked the story, the acting is really good and overall the depiction of mental illness feels genuine and respectful even if at some points, it's hard to know for someone with little to no knowledge of mental illness that what's happening is in fact that and not an element of a fantasy game.

The gameplay is serviceable, I liked the puzzles, not really difficult and some of them barely count as puzzles and more like, find this image somewhere. The combat is a little lackluster though; although I liked a lot of it, being able to string different attacks and make some really cool looking combos, it was also frustrating at time, with the camera being so close to the character that you're unaware of your surroundings, a lot of the challenges in combat weren't even the enemies sometimes, but just trying to get a sense of your surroundings and the placement of the camera.

My final thoughts are this: I feel like I'm between liking and nearly loving the game. It does strike a really good balance between letting me progress and enjoy the story which is intriguing enough that makes you want to know it, but being kind of frustrating and not really "fun" to play. What I mean by "not fun" is mainly, if I wanted to replay it for fun, the gameplay it's not really the biggest draw, the puzzles are not going to be challenging a second time, there's not much exploration outside of the main story and the combat is not good enough to make me want to play it again, but it's also kind of scarce with some chapters having no combats at all. And with the cutscenes being unskippable, thinking about playing it just for fun just isn't the most enjoyable experience.

I think if I wanted to replay it, it would have to be after a good time just if I want to go over the whole experience again, but as something I'd like to do just to have fun fighting norsemen or solving puzzles, this just isn't it.

The game is honestly a mixed bag for me. The combat is serviceable, not to deep and frustrating at times, the puzzles are just there, nothing to thoughtful or difficult. 142440509.review:
This game is a work of art, simple as that.

-Overview-
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a shining example of how to tell a story through a video game.
Accompanied by the ever-present voices in her mind, players follow Senua on a journey through her own personal hell, spawned from her twisted psyche. Hellblade makes excellent use of very subtle elements to immerse the player in the experience, and to provide just a small, personal glimpse of what the protagonist is experiencing.

🎮Hellblade can be played adequately with both keyboard/mouse and controller.🎮
-Gameplay-
Combat:
I played on the “Auto” difficulty setting, which made enemy and player health vary somewhat between fights.

Hellblade isn't really a fighting game, so combat is fairly sparse. When it does occur, I found it to be a mixed bag. Combat controls are fairly basic; you have a light attack, heavy attack, shove, block/parry, dodge and a special contextual ability. These are quite satisfying to use and have very nice animations, though the targeting system can be a burden.

Senua never loses the will to fight, even when reality has twisted into her own personal hell. 
A Screenshot of Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice
By: Spobbles

The game camera automatically locks on to whichever enemy is attacking Senua, and cannot be unlocked. Players can manually switch between targets, but it's still quite awkward sometimes, especially in confined spaces.

There are a small variety of enemies with different attacks, which is enough to keep combat interesting, though their spawning can be an issue. Enemies will spawn in set places in the combat area, even if the player is standing on that exact spot. This can lead to Senua getting whacked before the enemy has even fully spawned in, which is annoying considering she can be quite squishy.

One aspect of the game's combat I particularly liked was the hints and cues given by the voices in Senua's head. They will often yell “Behind you!” or “He's finished!”. It's a clever bit of design, and one that fits very well.

Level Design:
Levels in Hellblade are linear and often feature clever puzzle elements. A prominent one requires players to use aspects of the environment to form a symbol that matches the one present on a door. This can be debris viewed from the correct angle, a shadow cast on a wall, and more. I very much enjoyed it every time it appeared in the game.

At some points Senua backtracks through previously explored areas, which provides a stark contrast; where her original journey was twisted by her psychosis to make areas dark and foreboding, the return trip presents a warm and peaceful atmosphere.

-Story-
Hellblade's focus is entirely on Senua's psychosis. Ever-present voices follow her, judging, scolding and encouraging, and they're all hers. Senua's goal is to save the soul of her deceased lover Dillion, and she travels through battlefields, mental and literal, to reach the goddess Hela, whom she believes holds his soul.

Throughout the story, Senua suffers severe symptoms of her psychosis such as vivid hallucinations in which she witnesses everything from changes in the environment to people and events from her memories manifesting before her eyes. These provide backstory on Senua and the events of her past, offering insight into the factors influencing her severe mental illness.

Subtle efforts are made to trigger an emotional response to in-game events, for example, one section of the game features darkness that will kill Senua should she stay in it for too long. To avoid this, she carries a torch. Upon entering a dark area, one of the voices shouts “The torch is going out!”.

This instils a moment of panic in the player; fear of a danger, though maybe there never really was one. This reflects Senua's psychosis; her fear of the horrible experiences that aren't really happening.

Hellblade's story and themes are fascinating, bizarre, scary and beautiful at the same time, and make for a truly unique experience in an interesting world inspired by Celtic culture and Norse mythology. I'm left wondering if Senua's world is really a fantasy one with monsters and gods, or if it's all just her perception of it, influenced by her culture and beliefs.

Fumbling in the dark, while standing in the bright light of day; Senua's psychosis warps her reality. 
A Screenshot of Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice
By: Spobbles

Visuals:
Hellblade is a very pretty game, with beautifully crafted environments and great atmosphere. A particular aspect I was very impressed by was the sense of temperature; in one instance, Senua was exploring a pleasant grassy area in warm sunlight, only for it to suddenly shift to cold and overcast. The contrast almost made me shiver.

Senua's character model and animations are excellent. A lot of time is spent looking at her face in cutscenes, and her expressions and facial detail are outstanding, as are the detail and physics on her hair.

Senua's perception of reality can change in an instant. 
A Screenshot of Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice
By: Spobbles

Despite being very pretty, there were some aspects of the graphics I didn't like as much. Film grain and motion blur are quite heavy and do not have corresponding settings in the game options. I assume this is due to the effects being part of the artistic vision, and the way the developer intended the game to be experienced.

Regarding the U.I, I took issue with the lack of button prompts; the game does not teach the player the buttons or when to use them. I realise on-screen prompts aren't good for immersion, but I missed an optional lore item in the beginning of the game because I didn't even know that I could interact with it, let alone how to do it. Only upon coming to a ladder and nothing happening did I realise I'd have to work it out myself.

Some of it can be learned by looking at the keybinds in the options menu, but other aspects are more obscure. For example, when Senua is knocked down in combat, players can repeatedly press a button to make her get up and keep fighting before she is killed. I did not know this during my entire playthrough, and only discovered it when doing research for this review.

Performance:
Using the specs listed above, I got a stable 60fps on high settings, though something about the game's graphics often made it feel like it was running rough, as if I were only getting 40fps.

Audio:
Hellblade's audio design is outstanding. Music is subtle and fits the atmosphere perfectly, voice acting is superb and the binaural audio is incredible with headphones. The voices can whisper right in your ears, creating a chilling and unsettling experience, and adding another level of immersion.

Issues:
I encountered a couple of annoying bugs during my playthrough; the first being the game not saving after I exited on one occasion, leading to me having to do a boss fight twice. The second was mechanics triggering incorrectly in said boss fight, which was fixed by a trip to the main menu and back.

-Summary-
Hellblade is a unique and beautiful game. The storytelling and audio design are outstanding, and its exploration of the subject matter is fascinating and unsettling. The combat is rough around the edges, but puzzles are unique and enjoyable, and the game's length felt appropriate.

This game is work of art, and I would not hesitate to recommend it to anyone interested in the themes it embodies.

142434408.review:
Serious Trigger Warnings, this game is brutal;
Bitter. Horrifying. Difficult to sit through (but so much more than worth it). Heart rending and achingly beautiful. A dark tale, though not a new one. One as old as humans have been cognisant (that of the quest into the underworld to save a slain love and the redemption of truly letting go) but here told with a specific message in mind, and delivered with cold, cutting precision in an incredibly innovative way. The Dev's treatment of psychosis, childhood trauma, it's symptoms, suicide, the stages of grief, repressed memories, and the way it's all worked through a historical Norse narrative and perspective. Not for the faint of heart, or those that might struggle coping with those kinds of themes, because it is utterly unflinching in it's portrayal and it's uncomfortable to watch, even from the perspective of someone who hasn't dealt with many of the issues it looks at. 
It was designed to show the perspective of a woman from the very north of Ireland (The "Orkney Plains"), a time long ago, dealing with what we would currently call psychosis, after childhood abuse and the horrific murder of the lover (that saved her) and her entire village, done at the hands of "the Northmen", and her subsequent journey into the underworld to try and save him. She is even guided by a Virgil like figure known as Druth, an old man with terrible burns that she saved, finding him in the wilds, who died after telling her his stories about being slave to the Northmen, and how he himself had escape Hel. 
She has heard voices all her life, and they speak to you constantly. You HAVE to play with headphones. The first time I played it on PS4 without headphones and it was fantastic. This time, I played it on PC WITH headphones on and by all the dice gods, the experience could not be more different. The voices are an eerie, accurate, non stop and strange experience, making things incredibly intimate, and had me looking over my shoulder more than one. The intro is... Well. I got goosebumps. Chilling doesn't even come close. 
They even had Doctors and people who had dealt with psychosis as play testers to make it as accurate as they could. It lies to you about mechanics, gives you no tutorial, and you have to learn button presses by experimentation in the original (all in order to mimic the way people with psychosis find everything alien and unfamiliar), but the PC update has the buttons in the start menu in game for accessibility, same with being able to change the fight difficulty levels. Honestly, I've never played anything like it. It is utterly unique. 
It is absolutely art, and it's a fucking masterpiece. Everyone should play it at least once, if they can. 
Also, the OST is incredible. And I cried a couple times.
And not at the OST. 
It's also unbearably gorgeous, with great optimisation as an added bonus. The levels are spectacularly designed and really well set out, made with obvious intent and shocking amounts of care taken to increase the enjoyment of the experience. But considering how tight the rest of the game is, this isn't that surprising.
A Dev team that set out with a specific story to tell, and created something that was way more special than I think even they first realised.
(Hint without spoilers: MAKE SURE YOU GET EVERY LORE STONE, EVEN IF YOU HAVE TO USE A SPOILER-LESS GUIDE! The stories are well worth it, and the cutscene you get before the final battle if you find them all makes things make so much sense. THE HARDEST BATTLES ARE FOUGHT IN THE MIND, SENUA!)

142414663.review:
I came into this game expecting a fast-paced hack-and-slash similar to Ninja Theory's previous works with narrative themes of psychosis. This is not what Hellblade is, but I was very satisfied with it nonetheless.
The core gameplay is simplistic combat and perspective puzzles, but the framing is outstanding.

The combat is no DmC, but that's a good thing. The atmosphere it creates is claustrophobic and combat is more about avoiding being cornered and overwhelmed by a handful of opponents rather than dominating lone enemies, the voices you hear inform you in combat rather than a UI, warning you of incoming attacks, telling you when an enemy is almost dead, and when to use various abilities. It is a wonderful contrast to outside of combat, where they tend to be far less focused and far less helpful.

This is an amazing representation of mental illness and it is done so in a setting I never would have expected it to be a focal point in.

A fantastic game and story. 7.5 Hours to reach the end of the story and a further 2.6 Hours to collect the rest of the lore collectables.

If I've understood the story correctly then this is an exploration of grief through the lens of Norse mythology and also of Psychosis. It's a beautifully told story, amazing graphics, tension building and the game overall is very atmospheric.

I recommend playing this with nothing else on, i.e., if you're one to play a game with a video on in the background... don't!
I also recommend trying this game with headphones, the atmosphere of the game really shines through if you do!

A note for completionists: this game is extremely friendly towards completionists, all but one of the achievements is earned during the course of the main story. And they also provide a "Chapter Select" so you can easily revisit sections if you fancy doing a normal playthrough and completing the game afterwards.

142024448.review:
I had this game on Steam for years before finally playing it.. Now i regret not playing it sooner.
Many people call it a masterpiece, and i kinda agree.

Before anything, the game is made with 3D sound, so you should use headphones as the Devs intended!
I didn't, and i felt like i was missing out. (5.1 sound system wasn't good enough)

Alright, on to it.
it is a very slow paced, story-driven game with some easy puzzles to complete before you can continue, but in a way that works very well.
I found myself walking rather than running a lot of the time, it just feels good., But i guess you could easily shave of an hour by running, so expect 6 hours to complete it rather than my 7 if you care about such things.

It is a linear game(my preference), with some side paths if you want to find Lore stones, which i found to be worth it because Norse stories are damn awesome. (The stories are being told, you don't read yourself. very nice) - There might be a little treat in it for you if you find them all. The kind of treat you won't notice unless you know. (''true ending'' some have chosen to call it) .. It doesn't change anything, just an additional lore cutscene before the end. Don't sweat it if you don't enjoy the stories.

The combat feels super nice and smooth, but you can't change focus to other targets, which can lead to a bit of frustration in some fights, but it's not extremely horrible. (maybe you can change target and i just didn't find it.. The game doesn't tell you how to do anything)
Maybe i should have looked and the control settings, but i enjoyed only knowing how to do things i found out myself, so i didn't. 

The camera movement was a little laggy, i would guess because it was made for console, but then i got used to it (focused differently) and just enjoyed the game. (tried some different settings to fix it, was unsuccessful)

I love Norse mythology, and this game did it very well.
You will need patience, and the ability to just enjoy the world and story, or it might be too slow for you.
But if you can manage the patience, it is really really good.

So sit down with a nice warm cup of Yorkshire Gold, and let it be your favorite game on the Citadel.

I can't wait for Hellblade 2 now. (epic trailer is hype)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE!
Started a new game with headphones, and it really does add a lot with the surround sound.
Also found out you can switch target in combat by clicking the scroll wheel/mouse button 3.

The atmosphere, visuals, and story are all great.

From a strictly gameplay point of view, while the combat system is great, the extremely limited enemy types (maybe 5 throughout the whole game) make it feel repetitive, but the very few bosses you fight are actually very distinct and were really enjoyable to fight. The puzzles also feel very repetitive but the environments were unique enough to where I didn't lose total interest completing them.

The main reason I can't recommend the game is the ending: [spoiler] The game keeps building up the boss to be this big bad that you have to work to defeat in the end. I was excited because I was basing my assumption of the final boss off the previous bosses which, like I said were really cool and were the highlight of the game for me, personally. What you're actually met with at the end of the game is an endless wave of the same 5 enemies that you fight throughout the game where you're actually expected to die.
I was fine with the main character "losing" in the end, but there wasn't even an attempt at fighting the final boss directly. Just fighting an endless wave of cookie cutter enemies directly into an ending cutscene. I felt extremely robbed and it leaves the game feeling unfinished, as if the devs didn't have time to implement an actual final boss fight. [/spoiler]

141807133.review:
This is more an audio-visual experience than an outright game.

Something I love about this game is the lack of HUD or constant indicators.  I miss games that dropped you into the unknown and you had to learn and intuit your way through the game instead of a big neon sign pointing the direction where to go or which button to press.  The audio is just as fantastic as the visuals, which are unbelievably good for a game from 2017.

The combat is alright, personally I found it very easy.  Even putting combat difficulty to hard, I found you can breeze through most enemies, they are slow, telegraph their moves very blatantly and your counter + dodge will allow you to chain moves together to carve up enemies.  Ultimately it does get very repetitive, which ends up being the game's biggest weakness.  You don't really gain any new combat techniques and abilities, which you never really need to due to the simplicity of the enemies attack patterns, but as the game progresses, every fight is just an obstacle that pads out the game and doesn't add anything.  The sole exception is obtaining Gramr, which is a well timed upgrade both narrative and gameplay-wise.  You'll gain some new attacks that allow you to buzzsaw through enemies, which at this point of the game offsets the swarms of enemies the game throws your way.  You feel like you've really levelled up in the game finally, as Senua's resolve is galvanized, so are your powers.

Don't come into this game expecting a DMC game, Ninja Gaiden, God of War etc, combat is the bread and butter of those games.  This game is story driven, both thought-provoking, and visceral.  It's on sale for 5 bucks as I write this review, and 5 bucks is a steal for this game.  Get it.

141669937.review: Honestly, the entirety of the game is worth its price. The lores are fairly interesting, and having to dig deeper on Senua's fate in the game just tempts you to keep playing. The soundtrack is a beast, fiddling with atmospheric drones; nothing is melodic but they've brought more intensity to the ambiance—which is a good thing. The Graphics are superb, but you'd need enough specs to experience its intended look. I'm running it on a Ryzen 3, 2200g, with 16GB ram, and it's smooth enough when roaming casually—fps drops when facing multiple enemies. The Puzzles are too crap for me, sorry; You'd have to pay attention to precise details and roam around the map with focus to understand the clues and the positions of unlocking the gates. The whispering of voices while progressing the game is great, it adds a bit of depth to its dark atmosphere. The default game difficulty is set to auto, which I don't understand how it works. I think the only thing that is a big deal to me is that Senua doesn't have a HUD for her HP, stamina, and ability, including her foes; I feel like this game should really need a UI for it. Nonetheless, the game is great. Overall, it's worth its price. I got it on sale but I would still buy it if it wasn't.

141648676.review:
Overall, I enjoyed this game a lot. The story is very compelling, and the creators went above and beyond in creating a holistic and accurate representation of mental illness. Enough good can not be said about it on that front. If you are grading on story and story telling alone, it is a total 10/10. 
Same for the visuals - even as a somewhat "older" game (writing this in 2023) the the game still looks stunning. The environments are immersive and many are absolutely terrifying (in particular that one trial in the swamp, iyky). The mocap I think is particularly good for when the game was made, and in particularly I really enjoyed how they used actual live action actors in some instances of Senua's delusions/hallucinations. It was a very neat effect and heightened the sense that these are unreal visions or existing outside the "real" world (or that they're perhaps more real than the world Senua is existing in...however you want to see it). 
The only weakness for me was the gameplay itself. I enjoyed the puzzles quite a bit, even if there are really only four or maybe five different types of puzzles you encounter, the way they're utilized and altered to fit the different environments keeps it interesting enough for me. The major drawback imo is the combat. The mechanics of it are a bit clunky, but ultimately it is EXTREMELY repetitive. It started to feel like a chore more than a challenge about halfway through the game, especially considering the way they decided to up the challenge is just to throw more and more enemies at you at one time for longer and longer stretches. I know you need SOME combat to keep a certain level of tension up, but for me it just got so boring that it detracted from the overall experience.
That said, I would 100% still recommend this game. If you are a fan of story-driven games like TLoU and things in that vein, then you will enjoy this immensely. It's emotional, deeply terrifying, and ultimately rewarding.

- Amazing really had me hooked on the world and the lore something i'm not used to doing.

GRAPHICS:
- The game has a lot of potential definitely not well rounded YET, occasional stuttering and texture blur but hopefully someday all that will be fine tuned and it will be a smooth gaming experience.
- I played the game on my desktop which has a i7 13700k and 3080  at 1440p completely maxed with ray tracing and no DLSS visually was OK definitely needed polishing but very playable and enjoyable. I also played the game on my Gaming laptop and that has a Ryzen 7 cpu with a 3060 , at 1080p medium settings with low ray tracing no DLSS and i feel that 1080p was a much more smoother gaming experience compared to higher resolutions and would highly recommend it for those still rocking the 1080p displays its a visually beautiful game with again sooo much potential the story will really take your attention away from the graphical fidelity.

OVERALL A GAME I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND TO PLAY:)

141533814.review: For being a game that the combat is at least the 50% of it's content it's pretty bad done. The game is a scam PC port of a game made for consoles in mind from the beggining to end of development and many things just doesn't work right. In less than 2 hours of gameplay, you will have a combat where 2 enemies attack you at the same time (instead of one spawning only when you kill the first). In this scenario, what will happen is that the game automatically locks the camera onto one of the enemies and it can happens things like you're fighting against 1 of the enemies and you can't see see other enemy and this one attacks you and you receive all the damage since you couldn't have dodged or parry because you couldn't see him. AND THAT IS A BIG PROBLEM because the game tells you at the beggining that if you die too many times ALL OF YOUR PROGRESS WILL BE AUTOMATICALLY DELETED AND YOU WILL HAVE TO START ALL OVER AGAIN, and guess what, THAT IS ALSO A BIG ISSUE since you can't skip cinematics AND THIS GAME IS FULL OF THEM, AND EACH ONE OF THEM IS WAY TOO LONG. Imagine to have to suffer all of that just because the combat of the game is not technically well developed. Also the other 50% of the content of the game are "puzzles" that are so simple and easy that it's crystal clear that it's there just for FILLER, otherwise the game would be very short. The menu/ui desing it's mediocre and terrible, it's literally a low opacity black screen with white text over it with the default font. I'm pretty sure they knew this game was horrible and made just for the money and I'll tell you why; Along the game you will control Senua, our protagonist, wich suffers from schitzophrenia and it's constantly hearing voices in her head. The game puts lot of emphasis in this fact, at the point that when you open the game you see a disclaimer telling that for this game they had an expert who interviewed people who actually suffers from this psychological issue in real life. However, this is just a smoke screen to try to hide the fact that they just used something like schitzophrenia to envolve the game in a pretentious aura of deepness, but it's not, it's just another filler as the puzzles. I find pretty disrespectful that they used schitzophrenia just for selling a mediocre unfinished combat game. It's disrespectful to all the people in the world that suffers from schitzophrenia, all the suffering the had to go through converted just into a sellout piece of shit like if was nothing. As my final thought I wanna say that I don't understand why the majority of people just haven't realized about all of this. I bought the game thinking it was good because of the review state on Steam was pretty positive, however after playing it I realized how rushed for a quick buck it is and I wished that there were any review saying any of these. This is literally the first actual negative review that tells you what you will find in this game and why you should not buy it. This game is a scam, is disrespectful and no one is telling you that. I already asked for a refund and I'm truly sorry about all the console players that not only just can't get a refund but also had to pay way more for the same game, since the prices of videogames in consoles are always way more expensive that in PC, even if it's a game also released on PC, maybe that explains why this game constantly feels like it was designed for consoles in mind. Just another mediocre PC port of a mediocre videogame. Save yourself some time and money and do not buy/play this game. Have a good day.

141518636.review:
I cannot recommend this "game" if you can even call it that way.
You can't be more overrated than that. Be careful of the reviews.

[b]/!\ I'm warning you right now, this is mostly a "Cinematic" experience, you don't really play that much /!\
[/b]

- Basically you spend 70% of your adventure walking or running slowly while several NPC narrate you about the story which is not much. 

- 5% combat (mostly always the same enemies put at some key points of the story to make you waste another 5-10min) It's sad because they had something pretty polished combat wise and  it was just left at its basic state.

- 20% Puzzle, although i love puzzle games this one often bring the same kind of puzzle which can make you waste a crazy amount of time for no purpose at all (i mean, yes open a game everytime. this is how they paced their game, it has little to do with actual gameplay...)

Environment : All scripted and linear, you cannot jump down a spot or climb another because it's saves development resources and again paces the game, which create of these crazy detour/back tracking. It's utterly disgusting.

The writing : is not so crazy either, yes sure you got few nice quotes but to go crazy about it...maybe not.

Although the ending song was nice. This "game" is not that bad, just not exactly the experience i was looking for. Glad i only paid 5€ for it. This is clearly is a steal and a genius move of the devs if you paid more than 50€.

As someone else said, this shouldn't have been a tagged as game, and i would say at best it could've been named "an interactive visual novel".

141385659.review:
To judge Hellblade as an action hack-and-slash would be unfair. The camera is constrained and slow, but deliberate. The combat is methodical—perhaps simplistic, and it's a good thing 95% of the fight happen in a circular arena—but by the end of the experience I found myself quite enjoying it. 

The puzzles are not groundbreaking but have enough variety and finish quick enough that they do not wear out their welcome.

Overall, I would describe the experience as quite tight.

The real winners are the soundscape, which is incredible, the constant stream of unfolding narrative in which you're never quite sure what is or is not possible within this world. The visual effects and scenes accompanying this can be striking, no character draws too much on your nerves, and the overall direction is great. The portrayal of mythological ideas in a way that feels tangible to the human experience is great too.

The entire experience can be wrapped in 10 hours or less and feels like just enough. The presentation might be AA but makes up for it in a commitment to direction. 

Over all, highly enjoyed the experience and think it is well worth the playthrough.

141342255.review:
Like as soon as I got to the beach at the start of the game I knew I wanted to be fucked up to enhance how trippy and freaky it was gonna be. So I go to pour some booze and drink and play. Then I decided maybe getting high would be better. So I bought an edible and about 2 hours into it I am so utterly bored by the gameplay. Finding and lining up runes? So lame. I don't mind the jogging around slowly. I think it fits well with the game cinematically. But the controls are clunky and small rocks stop you. Then there's the fighting. Looks great! But it's dull and repetitive. The trickster boss was awkward and it took me a while to figure out to use my eagle vision to slow time. Which brings me to another point. There's no tutorial at all. Anybody new to games might struggle. I only got with it because I'm familiar with controls and their general button mappings to things in game was fairly standard. And further on that, there's pop up on interactable things in the world. Like opening doors or climbing ladders. I only knew to press the A Button because I was being predictive in my movements and button mashing it. Because there is no on screen prompt, you don't know what to do as well as you maybe should. Since the devs really wanted to make this such a cinematic game with filters and grain to make things look as beautiful and realistic as it can be(see the beach at game start), they don't alter the color or lighting of some of the interactable terrain you traverse. This would be beautiful if it was closer to an on rails and linear movement in the map and your character would just interact with these spots automatically. 

I'm truly interested in this game. I wanted it for so long. I wanted it to be so good. But it's not fun to play. I'll definitely look for a movie play through on YouTube though. The audio and the visuals are FANTASTIC.

141197227.review:
Senua's Sacrifice is a suitable name for the game. The developers made a concerted effort to incorporate psychosis, a very real disorder, into the game. Who says firms can't make good games on a shoestring budget? This is an excellent example of a AAA title that is not a AAA title. I'll try not to give any spoilers. Hellblade is an excellent blend of puzzle, psychology, and free-form game-play.

In terms of game-play, you can basically interact with the environment, items, and choose which path to go first. Then there are conflicts, where the environment or an area is locked, similar to DMC or Bayonetta games. Then problems had to be solved in order to progress, open hidden sectrets or routes. The majority of the riddles are required. You will remain involved in the game as voices continue to stream through your thoughts, sometimes giving hints and sometimes telling sections of the narrative.

The battles are quite good, and almost all of the bosses are unique. However, each of them has flaws that you can discover during the fighting. While fighting the bosses, you must be patient. Learn how they move.

A solid plot, as well as mystic and mystical figures based on Norse mythology.
I don't want to be rude, but if you have any form of mental problem or stress in your real life, avoid playing this game. THIS IS NOT FOR YOU.

Overall, I had a fantastic time with the game.  I've played DMC and Heavenly Sword by Ninja Theory, both of which are enjoyable, but Hellblade is fantastic. I'm still waiting for the Hellblade sequel.

And after this game, I have high hopes for Ninja Theory. The gaming time ranges between 8 and 10 hours. I went over 10 hours because I like to explore a lot.
If you haven't played it yet, this game is worth buying even if it's not on sale. This game should be added to your library now, while it is on sale for the summer.
Last words - Try not to die in the game TRY NOT TO DIE.

141195273.review: One of the best gaming experiences I have had.  Compelling, deeply moving, and terrifying at the same time.  Depicting a young woman with psychosis in 700AD is a really unique opportunity for story telling and immersion.

141183046.review:
This game is a legitimate work of art. 10/10

From the beginning the atmosphere of this game is immaculate, which is something I always look for in games. I love being able to immerse myself and focus on what I'm playing, and become a part of it. This game enables that perfectly. The visual and auditory effects implemented to portray the effects of psychosis are both impressive and chilling. 

The story telling and presentation is also amazing, I never quite felt lost and could always piece together the meanings behind events in the game, and realize what was going on. I was invested and thoroughly entertained to the end. Not to mention, this game can teach you some interesting facts about Celtic culture and mythology.

The game-play itself is fun. Puzzles aren't exactly the most difficult but they are certainly rewarding to figure out, with some fun mechanics to mess around with. Combat is a less important aspect of the game but is also surprisingly fun to engage with. Once you figure it out the fights turn into a slaughter-fest of you comboing and dancing around all of the enemies at max speed, slicing them to shreds. One boss in particular was genuinely pretty challenging to face down, which made beating them feel great.

In terms of the horror aspects of this game, its incredible. This is one of the only games I've played to have had a level that actually made me feel afraid. The aforementioned atmosphere is of course incredible and contributes to feeling uneasy and afraid at times. 

Whenever someone tries to tell me that video games can't be art, I won't ever forget to bring up this game.

141150980.review:
Got this game as a gift. I feel really bad that my partner spent this money on what turned out to be an incredibly unfitting and unsatisfying experience for me.

This game had all the ingredients for a fantastic gameplay experience: great animation, models, fluid combat mechanics, beautiful setting, amazing audiovisual design and art direction, unique concept. But then it gimps all of that by artificially slowing you to a crawl, slapping invisible geometry everywhere to ensure you can't even jump off a tiny ledge where it's not absolutely intended for you to do so, creating incredibly tedious and slow puzzles and making you crawl and wade through mud for literally HOURS just to get to a supremely anti-cathartic ending.

The ending payoff is zero. It basically doesn't tell us anything we didn't know and anticipate at the beginning of the entire affair yet at certain points almost seems to "reveal" this information to the player as if it's supposed to be a shock. For me, this was eight hours of torturous gameplay watching a girl suffer and suffer only to get an incredibly contrived message at the end. I'm left wondering why this was even a game. It could have been an artsy psychological horror movie and wasted 1.5 hours of my time instead of 8.5 hours. 

If you enjoy walking simulators and want to get a taste of psychosis along with some truly stellar acting performances, then this might be for you. If you're into games for the gameplay, definitely skip this.

141037770.review:
This is a really hard game to review! I think I'm gonna have to split it into two parts.

Firstly, gameplay. It's kinda mediocre, in all fairness. There are a [i]lot[/i] of environmental puzzles, which are mostly opening runedoors by finding the rune(s) in the environment and focusing on them. It's not hard, by any means, and more busywork thatn anything else. That said, some of them are hidden in clever places, like having to light a fire and finding the rune in the shadows cast and so on. It also forces you to explore the gorgeous and well crafted levels, so not all bad. 

There are other puzzles, some boil down to run a bit, but the illusory trickster god levels are a standout, with you manipulating the environment through looking through a circle and seeing an obstacle disappear, and then walking through the circle to find out your viewpoint has altered the level geometry enabling traversal. It's a lot better then I made it sound and really cool. Some of the later game trial levels are similar in scope, with you have to navigate a level by following the sound of water, or the rumble of your pad. I don't want to spoil them, but some of them are amazing and show some really good and unique gameplay ideas.

The combat is just kinda there. The parrying feels good, and you can parry a lot of enemy moves, but the overall it's not anything great. Apparently you can string a bunch of attacks together and combo off of a lot of things, but it's not really very rewarding in any way, or even necessary when you can parry -> strong attack most enemies to death. The enemies themselves look amazing and are well-crafted utter norse horrors, but there's not much variation, and you'll fight the same enemies a lot. The graphics and sound are top-notch even now. Senua looks great, the mo-cap is excellent, and the levels and environments are incredible. 

The plot, lore, voicework and journey are also nothing short of excellent, with Senua having very real and well-portrayed personal development over the course of the game. Game narrative usually leaves me cold, but when Senua screams in frustration and anger at the gods that have failed her, or fondly remembers the beautiful day she met her boyfriend, you absolutely feel it deep in your heart. I'm kinda running out of superlatives here, but it's amazing all the way through.

That's the game really, kinda medicore with some excellent standout gameplay parts which put a lot of more modern games to shame.

So why is it so great? Well Senua suffers from psychosis, and is reportedly an excellent (and respectful) portrayal. Headphones are kinda a must for this game, because all through the game, you will have different voices telling you things. Sometimes helpful, warning you of enemies behind or telling you when you're near the solution to a puzzle. Most of them time though, they laugh at your hopeless efforts in your hopeless quest, telling you you're a failure and that your quest is stupid and unachievable. Sometimes they blame you for the death of your boyfriend, family and tribe, sometimes they mock Senua's apparent abusive upbringing. Sometimes enemies do it too. I've never really experienced anything like it, and it is such a daring, determined and successful attempt at something most game devs would not have the balls to attempt that I'm in awe, frankly. It really works so well in the context of the game that it's nothing short of brilliant. There are other bits too, such as the face of Senua's mother hidden all around the game or a lot of the trials that are just amazing.

So yeah, in gameplay terms, Hellblade is kinda weak with some standout parts. As an overall package or experience or whatever, it's simply one of the best games ever made. And I don't think I can really praise it more than that. Play it.

140921400.review: Really not sure what to do with this. This game is pretty meticulously well crafted and I think it accomplishes what it sets out to do, to a point. There are a couple of problems though. First, I think it's in that category of media that makes a big deal of being "about mental illness" but really doesn't have anything to say about it (see also Dear Evan Hansen, Joker, etc). Second, making a game with the intent to replicate the experience of mental illness means that if you do it right, it's gonna be kinda unpleasant to play... which it often is. I like the atmosphere, and the combat and puzzles are fine, but if you're not down for an overwhelmingly dreary and directionless experience I'd go elsewhere.

140897854.review:
[h1] A Journey Through the Mind [/h1]
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice, developed by Ninja Theory and released in 2017, is a ground-breaking action-adventure game that delves into the psychological and emotional experiences of its protagonist, Senua. Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice tells the story of Senua, a Pict warrior who embarks on a harrowing journey to the Norse underworld, Helheim, to save the soul of her deceased lover, Dillion.

[h2] Pros and cons [/h2]
[table]
[tr]
[th] 🟩 Positives [/th]
[th] 🟥 Negatives [/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]
- Innovative storytelling and game design approach, focusing on narrative and emotional depth.

- Meticulously crafted environments and character design with a unique art style that combines realism and surrealism.

- Visceral and intense combat system that rewards strategy and timing.

- Nuanced and sensitive portrayal of mental illness, committed to accuracy and authenticity.

- Haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that complements the game's visual design.

- Significant cultural and social impact, raising awareness and fostering empathy for those with psychosis.
	[/td]
	[td]
- Relatively short playtime, with a main story that can be completed in 8-10 hours.

- Limited replayability, with puzzles and lore-stones that may lose their impact on subsequent playthroughs.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]
	
[h2] Narrative and Characterisation [/h2]
Hellblade tells a deeply personal and emotional story, focusing on themes of mental illness, grief, and self-discovery. The game's narrative is expertly woven into its mechanics and design, creating a cohesive and engaging experience. The storytelling in Hellblade is unconventional, with much of the game's narrative conveyed through environmental storytelling, lore stones, and the voices in Senua's head. 	

[h3] Exploration of Mental Illness [/h3]
Senua is a complex and well-realised character, with her struggles with psychosis serving as the driving force behind the game's narrative. Senua's journey is not only a physical one but also a psychological one as she grapples with the voices in her head and the hallucinations that plague her. The game's portrayal of psychosis is both sensitive and accurate, with the developers consulting with mental health professionals and individuals with lived experience to ensure authenticity. This commitment to representation allows players to gain a deeper understanding of the challenges those living with mental illness face, fostering empathy and raising awareness.

[h3] Symbolism and Metaphor [/h3]
Hellblade story is rich with symbolism and metaphor. Many aspects of the game's narrative serve as allegories for Senua's internal struggles. The game's environments, enemies, and puzzles reflect Senua's psychological state, with each challenge she faces representing a facet of her mental illness.

[h3] Personal Growth and Self-Discovery [/h3]
At its core, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a story of personal growth and self-discovery. Throughout the game, Senua confronts her fears, insecurities, and traumas, ultimately learning to accept and embrace her mental illness as a part of her identity. This focus on personal growth and self-discovery resonates with players, highlighting the universal themes of resilience, perseverance, and the power of the human spirit.

[h2] Mechanics and Gameplay [/h2]
The player controls Senua as she navigates through a dark and foreboding world inspired by Norse mythology and Celtic culture. The game's mechanics primarily focus on exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat, with each element contributing to the overall experience.

[h3] Exploration [/h3]
The exploration aspect of Hellblade is integral to the game's narrative and atmosphere. The game's environments are meticulously crafted, with keen attention to detail that immerses the player in Senua's world. The level design encourages exploration, with hidden lore stones providing additional context and backstory for those willing to venture off the beaten path. This design choice rewards players for their curiosity and enhances the game's replayability.

[h3] Puzzle-solving [/h3]
The player must solve various environmental puzzles to progress through the game. These puzzles often involve pattern recognition and perspective manipulation, requiring players to think critically and approach problems from multiple angles. The puzzles are well-integrated into the game's narrative, with each challenge serving as a metaphor for Senua's internal struggles.

[h3] Combat [/h3]
Combat in Hellblade is a visceral and intense experience focusing on timing, positioning, and strategy. The game's combat system is relatively simple, with light and heavy attacks, blocks, and dodges. However, it is executed with precision and fluidity. The game's difficulty scales appropriately, with enemy variety and complex attack patterns increasing as the player progresses. This ensures that combat remains engaging and challenging throughout the game.

[h2] Design and Aesthetics [/h2]
Hellblade is a visually stunning game with a unique art style that combines realistic character models and environments with surreal and otherworldly elements. The game's lighting and particle effects are particularly noteworthy, creating an atmosphere of dread and unease that permeates the entire experience.

[h3] Visual Design [/h3]
The game's environments are richly detailed and varied, with each location offering a distinct visual identity. The character design is equally impressive, with Senua's appearance reflecting her emotional state and her journey's toll on her body and mind.

[h3] Sound Design [/h3]
The sound design in Hellblade is exceptional, with a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that complements the game's visual design. The game's use of binaural audio is particularly noteworthy, as it simulates the experience of hearing voices in one's head, an essential aspect of Senua's psychosis. This innovative approach to sound design enhances the game's immersion and is a powerful narrative device.

[h2] Contextualisation and Cultural Impact [/h2]
Hellblade occupies a unique position within the gaming industry as a game that prioritises narrative and emotional depth over traditional gameplay elements. The game's exploration of mental illness and its innovative approach to storytelling has garnered widespread acclaim and sparked meaningful conversations about representation and inclusivity in gaming.

The game's portrayal of mental illness has had a significant cultural and social impact, raised awareness and fostered empathy for those with psychosis. Hellblade has also contributed to the ongoing conversation about representation and inclusivity in gaming, highlighting the importance of diverse perspectives and experiences.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
In conclusion, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is remarkable in game design, storytelling, and representation. Its innovative approach to mechanics, design, and narrative, combined with its commitment to authenticity and inclusivity, make it a must-play experience for those seeking a unique and thought-provoking gaming experience.

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a beautiful, intense and really unique game, but most of all is a life lesson, a deep and dark journey inside a psychotic mind. And oh my gods it is terrifying…

Visually the game is pretty great and the facial animations of your character are from the best I ever seen, and if you take into account that this is a 2017 you get even more speechless with the overall graphics, yes the game has received in 2021 an upgrade to “enriched visuals”, but even so the good stuff was already there. 
But even if the graphics were not good, what most impressed me was without a doubt the story. Senua is a psychotic mind and the way the game plays makes you feel her anguish, her sorrow, her pain. You will follow her path, her quest, her haunting vision (as the devs say) and you will discover her past, her story and even the story of the old goods along the way. 

I did pointed out before that the game was terrifying, but not because the game is scary or so, but because it is an overwhelming feeling to experience all these voices, all that noise, all that inner fight, it is an overwhelming experience just to imagine to live like that, that anguish, that darkness. For me it was a life lesson, to understand and feel how a psychotic mind can feel. 

Without a doubt a game that I fully recommend! Can wait to see what they will gonna do with next entrance of the series the already announced Senua's Saga: Hellblade II.

140467037.review:
Has to be one of the best games I've played in recent times.
I would like to praise around 90% of the game's aspects, but to keep it simple:

- Combat: This game has the best combat I've ever experienced in a third person game. At first, I expected the combat to be kinda wonky, but it turned out to be the opposite. Everything feels responsive, there's good feedback, and everything feels very well connected. Every move is well crafted enough to feel natural, and also, the enemies make you use all of the mechanics taught throughout the game, which makes combat at the end very dynamic

- Graphics: I don't know know how close this games gets to photorealism but holy shit, every time I walked to a new scene I had to take a photo because the environments look astonishingly good. The animations also help a ton, the motion tracking really paid off. Though I don't know if it's just me, but sometimes I felt that some of Senua's animations had a lower framerate (at this point I'm being very nitpicky)

- Voices: Don't want to spoil anything, but being the main selling point of the game, it does a great job at conveying this unusual way of narration in every way. The voices really feel like part of the player, and not just some mp3's put on top of each other.

- Mechanics: Every single mechanic is introduced and taught very well without the need of some text explaining what you have to do. Everything is conveyed in a very undersandable way, which makes for a very accesible experience.

Overall, great fucking game, honestly. Even if you're not a fan of the genre, like me, I'm sure you will enjoy it.

I knew nothing of this game when I got it. BAFTA winner? No idea. Just thought it looked amazing, so got it on sale. I'm 1 hour into it and it's blowing my mind how good it is. I'm running it on the steamdeck with headphones on and you keep getting these schizophrenic voices arguing and whispering in your ear. Are the myths real? Is Senua insane? This game makes a great job exploring that question. The graphics are superb, there are no loading screens and its all seamless. 
If I had to find fault in it, it would be the very basic and unoriginal gameplay: the combat is just parry and slash, the puzzles are walk simulator, align the perspective so it forms something, etc. Nothing revolutionary, but its not terribly dull either because of the great sound design, story, art and mythology.

So I'd say, you like walking simulators with a great story and an unbelievable sound design? This is your game.
If what you're looking for is a stellar action game with innovative gameplay... move along.

140421892.review:
Overview: Hellblade Senua's Sacrifice is an experience. A mentally unstable individual is living in a world that is hard to know what is real and what is created. You play as Senua, on a task to deliver her lover's head to its final resting place. You find out through flashbacks what happened to cause Senua to be where she is now and live out her struggles against her own mind as she valiantly fights to reach the game's end. 

Gameplay: So there is combat in this game but it is pretty minimalistic. There are only a few enemy types, and a few boss fights but most of the combat is you dodging and then learning the enemies timing to land some blows. I think it's best to describe Senua as mainly a walking simulator a la Death Stranding, which is more of an experiential type game, with the odd combat to break up the walking, and a few puzzles scattered to solve to progress. Unlike Death Stranding, I found this more immersive and the story compels you to find out what will happen to Senua and just what is real or not? The combat itself I found mostly lackluster. In particular there are battles that just go on too long, especially the shielded enemy, where you're just waiting for your openings and otherwise just bored. I give the gameplay itself a 3/5.
Story: The story is intriguing and mysterious. You don't know what is real and what is fake. The studio designed this game through rigorous research to give an approximation of what it is like to live with psychosis and mental issues such a hearing voices, irrational fear, having delusional visions. It certainly was cinematic and drew you in, making you think about what it would be like for people to live with these conditions, especially in a time period such as when this takes place. 4/5.
Music: The music was appropriate and again the sound effects overall were meant to put you in the state of a person undergoing several mental trauma/delusions. While the music was mostly not memorable, it fit the experience perfectly and I have to give this a 5/5.
Graphics: The graphics were well done, much of the in-game cinematics were acted and I have to say, kudos to the actress and supporting cast. Truly great performances that draw you in. A blend of live-action overlaid with certain in-game set pieces and areas really added to the effect of not knowing what is real and what is made up. The world itself is suitably horrific in areas and beautiful in others, making it a pleasure to view. I give this a 5/5.
Fun factor: I call this an experiential type of game. It's not meant to be fun, per se, but to draw you in and leave you with a unique experience. I definitely don't feel an urge to replay and the combat dragged for me, but I did want to finish the game and find out what Senua's ending would be. 4/5.
Overall: If you want an unique game, an experience that shows you what life could be like for those living with mental illness, or a game that brings to life Norse myths in a horrific but amazing way, I'd highly recommend this. If you're looking for a fun combat game then I'd look elsewhere. This game really reminds me a bit of the 13th Warrior, where in that movie they took a fantastical tale and made it real by presenting the myths in a realistic way, but having you see how they could have grown in telling. But instead for Senua, the myths and legends take shape in her own mind, becoming more fantastical and terrifying driven by her own mental state. I would highly recommend everyone play this once to see the unique perspective. 4/5 overall.

140358694.review:
Spoilers.

"It isn't bravery that drives her, bravery only means something to those afraid of death. Senuas fear runs far far deeper" 

I was hooked into this immediately, for someone like myself it was easy for me to relate to Senua on so many levels, I saw myself in her struggle, in her isolation and fear, her intense emotions, her deep unending drive to keep someone, to bring them back even when they are long gone.

And the deep loneliness that comes from just not being normal and the knowledge that you won't just have a normal life.

It's a painful game to play. I was terrified in some parts of it, to the point I had to make my sister come and sit with me to get through it. I cried at the end and i feel an overwhelming sadness that i couldn't fix it, that i couldn't bring him back for her.

This game is beautiful through and through. It teaches you about mental illness in a respectful and sympathetic way while empowering you to keep fighting it and any voice telling you can't do something or that you're not good enough. When Senua finally lets go of Dillion at the end it's a reminder that we must all let go of someone at some point in our lives no matter how painful it is. You can't carry that burden or fight endlessly for ever. it's a bitter sweet ending but ultimately hopeful. 

And that's all any of us can hope for.

140305112.review:
[h1]Recommended for cultural importance, not for gameplay[/h1]

Like many others, I'm terribly conflicted about this game. I originally wasn't going to recommend it, but it seems like it's very important to a lot of people. It's telling a story that needs to be told, and it's changing people's lives. I can't not recommend a game that does that.

However, the gameplay is very, very boring and frustrating. At the time of writing this review, I only have a few hours in the game, and I don't know if I'll ever finish it. If I don't play it, I'd like to find a good gameplay video of it so I can see the story and learn what it has to teach.

I bought the game knowing nothing about it or its impact, just that the main character looked cool and it was story-heavy. After playing the actual game, I was terribly disappointed and conflicted. Now, after reading the reviews from people who were deeply moved by the game, I want to keep trying even though I am just frustrated and miserable the whole time. Maybe that's the point? I dunno. I struggle with my own mental health and I definitely feel frustrated and miserable a lot of the time, so it could be. We'll see if I finish it.

It does do some things right. I can't speak from experience regarding psychosis -- and bear in mind I've only played about 4 hours, up to the second boss. But I can tell you what I think so far.

[b][u]Character Design[/u][/b]

Senua feels like a real human being. She moves realistically. She's small-framed, but tenacious, and her arms are skinny, but muscular from use. She experiences rage, fear, frustration, despair. She's vulnerable. She has no superpowers. She's just a woman who's been through some shit. The writers struck an excellent balance between strength and vulnerability.

Absolutely no focus is on Senua's looks, gender, or sexuality. She's a scrawny, tough lil thing and her face is covered in blue paint, blood, and dirt. I haven't seen a single slow-motion pan up the butt and boobs. More and more stories are being told about women these days without it being all about the male gaze, and I love every single dev who makes that choice.

[b][u]History/Mythology[/u][/b]

The depiction of Norse mythology (an interest of mine) is one of the best I've seen in video games or movies. I like that there are tidbits of the Eddas interwoven with Senua's story. I also appreciate that they acknowledge how bat shit insane Norse mythology is. Lookin' at you, Auðumbla.

[b][u]Combat[/u][/b]

The combat looks and feels more realistic than most games. Senua isn't acrobatic. She's not leaping five feet and somersaulting gracefully. Her body has weight. When she's hit with a strong attack, she isn't just staggered, she crashes to the ground. Her sword has weight and momentum; when she misses a big swing, the sword keeps moving and turns her body. And while some of her combat moves are a little flashy and dramatic, I've also seen some legit swordplay movements. (I took one longsword class and have watched lots of people fight with longswords in heavy armor. I'm sub-amateur level but Senua's movements ring true with what I've seen.) When Senua is injured, she moves more sluggishly, and I feel it while playing. She can't swing as fast or dodge-jump as far. It's immersive.

They also did a great job replicating the dance-like aspect of swordfighting. The back and forth, taking turns "leading." The beginning, when you're studying your opponent's movements, sizing them up and devising a strategy.

Unfortunately, the charm wears off before long, as combat gets repetitive. The same enemies, the same strategies. It goes from "ooh" to "ehh" pretty quickly.

[b][u]Graphics[/u][/b]

The game is visually stunning. The graphics quality and animation are outstanding. The setting at least in the first area is bleak and not terribly interesting. It's a lot of greyish brown tree trunks and sticks and rocks. But they are very exquisitely rendered sticks and rocks.

[b][u]Audio[/u][/b]

Clever use of sound as a game mechanic and storytelling device, though people who are Deaf or hard of hearing will not benefit from that as much. I have difficulties with auditory processing and it's hard to pick out any meaning from a cluster of voices. 

Subtitles are unfortunately unreliable; the subtitles don't exactly match the dialogue, and they're oddly timed -- like an entire paragraph of subtitles will appear on the screen at once, even though the spoken words are spread across two minutes of scenes with large stretches of silence in the middle. Because there are so many voices, many of them are not captured in the subtitles, which is understandable, but it further weakens the subtitles' effectiveness. 

[b][u]Puzzles?[/u][/b]

Uuuuugh. I'm glad I'm not the only person who hesitates to call them "puzzles." There's no real challenge to figuring them out. So far, all of the puzzles have been "Walk around the area until you're in the right place and can see the right thing." Or else it's "Follow the path, and there is only one path because every other path is blocked by trees, fences, or fire." It's just walking around. I'm not using my brain or problem-solving skills, so it's not rewarding at all when I "solve" them. But I am exercising every last ounce of my patience, because Senua's fastest movement speed is a casual jog. Not even a brisk jog. 

And there is no consistency regarding what she can and can't climb over, duck under, or jump down from. She can step over a log, but not a rock. She can climb over this three-foot wall, but not that three-foot fence. She can jump down from this six-foot cliff, but not that four-foot drop, because... there are some fist-sized rocks along the edge? I guess?

The tight, low over-the-shoulder view also makes it difficult to get a good sense of the entire area. Fences, buildings, trees etc all look more or less the same, and there's not nearly enough to differentiate between this path or that path. My directional sense is terrible, but the sameness of the environment has made me walk in so many circles. 

[b][u]Permadeath[/u][/b]

You can only die/fail a limited number of times before it's game over, man. I guess to build tension? But when I'm dying/failing because of bad game design, I get real mad at my limited lives being taken from me. I don't like roguelikes/roguelites. Permadeath doesn't make a game more thrilling, it makes it feel more pointless and frustrating. I'm 4-5 hours in and I'm already halfway to permadeath. I don't want to continue when I'm pretty sure I'm going to permadie before I can finish the game. Which means I'd have to start from scratch, and I do NOT want to go through all of that jogging again.

There are too many frustrating ways to die in this game due to factors outside of my control, like getting stuck on something in combat, or poor game/level design, or the developers just not telling you important things that you need to know to progress. Their approach is to throw you into the lake and you'll learn to swim eventually. I don't need to be spoon fed, and I like figuring things out in games, but I do need to know the basic mechanics and concepts of the game.

140169128.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice, es una montaña rusa emocional que me dejó sin palabras. Este juego no es solo un juego, es una experiencia que te agarra desde lo más profundo y no te suelta fácilmente.

La música, primero que todo, es como un abrazo a tus emociones. La manera en que cada nota se mezcla con la narrativa y el ambiente es simplemente alucinante. Después de jugar, es como si las melodías se quedaran contigo, reviviendo esos momentos intensos.

Los diálogos y la actuación de Melina Juergens como Senua son la clave de este viaje. Puedes sentir la lucha interna de Senua en cada palabra y gesto. No es solo un juego, es una exploración de la mente humana, y te sumerges en esa dualidad entre el miedo y la valentía. Es tan crudo y real que te hace cuestionar tu propia percepción de la realidad.

Visualmente, es una obra de arte. Cada rincón, desde los paisajes nórdicos hasta los oscuros reinos mentales, está lleno de detalles que te absorben por completo. No puedes evitar detenerte a mirar y apreciar lo que los desarrolladores lograron crear.

Y hablando del tema, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice toca aspectos serios como la salud mental y el trauma de una manera que pocos juegos se atreven. Es como un recordatorio de que los videojuegos pueden ser más que solo entretenimiento; pueden ser poderosas herramientas para contar historias impactantes y significativas.

En resumen, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice es una experiencia que se queda contigo. No es solo un juego que juegas y olvidas, es una travesía que te marca. Si buscas algo que te haga sentir y reflexionar sobre la vida y la mente humana, este juego es una joya que no deberías pasar por alto.
