140097589.review:
[h1][b]Une claque[/b][/h1] 

[i]Senua m’a scotché, ni plus ni moins. En quelques secondes, je me suis senti plonger dans un univers fort, et dérangeant. Je pense que tout a été dit dessus, le jeu mérite son succès, mais j’aimerais relever les deux points qui m’ont particulièrement plu.[/i]

[list]

[*][b]Le visuel [/b]

Alors bien sûr, on a des environnements superbes, la végétation, la mer, la lumière, tout ça claque, mais il y a aussi beaucoup d’endroits où c’est sale. Des lieux où visuellement, ça grouille, ça suinte, ça pullule, bref, où c’est dégueulasse.
Idem pour le personnage de Senua, son visage n’est pas dans les canons de beauté, elle grimace, elle grogne, elle s’enlaidit au rythme des coups qu’elle prend dans la gueule. Et je trouve que c’est justement cette laideur qui l’humanise. Il suffit de la comparer une seconde avec un perso de Nier Automata (pris tout à fait au hasard), pour constater que l’une est un personnage et l’autre une poupée gonflable.

[*][b]Le sonore [/b]

Pour moi le second et le plus gros point fort du jeu. L’ambiance sonore est tout simplement excellente, c’est elle qui permet l’immersion. Ça pourrait être simplement décontenançant et original si ça n’était qu’une ambiance schizophrénique, mais en avoir fait un élément de gameplay à part entière, je trouve ça génial. Parce que oui, votre schizophrénie va vous encourager et vous enfoncer, mais elle va surtout verbaliser les attaques que vous ne pourrez pas toujours voir et vous permettre d’y réagir. C’est une première pour moi de voir un élément original palier à ce gros défaut des jeux d’action à la troisième personne qu’est la caméra.

[*][b]Défauts ?[/b]

Seul bémol à mes yeux, j’ai trouvé que la narration n’était pas suffisamment intégrée au jeu, on a un peu l’impression d’écouter des podcasts au fur et à mesure de notre progression. Certains lui ont reproché une durée de vie trop courte. Pour moi, une expérience forte comme ça n’a pas besoin d’être plus longue, c’est aussi comme ça qu’on évite les jeux qui sortent sans être terminés.

[/list]

[i][b]Je le répète, Senua mérite à mes yeux le succès qu’il a eu. Le soin apporté au doublage, au jeu d’acteur et au game design est tout bonnement bluffant, c’est du très, très bon travail, et ça fait du bien.[b][/i]

140032954.review:
First off, I did like the HUD-less gameplay. It's pretty clever that the game makes you rely on audio and visual cues to figure out puzzles or clue into an enemy's health level. I also liked the historical and mythological setting. The optional audio logs recounting Norse myths were pretty much the only times I came close to enjoying myself.

That being said, this game was far too bleak for my taste. I play dark games sometimes, but the tone of this game is utterly and relentlessly miserable. Whenever the protagonist isn't screaming in mental agony, you have to hear the voices in her head whispering endlessly. It gets incredibly annoying after a while, like most ASMR does for me.

I bought this game because it was on sale for $7.50 instead of $30, and I only finished it as an endurance test.

If you love cinema.  If you are the type of person who watches films from The Criterion Collection.  If you love avant-garde stuff.  This game is for you.  It will make you FEEL.  You will be anxious, you will get frustrated with many of the puzzles (do yourself a favor and watch gameplay videos on YouTube to help you out) and you will definitely be impacted by this game.  Graphics and audio are world-class.  You will be immersed in the world of a schizophrenic main character, and you will go on an unforgettable journey.  Do not miss this if you are the adventurous type who wants to experience all that life has to offer.  As far as games go, this is not one to miss.

I will update my review once I finish this game, which I intend to do very soon.  Why I waited so long to play this game to the end, I cannot say.  Kind of like how long it took me to watch Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai.  I see no difference in quality with this game and that film.  I would go so far as to say, if Kurosawa were alive today, he would probably play this game and leave an amazing comment on Steam about his experience.

139944883.review:
Played and beat completely on steam deck. Just put the preset on high if you want best visuals with a frame rate that hangs from 40 to 60, or put it on medium for a frame rate that hangs around 55 to 60. Set FSR to ultra quality. Every other FSR  setting looks way too fuzzy. 

Pros
-Outstanding visuals
-Great art direction
-Flawless sound design
-Great story
-Responsive controls

Cons
-repetitive gameplay
-no ability progression whatsoever
-Slow pacing
-No incentive to do anything other than beeline for the finish

objectively, this is a good game. Everything about the game shows quality, polish, and meticulous care. Playing this with a surroundsound system or really good headphones will push the immersion even further. The game is unique enough that I feel like it will present a novel experience for anyone who hasn’t played it, so based on that fact alone, I have to recommend it.

However, personally, the game is not for me. The story is a bleak, dark, and depressing. The main character is suffering from the second you start the game up until the very end. The visual puzzles, the combat, and the well crafted environments drew me in enough so that I could see it through to the end, but if you are someone who is prone to depression or feelings of dread, do not play this game. 
some things I would like to see improved in the sequel would be some sort of character progression. You start off the game with the same abilities until the end. enemy variety is also nonexistent. You don’t notice it for long because the game is only about seven hours long so it’s not a huge issue, but there is no incentive to explore or fight as there is no reward. 
Play it for the story, the visuals, and the unique experience, as that is all there is to find here.

139853579.review:
First, this game is NOT meant to be enjoyable, or fun, or entertaining, it's an "experience" type, that tells or conveys and idea or sense of something. In this case, Psychosis and such mental disorders. Purely on it's own, the story, idea, etc... would be decent, not great, but overall ok and should work. And this type of thing is arguably best conveyed through interactive medium like a video game.
The problem... is the gameplay. It's bad... really bad at times. Combat is a fustercluck, with enemies able to spawn in at random seeming right next to you, and instantly start and attack while you're in the middle of an animation or other state already, not really able to respond. Sometimes there's input queueing that says you cna't dodge or block cause you're doing another attack, othertimes there is none... sometimes controls are just ignored. Sometimes they are even supposed to be when you get into the tired state. Many enemies are poorly designed to actually fight, shield holding ones especially. The camera and movement... and I say this coming from a long history of gaming in the third person, combat, exploration, platforming, etc... but this might take the cake for the worst camera and movement I've had to date. In combat it is just so ungodly awful that as soon as there's more than one enemy you probably aren't having any fun, and when there's three or more, or they spawn on different sides, you're just getting pissed dealing with it.
Then there's bugs, plenty of bugs, performance issues, it plays really badly even on a fairly high end system at low resolutions. And most of the gameplay is other than combat puzzles, but not really that good, a few are ok but most just feel like annoying time waster types where you explore around till you spot some specific thing they want you to find, not the other things you found that looked like it, no... gotta be this one specific thing, from one specific angle. So overall, the gameplay is just... too bad, it keeps me from focusing enough on the story or experience, and often takes away from this, overall I was thinking three hours in (well at least it's a short game" since it looked like I was almost done, it is short, thankfully.
Sadly I just can't recommend this, the idea was arguably good, but the execution was just... not...

139695213.review:
[h1]A priceless experience[/h1]

I caught glimpse of Hellblade from the first teasers nine years ago. The impression I was left with was that the game would be quite action-oriented with a hint of horror and heavily influenced by Norse themes (runes on swords etc). I must admit I put it under the radar as there have been quite a few releases which draw inspiration from Norse mythology and end up being lacklustre. How wrong my first impressions were! How lucky I was that I was not hyped! I got into the game unsuspecting of what I would witness.

There are many descriptions and tags which try to define Hellblade: “horror-orientated, action game”, “hack’n’slash”, “narrative”. They are quite wrong while being right; Hellblade is a study of its creators on a human psychosis using video games as a medium of visualisation and expression, and it’s a thorough experience for whoever chooses to play it. It transcends the petty genre tags and provides its audience with an unparalleled immersive experience.

Our heroine is Senua, a Celtic female warrior, her design influenced by the medieval Pict tribes in Scotland during the Roman occupation of Great Britain. She arrives in Helheim, the Norse land of the dead, to claim redemption for her lost lover. One might suggest that her tale is the Celtic take on the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice with the roles reversed. Right from the start, we understand that this is far from the case. Senua is special, in the sense that you arrive as a silent observer in her head. You are welcomed by a voice, the one of many – who would resemble the ancient Greek Erinyes – as she urges you to follow Senua in her quest. Senua’s aim is simple: she will reach and confront Hela, the goddess of Death, and claim Dillion – her lover – back to the world of the living.

I honestly do not want to spoil the story of Senua. It relies on a very simple premise, but ultimately it is how it unfolds into an intricate webby pattern that’s important. Small hints in the narrative comprise a very detailed character backstory and development, one you rarely see in the medium. The daemons Senua has to face balance between reality and fantasy. The game uses Senua as a vessel to provide just a glimpse of the hallucinations and delusions which a psychotic person may experience. Yes, Senua is psychotic as her grasp of reality is quite thin, that much is clear from the start. After all, how would it be possible to look us into the eyes, as if we were actually there? We are peering through the looking-glass, we’re just non-existent observers.

The players will find themselves deeply immersed in the game’s story. There are two major factors responsible for this: the approach in direction and and Ninja Theory’s handling of state-of-the-art technologies to tell their story and get their message across. As far as direction goes, there are quite a few things one can say. From the frame compositions, the sequences in unveiling new locations or enemies, to the actual behaviour of Senua herself everything is there for a reason. The first 5-6 hours of Hellblade provide a constant escalation of strong emotions as we learn new ways with which Senua observes her environs. Surroundings full of Norse paganist horror and imposing landscapes. Or is it just our twisted perception?

Otherworldly ambient sounds can be heard as we walk past derelict houses, the sounds of still life – or widespread death. We can listen to Viking horns in the mist, as we walk past longships, hanging chains and bones rattling against the wind. We may have the sudden urge to listen to the mystifying music of Wardruna and Forndom, but it will just as suddenly dissolve as we will listen to the ambient sounds which can only mean that new horrors need to be faced. One of the eeriest and horrifying video game experiences I’ve ever had was the start of Act 2 in the original Max Payne (the dream level). It was not because of what was there or not, but of what the visual – and more importantly – the sound effects (and… younger age) forced my mind make all those unconscious connections. While Senua is not disturbing for my taste – trust me there may be people who may find it as such – it managed to match that experience.

All these artistic details are hard to miss from the start (there a few more which are much more subtle). Although the direction takes a strong stance on how to best demonstrate the major conflict happening in Senua’s world, it leaves much to the player for assembly and, thus, interpretation, besides the main theme. How did Senua end up in her state is unveiled gradually, intricately, artistically, exceptionally. An average person (please note; not “normal”) may find Melina Juergens’ (Senua’s alter real-life ego) reactions and acting grossly exaggerated. Arguably, after finishing the game I understood and sympathised in a profound way why Senua reacts the way she does. From start to finish the attention to detail is outstanding.

Another field in which Hellblade shines is in how it uses the medium’s technologies. This visual novel/study pushes you on edge right from the start. You have to play this game with your headphones on no matter what. The audio is unmatched to my recent memory, and how could it not be? Ninja Theory used a binaural recording room, resulting in everything you listen to be relative in 3D space. “Oh, I heard a maniacal laugh from my right… wait, it moved towards the back of my head…now, back to the right… another voice on the left at the same time… what is happening to me?” You have suddenly become Senua herself. Special reference should be made to the voice actors who gave an outstanding performance. There were a few very unsuspecting moments where no action took place and the voices effects (eg. hisses) made my neck skin crawl out of nowhere.

In order to enforce the impact of the story, engage the players into immersion as much as possible the game has no HUD, only clues. The voices are one with another being Senua’s rotten hand, an indication of a health bar; her mental health. The game follows the golden rule “less is more” exceptionally. The engine contributes quite a lot to that aspect. It’s possibly one of the first games using Unreal Engine 4 I’ve played with the exception of UT2014. I’ve realised we have come a long way since the rendition of Xan’s and Malcolm’s faces in the original Unreal Tournament. Words cannot do justice to describe the motion capture technology that was utilised to bring Senua into digital life. I could see Senua’s eyes shining or the fear drawn on her face, a whole range of emotions which I was fortunate to witness. The environments are so still, devoid of life, yet so lush and rich in themes. Hellblade’s visuals are truly engrossing. Thankfully, Ninja Theory incorporated a Photo Mode (accessed by pressing the Home key) which can be used to take pictures of the game however we see fit. It’s a mode which possibly entitles a second playthrough just for the sake of it.

Honestly, I could drag on and on. I could emphasise how delicately Ninja Theory have dealt with a very sensitive matter such as psychosis, taking notes from established scientists in the field and actual people living in this perpetual state. How they have consulted historians to depict an accurate world. How the combat mechanics are quite fluent without being overbearing. I will not do that.

Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice is not a game. It’s an example of what people with vision, scope and means-for-the-purpose can achieve without being burdened about demographics of marketing to a target audience. It’s a true testament of what the combination of Art and Science can result in, using video games as a medium of expression. Forget for a moment all the trendy competitive online games. Buy Hellblade. Switch off the lights. Put on your headphones. Turn it on. And live one of the best experiences in gaming.

Hellblade is a Masterful work of art, a totally different game than any other i have ever laid my hands on, It delivers a gripping and emotionally charged experience like no other. From it's stunning visuals to its amazing and somewhat terrifying audio design, i was immersed from start to finish. The devs nailed the atmosphere, character design while showing just what a person who experiences psychosis actually goes through. While the subject matter can be heavy at times, the game handles it with care and is conveyed with an unprecedented level of authenticity and respect. Even as i'm writing this i can still feel the chills going down my spine.

The gameplay is more about exploring the world the senua's sees, solving puzzles to move forward and less about fighting enemies. although, the boss fights are brutal and can get pretty intense at times. Each chapter has a number of "lorestones" that are scattered throughout its entirety. They are not hard to find and offer depth to the story in general. Anyways, if you're still wondering if it's worth a buy or not then don't even think about it and go freakin' buy it already. it's a unique experience that you don't wanna miss out on.

139468779.review:
[h1]10 games worth of work, put into 1 single game[/h1]

1) [u][b]Increible ambientacion y gráficos:[/b][/u]
 
El juego entero así como Senua, que es el único personaje que vemos casi todo el juego, se ven [b]espectacular[/b]. El lore está [b]cuidadosamente[/b] estudiado e insertado. 

2) [u][b]Sarpado laburo para simular la esquizofrenia y psicosis:[/b][/u]

Varios profesores y doctores fueron parte del desarrollo de Hellblade.

3) [u][b]El combate:[/b][/u]

El combate empieza fácil, a modo de tutorial para que le agarres la mano, y termina bastante desafiante. También, cuando haces los parrys perfectos... es [b]simplemente hermoso[/b]. Y ni hablar cuando tenes a Gramr. El combate se torna aún más genial y desafiante.

4) [u][b]Bosses:[/b][/u]

Si bien la mecánica de combate es simple y son pocas las peleas de bosses, son hermosas y memorables.

5) [u][b]Cutscenes:[/b][/u]

El [b]laburo[/b] que se pegaron con las cinemáticas hace que Hellblade sea tranquilamente una película.
A mí, personalmente, no me importa que el juego tenga muchas cinemáticas.

6) [u][b]"Inclusión" sin ser forzada:[/b][/u]

Hay que decirlo. Crearon una historia única de una [b][u]MUJER[/u] guerrera celta recontra badass[/b], no robada ni forzada. La mayoría cuando piensa en un guerrero celta o vikingo, piensa en un hombre, obviamente porque casi todos lo eran. Pero Senua nos enamoró a todos, y a la vez no me gustaría cruzarme en su camino.

Y eso es solo la punta del iceberg. Los tipos se animaron a representar la psicosis, que sufren muchas personas, en un juego para que vos la puedas experimentar. Se animaron a hablar de lo que muchas personas consideran tabú. [b]Merecido cada uno de los premios ganados.[/b]

7) [u][b]Actuaciones:[/b][/u]

La actuación de Melina Juerguens es [b][u]sublime e inmejorable[/u][/b]. Le puso muchísimas ganas para representar la psicosis y darle vida al personaje de Senua. Con respecto al resto, en general muy buenas las actuaciones de voz.

8) [u][b]No HUD:[/b][/u]

No estoy acostumbrado a jugar juegos sin HUD. Tengo que admitir que se suele sentir un poco incómodo ya que estamos tan acostumbrados a ello. Pero en Hellblade, las mecánicas son lo suficientemente simples y aún así perfectamente pulidas, que la falta de HUD no solo no afecta, si no que aumenta muchísimo más la buena atmosfera que el juego crea para vos.

9) [u][b]Opinión personal:[/b][/u]

No me gustó mucho la música estilo pop al final. Hubiese quedado mejor, a mi gusto, otra música capaz más epica. Es la única, y minúscula, crítica constructiva que tendría para hacerle.
Literalmente no tengo otra cosa que decir de Hellblade que no sean cosas buenas.

[u]Es una completa obra de arte, y merece que la juegues tarde o temprano.[/u]

139464477.review:
At first I thought this game was carried by its concept over its content but it definitely brings it back around. Cutscenes and scripted sequences were cinematic and incorporated a lot more horror than I had initially realized, there were lots of intense moments that also show off some really impressive graphics. Sound design is also great and the 3d audio of the voices in Senua's head were very cool to experience. Things do initially begin pretty slowly, the puzzles are a bit obtuse and you'll be asked to look at things from certain angles many times over but they do become more intuitive as you progress. Similarly, I started as pretty unimpressed by the combat as while again very cinematic, it does feel a little simple at times. That being said as I progressed, through a combination of getting more comfortable with the controls and the game having more interesting combinations of enemies, I learned to like it. I found the game difficulty is set automatically based on an early game fight which in my case set it to hard and made enemies unnecessarily tanky though, would recommend manually adjusting it to Normal as that felt much better balanced after changing. I will also warn that this game isn't incredibly polished. There were a few pretty inconvenient checkpoints, some rough looking pop-in at certain points, numerous occasions of objects clipping through things, and multiple times where I had to reload my save file due to getting stuck on bad geometry, once from getting softlocked in a small ring of rocks, and twice from just getting stuck to trees and freezing in place.

Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice tonally, graphically, and cinematically is a brilliant experience with puzzles and combat ranging from serviceable to decent, so if you're still interested and can live with that balance I'd say definitely pick it up on the next sale.

139460305.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is the story of a mentally ill woman on a mission to wrest her lover's soul from the bloody, twitching entrails of hell itself.

They apparently consulted with a number of experts about psychosis and did their best to represent it accurately though dramatically.
The story is well-presented and engaging.

The visuals are phenomenal, although some of the screen effects are pretty overboard.

The gameplay involves solving perspective puzzles, listening to old norse audiologs about mythology, and of course stabbing dudes, while worming your way into the depths of Hel. IMO stabbing dudes was the [i]least[/i] enthralling part of the game - unfortunately, it was a large part. I feel like it's telling that the section I liked the most was one where Senua broke her sword and had to traverse a number of areas unarmed before getting a new one.

Despite my nitpicks, I enjoyed the experience and will almost certainly play the sequel eventually.

No idea why this has so many positive reviews.
I might be too old, but I'm having a hard time identifying with a whiny nutcase looking for her boyfriend.
Maybe it could have worked with an actual personality, but she's really just whining and moaning the whole game bare any other facets.
But, more important, the game itself just sucks really hard. Took me just 7ish hours to finish and still felt like eternity. Just about half of that time you're actually playing (solving riddles, fighting), the other half you're walking around at a terribly slow pace or listening to lore. You can't even jump, further limiting the leveldesign. I didn't explore anything due to the slow speed, still didn't miss alot.
The fighting itself is very shallow and has only few different enemies, not that these few make much of a difference anyway. 

On the plus side, sound and graphic design is great, but that won't cut it for me.

139311605.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an extraordinary game that left me utterly captivated and emotionally moved. From the moment I entered Senua's shattered world, I was enveloped in a hauntingly beautiful and deeply immersive experience that pushed the boundaries of storytelling in gaming.

The game's greatest strength lies in its portrayal of mental health and the inner struggles of its protagonist, Senua. As someone who has dealt with my own share of personal challenges, I found the depiction of mental illness and psychosis to be incredibly authentic and respectful. Senua's journey is a raw and powerful exploration of the human mind, and it had a profound impact on me. It's a reminder that we all have our own battles, and it's through empathy and understanding that we can find strength and resilience.

The gameplay mechanics perfectly complement the narrative, creating an intense and immersive experience. The combat sequences are visceral and satisfying, demanding precise timing and strategic thinking. But what truly sets Hellblade apart is its ability to seamlessly integrate Senua's own mental manifestations into gameplay. The voices in her head, the visual distortions, and the puzzles that reflect her internal struggles all serve to deepen the connection between the player and the protagonist. It's a masterful approach that blurs the line between reality and illusion.

Visually, Hellblade is a work of art. The attention to detail is astounding, from the meticulously designed environments to the hauntingly realistic character models. The game's use of light and shadow creates an atmosphere that is both beautiful and foreboding, enhancing the sense of unease and tension. The breathtaking landscapes and the nightmarish realms that Senua traverses are a testament to the artistry of the developers.

The audio design in Hellblade is nothing short of exceptional. The haunting score perfectly captures the emotional depth of the story, evoking a wide range of feelings from fear and despair to hope and triumph. The use of binaural audio techniques is a stroke of genius, as it immerses you in Senua's world, making you feel every whisper and murmur as if it's happening inside your own mind. It's a sensory experience that heightens the emotional impact of the narrative and adds another layer of immersion.

In conclusion, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an extraordinary and thought-provoking game that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and tackles sensitive subject matter with grace and respect. It's a deeply personal and emotional journey that resonated with me on a profound level. From its compelling narrative to its innovative gameplay mechanics and stunning visuals, every aspect of the game is a testament to the dedication and artistry of the development team. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you intellectually, emotionally, and leave a lasting impression, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an absolute must-play.

139264687.review:
This is the best sounding game of all time thanks to its binaural audio simulating voices in your head. What a great way to simulate mental health issues. I cannot wait for its sequel.

I finished the game a long time ago and I've just tried starting it now, when it's about 6 years old and even the graphics hold up tremendously well. If this game came out today, it would still be praised for how beautiful it is and that's not even counting the 2021 Enhanced patch, because that only improves shadows and reflections. The game is gorgeous even without RT. The gameplay is fine, but nothing to write home about. The game really is about immersion and atmosphere and it delivers on both fronts in a spectacular way. 

From technical standpoint it's very good as well as it has all the things you want - HDR, DLSS, super-ultrawide support and pretty good optimization. DQHD resolution (~4K) with RT without DLSS was able to bring my framerate under 100FPS on a 4090, but DLSS/FSR brings it right back up to over 150 and RT is not really super necessary, so I'm sure it will run fine on most modern PCs... Especially since it hardly needs more than 60FPS due to its slower nature. It's perfectly playable even in 30 for people that can stand it. I also finished the whole game back when it was new on a gtx1080 in QHD without running into any major framerate drops, so if you have an old PC and want to play a very pretty game on it, this is one of the best choices.

139233760.review:
[h1]Your worst enemy doesn’t need to be physically present[/h1]

Hellblade is one of the kind game that I ran too, without knowing what will greet me. Even though I heard some reviews and talks about Hellblade few years ago, except the core part of the game what it revolves around, in the end it actually really blew my expectation away. Kind of hard to treat this as a video game entertainment. But regardless, it has incorporated gameplay elements in this short adventure to call it a video game and single out Pros and Cons.

[h1]Presentation:[/h1]
Hellblade Senua’s Sacrifice is a third person action adventure semi-open yet linear game set in a world of Norse mythology. Each part of level environment perfectly blends with Senua’s story and her problems that accompany it. In some other games many will say it’s empty and doesn’t give you a reason to care or play it, except here. It's very fitting for the theme which capsulates the feeling of condition of being lonely, otherwise it would kill the whole vibe of collecting little items, since the whole goal is to not waste time around running here and there. Aside from being lonely, the environment often changes, based on your mental state which gives you a feeling being insane. Apart from the main quest, there is nothing else to explore besides lore stones that teach you about Norse mythology.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2982419433
[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
At first I was thinking it would be an interactive movie, with how the main character walks very slow, but glad I was wrong. First thing as a player what you greet with, is having ability to focus on the runes which are everywhere around us until you look properly and realize the right one. The game gives you hints where it should be, but you’re the one who will need to look properly to find it. Later on, with focusing you can find patterns, or manipulate whole environment to open new paths. And I really liked this open new path manipulation (switching back and forth was kind of funny to see how was implemented in the game). Basically, when you watch through a specific gate, it totally changes path which can open further progression. Overall, it serves as a break from combat and contribute to the overall atmosphere of the game. Aside from this puzzle elements, which is one part of this game that surprised me, focus also helps you during a combat as a time manipulation thingy to overcome your enemies. As for the combat, I found it mixed bag, would say it’s pretty basic. You have heavy attack and light attack, dodging or blocking or parry. The game camera automatically locks on to whichever enemy is attacking Senua. Timing is also important, otherwise it can punish you pretty good, not as like souls game. If you die, you’re not gonna respawn far away but the pressure of near death and her illness will give you second thought before rushing in again and button mashing it. There are few types of foes. It basically comes down to light and heavy types with the same fighting technique. I'd like to see in a second game that addresses this with more types and styles of enemies.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2982419775
On the other side, the suggestions and cues provided by Senua's inner voices were one feature of the game's combat that I found to be very enjoyable. They frequently shout, "Behind you!" or "FOCUS!" really helped me especially with limited camera movement. It fits perfectly and is a clever design choice. Using your senses in later gameplay to move through environment was also cleverly designed. Even though there are a lot of linear games, most of them are flooded with texts and prompts, except here it’s opposite. No tutorial, you will learn simply and naturally and no HUD, which gives overall cleanliness and ability to look around without to go in photo mode. Overall gameplay is good but it's not the main shine where it stands out. As others have said the main critique would be about being very slow and more of a "walking sim" type of game. Anxious to see how the sequel will differ.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
It follows Senua on a journey into Helheim with hopes of rescuing her dead lover. From very beginning we learn that’s more heavily focused on Senua's personal journey and her struggle with mental illness through life. The narrative of the game is intricately entwined with themes of sorrow, trauma, and her battle with psychosis. The battle manifests in a way that it feels especially extraordinary, as they are represented by untrustworthy narrators, voices who suggest contradictory concepts in order to make you doubt yourself and blurs the lines between reality and Senua's subjective experience. As a player, you’re immersed in Senua's tortured psyche as you navigate the haunting landscapes and confront her inner demons, but also makes you feel fear, dread, anxiety. In my personal opinion, it would have been far better executed if we as players wouldn’t have been addressed with the depictions of psychosis from very beginning, rather gradually realizing this aspect on your own. Nevertheless, you can really tell that the developers really put all of their effort to present this very complex topic in a clever, bold and respectful way which was obviously well-researched and that I found to be incredibly enlightening. Whole story and more of details around this theme is addressed in the video.

[h1]Audio/Visuals:[/h1]
Hellblade's audio design is outstanding, music is perfectly blended with environment. But the main show comes from voices. My god, that was executed phenomenally (especially after seeing how it was done, in one of the videos). At one point even I started to quarrel with in game voices. Really wish more games had this 3D audio feature. As stated in the game, you must play this with headphones; otherwise, the game will not be as immersive as it should be.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2982421459
Hellblade is also a very pretty game. Beautifully crafted environments, great atmosphere and with the addition of ray tracing, it appears to be released from last year and can be screen archer's dream. Character model and animations are excellent. When you move your camera, either her head moves or whole body depending on situation, which I like when this is implemented rather to be static unless you move the character. In game photo mode is by todays standards bare-bones, doesn’t offer a lot and has visual bugs like not seeing mouse. Also, camera can’t be moved in 3D rather left/right or up/down. Thankfully the game comes with my personally best software implementation, NVIDIA Ansel, a powerful tool that takes your photos on a whole new level and makes you like a professional digital photographer.

[h1]Performance:[/h1]
Didn’t encounter any visual glitches or game braking bugs. Ran constantly above 100 fps on ultra settings even with ray tracing elements on max, to be straight I was playing on 4070 Ti and in 1080p. I suggest you to turn off DLSS, especially if you are digital photographer because it can be seen how it shimmers around Senua’s outfit and everywhere else (DLSS was on quality).

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
Visually great looking great, awesome audio and very well storytelling which can’t be seen very often in AAA video game industry. Hellblade truly transfers you to another world for a little period of time, giving you the sensation of living as someone else. To have deeper connection with or a greater understanding of the character. And that’s what this game and many other remind me why I play video games to begin with. No other media achieves this quite as well as this one.

Rating: 8 / 10
Recommendation: YES

I suggest disregarding any negative criticisms concerning gameplay elements and immersing yourself in Senua's captivating vision quest firsthand. In my opinion, the compelling story and relatively short duration of the game outweigh any potential drawbacks.

139022157.review:
!Small spoilers! (more of a retrospective than a review)

First off:
Absolutely amazing game. I loved it. I count it as one of my favorite games (if you can't tell by my profile).

I gotta say the game feels different when you first play it but I couldn't put my finger on it at first until I played other games and it suddenly clicked. I realized what this game was missing: A HUD.
There is no HUD and it feels like a real journey, a movie almost, no indication of your health, stamina, items, quests or whatever, just you, your sword and the voices.
You have to watch your surroundings and react to it like your character as it becomes slower the closer you come to dying but surprisingly and amazingly the same is said for the enemy, they also react to hits and slow down when low, have less attacks etc. which gives the fights a fair feeling throughout the game.
You have the focus mechanic that is indicated on the mirror you carry on the waist but nothing is really in your face or in the way, it helps you focus (no pun intented) on the game a lot more.

The puzzles which form the core gameplay are very creative at first. I really liked the looking out for the runes bit but they became a bit of a chore after a few times (maybe that's intented to represent the condition by constantly recognizing patterns or challenges that aren't there but nonetheless).
It felt somewhat tedious and especially if you're going for 100% like I did because either you walk around everywhere to find lorestones beforehand or play the sections again which for me was a bit annoying since I knew the story already but the bit before Valravn dragged on for so long (maybe also because I was being stupid and had to watch a walkthrough).

It's not open world which don't get me wrong is perfect for this game. It's very fitting for the theme to be confined to the story path and running around as you please would kill the whole vibe.
You have a goal and that goal only and there is no time to waste running around doing useless errands etc.
The experience was improved that way and made you feel trapped, almost claustrophobic even within a wide empty landscape like before the gates to Hela or at the tree before Odin's trials, it feels lonely, which capsulates the feeling of the condition.
The feeling of loneliness is reinforced even more when you realize that you're truly alone the whole time, the only living beings are the enemies you face that want to kill you and they don't really talkand the only people you trust are not even real.

I really enjoyed the combat. Since there aren't many attacks you have to memorize and it's straight forward, you can work on perfecting your skills with what you have.
The bosses are great themewise but were relatively easy at all difficulties although the later bosses are pretty terrifying 
(I died like 20 times to the man-bear-pig boar wolf beast thing but it was the best boss fight in the game and one of the most terrifying moments along with that one Odin trial (you know which one I mean)).
The thing that confused me at the start from a gameplay perspective was that you got no real introduction to the controls or mechanics and had to go to the menu screen to read them first, which I immediatly did but others did not.
That resulted in many mechanics not learned or only very late if you didn't experiment with the controls or watched tutorials (like the focus mechanic). I kind of liked it though since it encouraged you to try out different combos and I learned that you could even stun the enemies by just running into them which (along with the kick) helped against 
shielded enemies.
There were no instructions, no manual for enemies, nothing to help you fight, you are alone only accompanied by your voices and since there were no indications etc., you only had those to help you in a fight by saying things like "attack", "behind you", which helped me alot.
Of course the premise is perfect for such a mechanic since it is not out of place for the voices to help you in a realistic scenario and it doesn't feel out of place or disturb the immersion like some on screen indicators or tutorials would.
If I would have to give one tip it would be: Really listen to the voices, they guide and help you when you're lost or struggling against enemies. It's not just some rambling.

Nonetheless the story is great and makes you question just as much after beating the game as in the beginning if not more. The game forces you to come up with your own interpretations and judgement which is a refreshing take.
The delusions could really kill you even though you as a player knew they weren't real but since they posed a real threat (like the darkness) you were scared of it nonetheless, making you just as afraid as Senua herself and helping you understand her better. At no point did I question why Senua felt or acted a certain way since we as a player are pratically inside her mind knowing her every move and thought.
The player itself becomes a part of the delusions, sometimes on Senua's side where you're wondering if you're not just another voice inside her head, controlling her and sometimes on your own side where you're questioning if you're really seeing things you're supposed to see such as the search for the runes. You spend so much time looking for these runes, 
placing yourself and other objects at just the right angle that sometimes you think you see it but really it isn't what the game intented you to find.
You're really adapting the mindset of the protagonist like when fighting the bosses. Things like "Yeah, let's get them and find Dillion" "Where the hell is my lover?" or "I'll kill all of you if I must" are what I thought even though I knew it wasn't real.
But the beauty in this game is you never know what part is real and what isn't. 
Did she fight real gods? Was she fighting some random people who she saw as that way? Or did she just imagine all of it in her head? 
Well, the ending confuses you more than giving you closure and frankly, we will never know which leaves every player interpreting it in their own way and having their own head canon.
But this exact experience is really the most memorable thing about this game.
It's an eery but badass experience.

Oh and another tip would be to play the game. But if you really don't like puzzles/riddles and are only there for combat, then this isn't for you.
This game heavily relies on lore and audiovisual experience and there is not alot of combat like in other games.

139006610.review:
This is probably one of my all time favorite games. It's such an amazing experience, and a piece of art through and through. The amount of detail in this game is incredible, the developers definitely put their heart into this game. Highly recommend watching their "dev logs" on Youtube, it really shows how much research and detail they put into the game. 

As a game developer myself, I often play this game when I start to feel down and lose my passion for making games. I've played this game 4 times now and it's safe to say that each time I play it, I'm fueled with inspiration and passion for video games again. 

Now one of the main critiques I hear about this game is that it's more of a "walking sim" type of game. And they are right, but that's not a bad thing. The game doesn't really focus on action and combat too much, but mainly on the players experience with the game. You're put in Senua's mind and so you hear and see everything she does, which can be very intense.  She experiences psychosis, depression and grief, and those elements are heavily present in the game. Like hearing voices right up against your ear and the walls appearing as if they're melting.  

I recommend walking into this game knowing that combat and even game play isn't the focus of the game, rather that it's focus is on being a part of Senua's journey through hell and the absolutely incredible story and experience you get from that. 

This is a game I always recommend everyone plays at least once in their life!

138947212.review:
[b]Worth playing in 2023?[/b]
(or before [u]Senua's Saga: Hellblade II[/u] releases)

[hr][/hr]

Short answer: [b]YES[/b]
I bought this game back in 2020 and never really touched it for whatever reason. Last year I did my first playthrough on Xbox and I was very impressed. The overall concept behind Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is so abstract that it's a playable piece of art.  You find yourself in a cryptic dark fantasy world with an oppressively dense atmosphere. The acting, animations and storytelling is amazing - the graphics are still quite stunning. It has no replay value, but is an exciting adventure in its own way.

The biggest criticism is hidden in the combat: the system is simple and effective to use, which comes in very handy since the fights are quite challenging at times.  But unfortunately it's too repetitive and it often feels like copy-paste/go-again. Disappointing, but not disappointing enough to not recommend this masterpiece. I'm really looking forward to the second part and I hope the developers improve the weaknesses.

138835402.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a groundbreaking game that takes players on a gripping adventure through the complexities of mental health. With its captivating gameplay, stunning visuals, and immersive audio design, it pushes the boundaries of storytelling in video games.

As players assume the role of Senua, a Celtic warrior, they embark on a harrowing quest through a haunting Norse underworld. The game seamlessly blends combat, puzzles, and exploration, keeping players engaged throughout.

What sets Hellblade apart is its authentic portrayal of mental illness. It sheds light on the protagonist's struggles, creating a truly empathetic experience. The visuals are breathtaking, immersing players in a meticulously crafted world that reflects Senua's fractured mind.

The audio design is masterful, utilizing binaural techniques to heighten immersion. Whispers and echoes envelop players, intensifying the emotional journey. The voice acting, especially by Melina Juergens, captures Senua's depth and adds weight to the story.

While the combat and puzzles have minor shortcomings, they are overshadowed by the game's brilliance. Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a landmark achievement in video game storytelling, addressing sensitive subjects with maturity. It is an unforgettable experience that deserves to be played by those seeking a profound and memorable gaming journey.

138462499.review:
A Haunting Journey through the Depths of the Mind

Introduction:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an extraordinary masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of traditional video games, delving deep into the realms of psychological horror and storytelling. Developed by Ninja Theory, this dark and immersive experience is a testament to the power of gaming as an art form. With its thought-provoking narrative, breathtaking visuals, and unique gameplay mechanics, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice stands as an unforgettable testament to the potential of interactive storytelling.

Mind-Bending Narrative:
At the heart of Hellblade lies a narrative that fearlessly tackles the complex and sensitive topic of mental illness. The game follows the journey of Senua, a Celtic warrior plagued by psychosis, as she embarks on a quest through the Viking underworld of Helheim to save the soul of her beloved. The developers collaborated with neuroscientists and individuals who have firsthand experience with mental health conditions to ensure an authentic portrayal. This attention to detail shines through, resulting in a deeply empathetic and thought-provoking exploration of the human mind.

Incredible Atmosphere:
From the moment you step into Senua's world, you're enveloped in an atmosphere that is equal parts haunting and mesmerizing. The game's audio design deserves special recognition, as it plays a vital role in immersing players into Senua's fractured reality. Voices whisper, shout, and sometimes deceive, providing an eerie accompaniment to the unsettling visuals. The attention to detail in sound design is commendable, contributing to the overall sense of unease and anxiety that permeates the experience.

Visual Poetry:
Hellblade's visual presentation is nothing short of breathtaking. The game's environments range from grim and desolate landscapes to ethereal and otherworldly realms, all meticulously crafted with an unparalleled attention to detail. The use of light and shadow is masterful, creating a chiaroscuro effect that further enhances the game's atmosphere. Moreover, the motion capture performances and facial animations are remarkably realistic, breathing life into the characters and allowing players to forge an emotional connection with them.

Innovative Gameplay Mechanics:
Hellblade's gameplay mechanics are a perfect blend of exploration, puzzles, and intense combat sequences. As you traverse the game's beautifully haunting landscapes, you'll solve environmental puzzles that are seamlessly integrated into the narrative, allowing for a smooth and immersive experience. Combat, on the other hand, is brutal and unforgiving, emphasizing the weight and impact of every strike. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenge and accessibility, ensuring that players of varying skill levels can enjoy the journey.

Conclusion:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is an undeniable triumph, pushing the boundaries of storytelling and gaming as an art form. Its unflinching exploration of mental illness, combined with its haunting atmosphere, stunning visuals, and innovative gameplay mechanics, sets it apart as a truly exceptional experience. Ninja Theory's dedication to creating a game that resonates on an emotional level is evident in every aspect, making Hellblade an unforgettable journey into the depths of the human psyche. Prepare to be captivated, challenged, and forever changed by this masterwork of interactive storytelling.

138348864.review:
I'm writing this review after one 100% playthrough, hopefully it makes sence :)

9,5/10

I couldn't stop thinking about this game, an incredible masterpiece. I was hooked by Senua's creepy journey from the start because to its unique blend of psychological terror, furious combat, and an intensely personal story. (Yea i actually liked the combat)
The game's portrayal of mental health is both raw and empathetic! It delves into the mind of Senua, a Celtic warrior plagued by psychosis. The use of binaural audio techniques create an atmosphere that truly immerses you in Senua's tormented world.
The game's visual design is breathtaking. The landscapes are both beautiful and haunting, reflecting the duality of Senua's mind. The attention to detail, especially in the facial animations, is astonishing, further enhancing the emotional depth of the story.
The combat mechanisms are smooth and satisfying and they flow naturally with the story. Every interaction is intimate and difficult, as if Senua's inner demons were taking on physical shape. Every combat is an intense and thought-provoking experience because to the utilization of different perspectives and hallucinations, which adds another level of complexity to the action.

But the story of Hellblade is what really makes it stand out. The tragic and deep journey of Senua to save the soul of her deceased lover explores grief, guilt, and self-discovery.(I have to add that Dillion felt out of the place sometimes and even breaking immersion, but maybe im missing something). Melina Juergens' portrayal as Senua is nothing short of amazing! Senua's hardships drew me in on an emotional level, and I could feel her anguish, anxiety, and tenacity in every move.
Senua's Sacrifice is more than just a game; it's a piece of art that respectfully and eloquently addresses serious issues. It serves as a reminder of the storytelling and empathetic potential of video games. It made a deep impression on me by provoking a spectrum of emotions I hardly ever feel in other games and questioning my perceptions. Thank you for this experience Ninja Theory!

I can't suggest Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice enough if you're seeking for a challenging and engaging experience that pushes the limits of storytelling in video games. It's a gloomy and terrifying voyage that you'll remember long after the final credits have rolled.
Definitelly worth the money!

I have mixed feelings about this game. I finished it in less than 6 hours, got most of the lorestones during the story and the rest of the time I spent to get what I missed for the last achievement. So it was quite short, definitely grab it on a sale, it's not worth the full price. 
The game is unique, I loved the art style, the mechanics were innovative, but anything else felt average. Combat is very basic - dodge, block, parry, heavy attack, light attack with no real combos, switching targets was well done and I liked that the voices are telling you when an enemy is about to strike from behind. The puzzles were also average, a little bit confusing at the beginning, but very cool designed. The forced backtracking was annoying and has no purpose other than artificially increasing the gameplay duration. Combine this with the fact that Senua can't move faster than my grandfather and it results in the game being more of a walking simulator with psychotic voices in your head that sometimes tell important story related stuff, but most of the time are useless thoughts.
All in all, I understand the people who say this game is overrated, but it's a good game, I had a good experience, it wasn't anything crazy. I will play for sure the sequel :)

137976654.review:
I’ve known about Hellblade for a long time but have never gotten around to playing it. I didn’t know that much about it, but I was very impressed with the footage they’ve shown of the upcoming sequel and wanted to see if the original game looked as good. And this game absolutely blew me away. Hellblade Senua’s Sacrifice is one of the best games I’ve played in a long time and it’s a game that everyone should experience at some point. One of the best parts about it is the atmosphere. Hellblade is absolutely terrifying and one of the scariest games I have ever played. The world is horrifically beautiful and the game has a bleak and overwhelming sense of dread throughout it. The game has a lot to say, diving deep into Norse mythology, mental illness, and themes of acceptance. The story has a ton of depth to it, and it turns its relatively simple journey into a moving and powerful narrative. The acting is fantastic too, along with the sound design which is some of the best I have ever heard. The graphics are absolutely stunning, especially for such a small team. As for the gameplay, a lot of it is slow exploration, but the game never feels boring or slow. While it is pretty spaced out, the combat is incredible. The animations are insanely realistic, each hit feels impactful, and mastering the combat system was very satisfying. The enemy designs were great too, although sometimes it feels like they can have way too much health. The puzzles are the other main gameplay component and they were fun too. The game doesn’t tell you anything which adds to the immersion, but can make you feel lost during these sections. You have to figure everything out on your own, which was fun, but some of the solutions were very obtuse and I had to look a few of them up. Missing something small or not finding a barely visible path can be a bit frustrating as well. This wasn’t a huge issue in the grand scheme of things, and I have no problems with the game other than that. Senua’s Sacrifice is a phenomenal game with beautiful visuals, a powerful narrative, and an extremely intense atmosphere that is absolutely worth playing. Definitely check this one out as soon as you can.

10/10

137848545.review:
Baita jogo sobre uma garota celtica com psicose. Tudo no jogo é feito em torno desse tema central da psicose e saúde mental, sendo quase o protagonista do jogo. Fizeram um ótimo trabalho em representar o que é ser psicótico, com a cereja do bolo sendo a atriz de Senua, que fez uma ótima interpretação (parece que ela também sofre de algumas questões do tipo segundo a equipe DEV, e por isso ela soube atuar tão bem). 

É uma viagem que vai te levar aos lugares mais sombrios da mente de Senua, retratando perda, desespero, depressão, medo, ansiedade; e como eu já disse a atuação realmente transparece os sentimentos faz esses momentos serem bem relacionaveis. É realmente um prato cheio pra quem gosta desses temas mais psicológicos em jogos

Dito isso, apesar do combate ser gostosinho, e os puzzles serem legais, é um pouco "Walking Simulator" então isso não deve agradar muita gente. Não é muito, mas vai ter momentos em que vc vai sentir isso. 

E eu sinto que tinha tudo pra ser uma história que me fizesse chorar igual uma criança mas eu acho que o uso demasiado de mistério dos fatos atrapalhou um pouco isso

É um conceito, feito em jogo. Uma experiência. Nada pra vc se divertir depois de um dia longo de trabalho, mas sim pra vc embarcar em uma jornada que entrega bem.

[i] Hellblade Senua's Sacrifice [/i] is a game that is not for everyone, its a great game but could have been better, the -3 points are because of the following: 
1- The game is not optimized on my AMD system and its beyond the recommended specs to play, in other words it favors nvidia systems, personally i love both brands but when it comes to games its better not to give one sided satisfaction with the gameplay experience and let the other side suffer a little.

2- The story of Senua and Dillion's love is not a strong motif to complete the game, the story could have some tweaks to be better like giving more back story lore so we feel attached to their relation and it becomes a real motif to go through all this, all I had as a motif is me wanting to reach the wooden big statue or I dunno what to call it that we see at the beginning of the game and beat the game because I downloaded it.

3- The "inability" to change the FOV lowers the satisfaction of the game, especially in fights, you can't see clearly the environment. 

4- The puzzles can be irritating sometimes, its repetitive.

Now what I liked the most about the game is the delivering of the experience of the suffering of psychosis, seeing things and hearing inner voices, its something that is real hard to experience and live with it, it slowly destroys and kills you.
The Northmen stories of Druth are among the best things in the game, his voice is great, his narration of the stories keeps you interesting to hear more and more.

Overall, the game is not for everyone like I said, and of course not suitable for children...

137501818.review:
Hellblade is a unique game that is unlike any other. You play as Senua, who is psychotic and hears voices in her head. These voices, dance around in the player's head, especially since the surround sound effects are really well done. The perfectly positioned sounds run through the entire game experience, allowing you to hear enemies behind you, solve puzzles or simply be harassed by the voices. 

On her way to Hellblade, Senua has to solve various puzzles and fight enemies. The combat system is kept very simple and only consists of dodging, light attack, heavy attack and the special power, but it is still really fun and can also get intense as soon as you are attacked by 5 enemies at the same time. The more often you die, the harder the game becomes, especially as the shadow eats us up.

The overall atmosphere in Hellablade, which plays with light and shadow, is really spooky and very well done. It's a great way to immerse yourself in the game and enjoy the beautiful graphics and colour effects. Also the narrator's voice, which accompanies us permanently, adds to the atmosphere and makes the experience even more special.

The puzzles are relatively monotonous. Most of the time you are just looking for certain symbols that you can only recognise in certain places through special angles and viewpoints. Apart from that, there is also a labyrinth, which was particularly difficult (especially since it is not a labyrinth in the classical sense) and portals & masks - through which you travel to different worlds within a zone - to solve the puzzles.

The only annoying thing about the game was that there was a lot of backtracking in between. Apart from that, I have nothing to complain about. A really unique and exciting experience. I clearly recommend Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice.

137433033.review:
TL;DR: Beautiful walking simulator, with some light puzzle solving and a handful of combat, that tells an interesting and compelling story. I recommend picking it up when it's on sale.

Lets start off with the Pros:
The graphics and effects are fantastic. The entire time I was playing I was like "oh damn this looks amazing". I can't stress that enough, 11/10 for graphics and effects.
The story is well told and engaging. I didn't pick up on a few things initially, but in hindsight it's pretty clear and really makes you think. If you're into Norse mythology at all you'll probably dig it. I won't say more than that for fear of spoilers.

Cons:
Puzzles were kinda all the same; door is locked with runes, find them to unlock the door. Exploring was kinda punished in this way, because almost everywhere you might explore is where you'd have to come back to find a rune anyway.
The combat was pretty well done, but every encounter was basically the same after a while.
It's easy to get turned around and be unsure of which way is forward, especially in a certain area. The lack of any kind of tutorial cost me a few deaths as well, as I had to go into the options menu to see what keys did what in combat.
Invisible walls. They're all over the place and I hate them. JUST STEP UP ON THAT ROCK FFS IT'S LIKE THREE INCHES TALL WHY CAN'T YOU WALK THERE.
Clipping is another issue. It feels like the game really wants you to focus on what you're looking at.. so when a texture egregiously clips through another, especially in some of the cutscenes, it really takes me out of it. It was only really bad a small handful of times, but with how beautiful and seamless the world is otherwise, it's a shame.
And finally, the optimization. I have a 5900x, 32gb of 3600/CL16 RAM, and a 3080ti. At 1440p with everything on high except for Ray Tracing (which was on low) I got an average of 40fps with frequent dips to single digits. Turning DLSS on bumped that up to 150 in some areas, 80 in others, and fairly frequent dips to sub-30. DLSS made it so I didn't have to resort to lowering the resolution, but at some points I was really gritting my teeth.
Speaking of teeth: By the end of the game Seuna is bloody and dirty and beat to shit... but still her teeth and sciera (eyes) are this flawless white. For all the attention to detail... come on, throw some grit in those teeth, I just watched her puke black tar after being hit in the head with a mace, show some swelling and bruising, or at least put some blood vessels in her eyes! I mean really. A minor nitpick, I know, but like the clipping it's an easy thing to notice when the game is screaming at you FOCUS ON THIS SCENE IN ALL ITS DETAIL.

Conclusion:
I beat it in a single session (~6 hours) and I'm happy that I had the time to do so because I feel like this game would occupy my every waking thought until I completed it.
I paid like $8.50CAD for this game during a -75% off sale, and it was 100% worth it. I'm not sure I'd be happy with paying the full asking price of $33CAD today, but at $20CAD or less for me it's a no-brainer.
Hopefully they leraned some lessons from this and Hellblade 2 has a bit more polish, as I will almost certainly be buying Hellblade 2 the day it's released.

137357572.review:
What an amazing experience!

First off, it is beautiful looking.  The Unreal4 engine being used like this is absolutely beautiful.  I would recommend a system that can make use of the lighting aspects as that is a key feature of the experience the devs were going for.

Wonderful tale of a hero's journey but with a dark twist of mental illness.  I literally sat down and played the whole thing in one go.  Due to the nature of the development of the game it's non-linear in some aspects.  Engaging and the actress who portrays the main character really drew me in and made me believe their struggle.  Combat system is fluid and makes sense given the type of weapons she is using.  I think I only had some issues due to the limitations of my own hardware (60fps for 95% of time but I would get some moments where it would drop to 20fps and eff up my day)

Puzzle solving is my only drawback of the game, kind of interrupted the flow for me a lot, but as I understand the puzzle solving is woven into the games mental illness representation.

I have to say that their portrayal of psychosis is something that is about as accurate as I have ever heard it.  Being someone who does not experience psychosis I can only look to this game as the closest example.  The developers took their time and interviewed people who study and experience psychosis and really listened.  I have a family member whom (without their medication) will start experiencing the same symptoms.  One of the best mental health issue representations I have ever seen, the use of a binaural microphone with the voices really made me feel unsettled and the constant whiplash between supportive and downright cruel is..upsetting, but in a good way.

All in all I truly recommend this title as a wonderful piece of art.  I wish I could go more into the mythology of the game, but Norse and Celtic mythology is not something I am very knowledgeable on beyond surface level.  Can't wait for the sequel on the Unreal5 engine.  Gonna be fantastic.

137254936.review: Scary, Beautiful, Horrifying, and Unique. Hellblade is a work of art.

137247292.review:
[h1]Una obra de arte en su totalidad[/h1]

La historia: este juego te pone en los pies de Senua, una guerrera celta que sufre de una enfermedad mental, ambientado en la época vikinga, que se sitúa entre los siglos VIII y XI en Europa del Norte. también presenta elementos de la mitología nórdica. 

El gamplay es una locura, pensar que los desarrolladores trabajaron con expertos en psicosis y trastornos relacionados para investigar y comprender los síntomas y las experiencias de las personas que sufren estas condiciones, y que lo implementaron tan bien en este juego ufff una maravilla. Esto con la narrativa, la implementación de captura de movimiento para las expresiones faciales, su propio sistema de sonido binaural, que utiliza audio en 3D para crear una experiencia de sonido inmersiva, nos da como resultado esta diamante en bruto. 

Sería mucho texto el explicar con detalle este título y sus maravillas, prefiero que lo juegues y lo descubras por ti mismo. 

"A veces incluso el más simple de los recuerdos puede ser el más doloroso." (Sometimes even the simplest of memories can be the most painful.) 

10/10

This is iINTENSE! The behind the scenes documentary (the making of) explains how in depth this game is psychologically. But note that had some spoilers.

The puzzles: It's a nice balance between not having to think too much yet challenging enough to feel satisfying.  It's quick enough, it flows, yet they are not insultingly boring. 

The story, acting, dialogue: all very well done. I do wish the story had subplots, but make no mistake - there's plenty here. The audio is definitely a huge part of the experience.

Combat: It's nothing memorable for me, but I was in it for the story.

This is a game you really have to be in the mood for, but it's worth the wait for when the mood strikes.

137197824.review:
A game that lacks some of the fundamental elements that standard video games are built upon.from a different point of view it may be considered an innovative action and i respect that view and to some people it may be fun to experience , but definitely not for me, when i look at it, I see a walking simulator with some added flavors like repetitive puzzles and boring combat to push it into becoming a video game,and it definitely fails at it.
Combat at first feels nice with polished animations and sound design but quickly becomes very boring , some fights take way too long for no reason , you just mindlessly click your mouse and dodge until it's over and once it's over you don't even feel you've accomplished anything, you are just happy that it ended , like a torture and then when it comes to the puzzles , it's the same story , from the start of the game, puzzle mechanic is the same till the end of the game with one exception in one of the chapters which doesn't even add that much variety to make it worth talking about it.
The game is visually very appealing and sound design is adding so much to the dark atmospheric feeling of the game, but to me it's way too much , the voices in your head are just talking almost non stop throughout the entire game, sometimes they were making me feel dizzy,also there is no way to turn them off and even if you could you would be missing an important tool to fight because these voices help you in the fights telling you if you are being attacked from behind or if you should focus, ... which i it think is an interesting mechanic(a positive point) to be ruined with a boring combat.
The game definitely succeeds in creating a dark , hellish and brutal world with a depressed ,sad and deceived protagonist gradually falling into the darkness to then rise from it by confronting and overcoming it. hopefully this journey doesn't take too long and considering what the game is aiming to be , i think pacing is fine.
At the end I think this game is really overrated and definitely not for everyone but for a few game enthusiasts seeking new experiences and maybe a group of players that don't look for ''traditional video game feelings'' in a game and are open to experience something somewhat new.

137065156.review:
Very different, very intense, very unique experience. 

The story and art direction are top notch, weaving mental illness with medieval history and superstition to craft a very vibrant, believable and personal world. It transports you to a state of mind that is very subjective and overbearing. The game is a marvel to look at and listen to. Especially appreciated the soundscape and how it's interwoven to the gameplay. The characters are very well written, developed and brought to life. 

The gameplay itself is fine. Nothing to write home about, but with a few core loops that have enough variation in pace to keep things fresh, interesting and moving forward. The battle is a bit repetitive, though and probably the weakest aspect of the game, which, considering this was made by Ninja Theory, says something about their priorities. I don't mind that, as much. I was here for the story and world building. It's just that gameplay frequently felt disconnected to the story or themes of the game. Inorganic. And, judged on itself, the fighting mechanics are dull. 

Extra kudos for the lack of a HUD, map, objectives etc, opting instead for in-world logic prompts and that excellent sound design. Even though it's a very restricted, linear path, I sometimes got lost or confused, which added to this particular experience. Due to the linearity of the level design, though, I never needed to check an online guide. With a little patience and attention, I could still figure out things. 

If you are looking for a chill time, or a brutal beat 'em up, look somewhere else. This isn't pop corn entertainment. There are heavy themes explored in a way that takes a toll on you. Even though it took me 8,6 hours of gameplay to complete, I took a few weeks break in the middle, playing other stuff, because the atmosphere was a bit too overbearing to handle in one go. It started getting under my skin. 

Highly recommended. Really liked this.

136971545.review: Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a game that features really good storytelling, a compelling and unique protagonist, amazing audio design and graphics that still hold up after all these years. It's a short experience that doesn't overstay its welcome and manages to tell a simple yet emotional story with an in-depth look at a severe mental illness. It's hard to separate truth from fiction in Senua's Sacrifice but the journey the hero takes makes sense within the confines of the story. At face value it's a classic hero's journey to the depths of hell to find and save her lover's soul but the additional layers it provides with the psychosis angle adds depth that may not have been seen previously in a video game. It could have been a walking simulator that only features puzzles that are mostly fun and intuitive but I'm thankful Ninja Theory also decided to break up the exploration with a simple but fun combat system. And that it's a really solid experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression on the player.

136963234.review:
He aquí un videojuego con una narrativa inmersa y psicológica potente.

Desde que un videojuego era solamente como objetivo entretenernos, el paso de los años han hecho estragos en dichos Hobbies, los videojuegos, ya que de jugar y dar botones, evolucionaron en pensar, sentir y como debe ser, disfrutar y entretener.
Senua ofrece todo ello, pero más el SENTIR, porque quiere comentarnos algo en base hacia una crítica, la cual no diré para que podáis descubrirla.
Mi aportación mala, sería su Port-PC, ya que por mucho que yo use un PC potente, se me resiste y da cierto fallo, aunque mínimo. Hablo de si lo deseo meter al máximo que ofrecen.
Pero que eso no nos alarme, puesto que el videojuego visualmente, se disfruta mucho, no nos para en nada a la hora de jugar.
Mecánicas:
"Innovador" por gameplay, ya que si te esperabas a la típica guerrera Nórdica, aquí no la vas a encontrar, sino que su acción es puntual, pero eso no lo hace malo, al contrario, lo hace ligero y satisfactorio, porque estamos en un modo de investigación, suspense, dudas y de repente, acción.
Es fácil su sistema de combate, y su apartado de LOGROS, es simplemente tirar hacia adelante, excepto uno, que es el típico de Coleccionable, aunque muy útil, ya que son pequeñas narraciones que aportan mucho en cuanto a la trama en cuestión.
Su duración es corta, pero insisto que algo corto, no debe ser malo si en sus escasas horas, es aprovechado al máximo, cosas que este título hace.
Un juego recomendado para los que desean jugar-pensar, y sentirse los/as verdaderos/as protagonistas.

136871692.review:
Hellblade is one amazing trip, an incredible experience which, at times, ressembles a movie more than a videogame.

In Hellblade, you play as Senua, a young celtic warrior which embarks in a journey to bargain with the lost life of his beloved, Dillion, and will do whatever is needed to reclaim his soul. The twist? Senua suffers from extreme psychosis, which alters the way in which she perceives reality, and this trait is the focal point of your journey. Hellblade is an action-adventure game with heavy focus on exploration and puzzle solving, and illusions that twist reality are fully integrated in how not only Senua perceives the world, but also as a core mechanic needed to solve puzzles and advance through the adventure.

But what makes Hellblade its own thing, is the inmersion. Right off the bat, the game tells you to use headphones while playing it, and for good reason: Senua will hear voices throughout her quest that will talk to her, and assist her both in exploration and combat.

It's incredible how central this mechanic is, and how well it is implemented in every aspect of the game - graphics, settings, sound, combat, storytelling and direction...Hellblade might not be the best game ever created, but it could be the most immersive experience a videogame has been able to create.

Take for example combat - it is not focal to the adventure, it is well done and well balanced, but rather simple and enemy variety is not its strong point, but a couple of boss battles make full extent of Senua's psychosis as a mechanic, and even in normal combats, it is focal - there is no UI, no life bar, no markers showing enemy positioning, nothing. Only Senua's perception which gets bleaker as she gets closer to defeat, and the voices which assist you, telling you when you are in danger, if you're surrounded etc...

The game is rather short (7-8 hours) but given its intensity, it's the perfect lenght for it. Creators even added a 20-some minute long documentary in which they explained how they created a game as special as this and is the perfect closure for your experience with Hellblade.

As a player who always puts action over exploration and who is easily annoyed by puzzles, Hellblade was rather tough on me at first (the infamous Valrand section, which will be one fo your the first two sections you play) discouraged me at first, but the game grew on me as the story advanced and I ended up loving it.

Solid 8.5/10 and a masterful piece of art

136825553.review: I was absolutely blown away by Hellblade Senua's Sacrifice. The graphics, sound design, and storytelling are all incredibly immersive and haunting. The game tackles some heavy themes with grace and sensitivity, and I found myself deeply invested in Senua's journey. The combat mechanics are also really satisfying, with a good balance of challenge and accessibility. Although the game is quite short, there are collectibles in the form of lore stones that add to the overall experience and can help to lengthen the gameplay. By exploring the game's world and finding all of the lore stones, you can uncover additional backstory and deepen your understanding of the game's world. Overall, this is a must-play for fans of dark, atmospheric games that push the boundaries of storytelling and gameplay.

Can't wait for the sequel!

136778504.review:
Sadly, I don't think I'll be able to finish this one.

Cons: 
-Too much walking (can't even sprint) and clunky movement.
-Collectible lore stones: if you miss one or more, it seems there's no way of getting back to the ones you've missed, without perhaps, slowly walking all the way back to potentially find them.
-Game will occasionally glitch/bug out with the only solution being a restart.
-Game doesn't seem to run very smoothly.
-Ends up becoming very repetitive and boring
-Puzzles are basically all the same.
-While in combat, you cannot disengage to back up a bit or anything. Sucks when, in cases of block being ineffective against certain stronger enemies, you cannot create space between you and your opponent and have to hope your dodge works.

Pros: 

-The fighting animation is enjoyable enough.
-This game has a level of immersion for people who can potentially relate to the character. Bit of a mental trip, full of confusion.
-Interesting and immersive game atmospheres; pretty nice graphics.
