Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice es un juego increíblemente intenso y emocionante que ofrece una experiencia única y envolvente. La narrativa es profunda y reflexiva, y la forma en que se presenta la historia es impresionante. Los personajes son complejos y bien desarrollados, y la actuación de voz y los efectos de sonido agregan un nivel adicional de inmersión al juego.

La jugabilidad es desafiante pero justa, y los rompecabezas y combates son una mezcla perfecta de habilidad y estrategia. El mundo del juego está bellamente diseñado y es un placer explorarlo, y la banda sonora es simplemente impresionante.

En general, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice es un juego que debe ser experimentado para ser apreciado. Es una obra maestra en términos de narrativa, jugabilidad y presentación, y es una experiencia que no se olvida fácilmente. Si eres un amante de los juegos emocionales y profundos, definitivamente debes darle una oportunidad a este juego.

Its simple and difficult all at the same time.  There are a lot of flashes, and lighting effects that add story and ambiance to the game, so playing this in the dark could involve a jump or two, you've been warned. also, YOU MUST PLAY THIS GAME W/HEADPHONES.  The sound effects and the various voices talking at you or over each other, is disorienting at first, but it's meant to be that way. The combat was fun and also difficult and required skill, almost Dark Souls, but I'm a moderate gamer so that could just be me, lol.  The only issue I had was the walking/running mechanic. 136553054.review:
Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is easily one of the best games I've ever played. 
Just as a game it already does incredibly well, with an immersive and engaging story, a compelling and unique protagonist, good puzzles, a simple yet satisfying combat system, and amazing audio and visual design. However, Hellblade does not feel like just any game. Hellblade is truly unique, a game of AAA quality made by just 20 developers, without a hint of the typical AAA greed I've come to expect whatsoever. Hellblade also goes beyond just a game by attempting to accurately portray psychosis and help reduce stigma surrounding mental health by allowing people without psychosis to somewhat experience what it might be like, and helping them to empathize with those who are affected. (Ninja Theory video on this for those who are interested: https://youtu.be/HM0yaCFwHDE). In order to do this, Ninja Theory even brought in mental health professionals to aid in the development of the game, taking the extra step to ensure they didn't get anything wrong in their portrayal of severe mental illness. More than the game itself, this is what makes Hellblade so impressive to me, and sets it firmly among my favorites.
11/10

136437401.review:
Se trata de una joya de juego. Es un walking simulator, con puzzles y escenas de combate. Es una delicia como está realizado el juego, el solo hecho de andar está simulado de tal forma, tan realista que te apetece andar solo por ver los movimientos de la protagonista.

Sobre el tema del juego, para mi es una búsqueda heroica,  muy antigua, un guerrero que viaja al Reino de los Muertos para salvar a su compañero. Es un mito primordial, muy antiguo, Gilgamesh, o en la mitología griega, Orfeo, Hercules o Ulises también se enfrentaron a Hades y a Perséfone para ir la tierra de los muertos. Hellblade nos ofrece este viaje heróico de superación desde la perspectiva de la mitología nórdica. De hecho el juego está plagado de pequeñas semillas y relatos de mitología vikinga que son una maravilla.

El juego incide mucho en su producción en el tema de los Deliros y la psicosis del personaje, es un tema interesante e incluso muestra un documental de cómo se nutrieron de experiencias reales de personas con trastornos. Está muy bien introducido la idea de los patrones que dan sentido a la mente del trastorno. Pero en mi humilde opinión, lo interesante del juego es el viaje heroico y como se represnta el mundo divino (o trastornado en la mente de senua, que es la explicación oficial que dan los productores pero).

El apartado sonoro, la dificiultad, la orignalidad del juego, el diseño, los combates ... son una maravilla.

Ojalá hubiera más juegos de este tipo y con tanta calidad. Muy Muy Recomendado.

136369154.review:
Taking just 6 hours to beat, Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is pretty short, but that means it does not overstay its welcome. The game has a really interesting mechanic where voices in your head talk to you, puzzles, and a story I don’t think I fully understood.

For the most part, the puzzles were interesting and and pretty simple to solve, but there were a few I got stuck on, and a few I solved without meaning too and I’m still not sure what the solution was. The bits of the story I did get were interesting, and I do feel like I understood the general idea. The combat is not super complicated, but it was very satisfying. Attacks felt fast and weighty.

The game likes to throw all sort of effects at you, such as different types of blurs, film grains, ghostly images, particles, and other detritus that make much of the game look very unclear. I didn’t see an obvious way to turn this stuff off and it definitely felt like it was there to set the mood, and sometimes it did work, but the end result is that much of the game looks bad and blurry.

136347956.review:
Beat Hellblade Senua’s Sacrifice last night and fucking loved it going to ramble a bit about why I loved it in non-spoilery terms since you should play it for yourself! 
1.Senua as a character is so well done her mental illness is treated empathetically (there is a whole behind the scenes thing included with the game that covers how they approached it). I really came to care about this character over the course of the game. The actor portarying her does an amazing job the facial expressions/animations are so good. 
2.The Voices Senua hears voices these voices act as a turtorial at times but they are mostly there to second guess Senua and the players actions (though sometimes they cheer you on). In combat they warn you of enemies attacking from behind while also discouraging or encouraging you depending on the voice. This made combat feel pretty tense like I was being judged for every missed parry or dodge, I liked it it added to the paranoia and doubt the game is going for.
3.Combat was fine, it felt sluggish at times but I enjoyed parrying and when I was in the grove it was fun but it deff won’t be for everyone. I found it more engaging than 2018 God of War’s combat.
4.Puzzles mostly perspective stuff which made sense since Senua sees the world differently. Some of these puzzles are pretty clever There were also some parts that reminded me of Little Nightmares only without the wonky platforming. Looking for Runes got a bit tiring toward the end though (used a guide for some of them).
5.The Environments or fucking gorgeous this is a damn pretty game at times and a damn scary one at others. Some of the imagery is real gnarly and I loved it (This is a horror game). 
6.Bosses are challenging and fun in this at least for me they were. Not going to say much more about them except that the bird like one was my favorite.
7.Random other stuff the game does a great job at making Senua look dirty and bloody it really looks like she has been through/going through Hel inside and out. The other Voice actors do great in this game. I love how enemies react when you deflect their weapon back at them. The music is really good.
8.The lack of button prompts during tutorials threw me off but the controls are right there every time you pause the game. 
9.Dillion is a silly name.
Wild that the same developers who made Kung Fu Chaos would make such an empathetic and thoughtful game.

136347257.review:
About as perfect as any 30 dollar game can be. 

Completely original, graphically beautiful, simple but fun combat. In terms of gameplay, the only thing I'll mention is that it does deal with very dark themes, and can get scary at times. That said, I *cannot* play horror video games and I got through this just fine.

As to how it runs on PC, it's pretty great-- I had high framerates at native 4K (100+ fps) on my 4090. 100 GPU utilization, low CPU utilization-- we love it! It does appear to have some issues when loading new areas from disk, where I'll see my GPU utilization drop (along with the framerate). It can be a little distracting, and so it's worth mentioning.

But all that said, this game is a masterpiece: one of a kind. It deserves more eyes and ears, since it's got such an interesting and important story to tell.

136315141.review:
While I enjoyed the broad strokes of Senua's Sacrifice and would recommend it in small doses (and whenever it goes on sale) there were a significant number of things I found frustrating in my playthrough that I can't wholly recommend it.
In terms of things I enjoyed, I found the rune and vision puzzles to be engaging. I thought they were a creative way of using the idea of vision being the focus of magic in the ancient world; you find the truth by searching and literally focusing to reveal the path forward through the supernatural world of Helheim. I also liked the nods to more obscure Celtic lore (not Norse as that is there in spades, but specifically Celtic references such as the geilt). There were also very gorgeous scenes I came upon, despite my rig not being able to optimize it in Geforce.
Combat was a mixed bag for me. On the one hand, it is serviceable hack-and-slash with entertaining combos and techniques that can be pulled off. It is also one of the few times I found the voices in Senua's head to be somewhat helpful. On the other hand, combat in a broad sense feels more tacked on in order to pad out the game time with only certain fights really progressing the story. Although there is a significant mechanic based around combat, it feels more like an afterthought for what is primarily a cinematic game.
This last part is where I have trouble recommending Senua's Sacrifice to most gamers as I personally do not like games that are made to feel like long, interactive, animated movies. Senua's Sacrifice feels as though it is part of the trend of AAA games (although it comes from a middle-market studio) that is made to be more of a cinematic experience than an actual game. There is no player agency in Senua's decisions and no branching paths, just one track leading from level to level. While an on-the-rails game can be perfectly executed, Senua's Sacrifice doesn't itch the same scratch as more attention seems to have been given to the story and melodrama of Senua's journey than the actual gameplay. While the effort of Ninja Theory shows in certain sections, such as ones where you are challenged to use other senses than pure "gamer instinct", I could not get over the feeling that I was being strung along through a melancholic mood piece with the same self-indulgence as an A24 film. The cinematics at best showcased interesting motion capture technology blended with live action superimpositions, and at worst made me roll my eyes and wait for them to be over with.
While I understand that the game is meant to replicate psychosis and includes different deterrents and themes that served to present that experience, I found it to be one of the more frustrating parts of the game. The voices are one of the worst parts of this game. While I wanted to turn them off to play in peace, I felt forced to leave them on in case I needed a hint in combat or exploration or maybe to listen to tidbits of lore as they came. The self-doubt/self-encouragement dichotomy the voices engage in that becomes a theme as you continue through the game is also grating as one minute the voices are telling Senua that she's worthless but then the next they hyper her up like she's had secret powers inside her this whole time. This relates back to my gripe about this not really feeling like a game per say but a showcase of good looking graphics, interesting methods of using sight and sound in gameplay, and this particular character's journey through grief and insanity.
By the end of the game I was not really sure how to feel. I understood what happened but felt rather unfulfilled. I did not particularly connect with Senua although I understood her grief and story throughout the game. In fact, I found her somewhat annoying as she would switch between doubting herself and suddenly acting confident or break the fourth wall completely to make some pseudo-philosophical comment. In fact, I found myself pitying her more than empathizing with her, which oddly might be how she would be perceived in her culture as treatment for mental illnesses was almost non-existent. Still, there was some odd link that I felt in the sense that the characters used modern ways of speaking and talked about more modern concepts, which only broke immersion a few times.
I really wanted to like Senua's Sacrifice but I can only confidently call it "alright." This is best acquired on sale if you are dying to get this game. Hopefully the sequel will improve upon this game, maybe providing more player agency, making combat more meaningful, and Senua more sympathetic.

136155691.review:
I was originally holding off playing Hellblade and avoiding spoilers until getting a VR headset; going in spoiler-free was absolutely the best way to handle it, but delaying a playthrough so long was a mistake.  The non-VR version was already engaging enough and the game quality vs. length already felt "short & sweet" enough that I'd be happy to replay it in VR again in however many years it takes for me to get such a setup.  Dunno that I'd replay it a 3rd+ time; at that point I imagine the novelty of the story & gameplay may wear off.  But that's fine -- one playthrough and checking it out in VR later's enough to say it leaves a strong positive impression.

Felt all the more impressive to have played it while a psychology-field-familiar friend spectated, and hear them comment on things they noticed & I didn't, all while complimenting how well the whole game world was presented.  The entertainment industry is generally lacking in well-produced, well-executed titles featuring either non-sexualized women in leading action roles, or respectful presentation of characters facing the same kinds of internal struggles as this one did, so to see all of it done at the same time made this game seem all the more like a standout.

I played the first half on a Steam Deck docked to a TV, and it ran impressively well.  But the latter half of a game really shone when played in a computer, arguably less so because of the better GPU being able to do raytracing, and more because I was using far superior audio hardware & headphones.  I'm struggling to think of other games that have had positional audio done this well and had similar importance from opening credits through to end credits.

136131617.review:
[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ The story, voice acting, and sound design is unparalleled. The entire game is built around this eerily accurate portrayal of psychosis, and what that means for both the protagonist, Senua, and her journey as a whole. Are the foes and forces she faces real or part of her repressed trauma coming to light? That line is constantly blurred, which is in and of itself an apt description of those who deal with these types of hallucinatory mental disorders; what is "real" takes on a whole new meaning for people with psychosis because what they experience [i]is[/i] real for them. Anyone who has interacted with someone going through psychosis, dementia, schizophrenia, or any type of reality bending disorders will resonate deeply with this game's story and characters.

+ Animations, especially facial, are so well done; the animation and motion capture brings so much life into Senua's struggle. It's impossible not to connect with her on a deep emotional level and to feel every bit of confusion, anger, and sadness that boils up to the surface amidst traumatic memories and terrifying hallucinations.

+ Nordic mythology acts as the backdrop to the story, which helps sell that feeling of mysticism and uncertainty surrounding Senua's condition. Throughout history mental disorders have been misunderstood, and even attributed to having been both blessed by the gods or cursed with some unholy corruption. This story leans heavily on the latter, and shows how ancient Celtic civilization would have vilified Senua due to her condition and caused tremendous trauma that would only make her worse.

+ The combat is simple, cinematic, and satisfactory. It's nothing special, but it gets the job done and feels good when you get into a flow. The game does a good job at making you feel like with every strike and every dead foe, Senua is (literally) fighting her demons and conquering her trauma.

+ Puzzles are clever and play into the whole hallucination factor, often seeing runes made out of normal objects or changing reality based on perspective. It all fits perfectly into the overarching story.


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Combat can be too simple for some tastes. The damage you can take, even on hard difficulty, is extremely forgiving and the same can be said for the amount of times you can "die". This makes it so combat feels less dire and ultimately just a break between story points.

- It's short, which is fine for a story-driven game, but I would love to see a fuller game built around this same character and concept. One that has a slower burn and can afford a larger level design with some limited exploration and more interaction between the character and the environment.


[h1]Summary[/h1]
Base game completed:  YES
DLC completed:  N/A
Rating:  8 / 10 - Very Good

135827468.review:
This game is generally one of the better offerings from the past decade. I love the fact that the game doesn't overstay it's welcome, and effectively uses it's entire lenght to maximum without making me feel like it was getting stretched or that it was cut short. 

Another (subjective) plus is that I managed to get 100% in my first playthrough. Sure, this doesn't make the game that replayable if you're an achievement hunter, but it invites replayability just through the story, the settings, and gameplay. Therefore, replaying the game is more like rewatching your favorite movie rather than experiencing the game in a new way.

I love the art, the music, the atmosphere, the themes, the story everything is great. But, for the sake of not spoiling anything, I won't detail what I liked at each point in the game.

The only real downside is how the game seems to throw enemies at you at random points. Also, during certain points, you will be able to tell when you're about to enter an arena. 

Senua is a great character, beautifully acted and voiced. Also, the audio in general is probably the best audio I've ever heard in a game. I won't spoil much, as it's story-relevant, but DEAR LORD IN HEAVENS, this game sounds so good.

So, who would I recommend this game for? People who like story based games with light combat and light puzzle solving. People who like puzzle games or combat games will be disappointed, as Hellblade decides to focus more on the story. 

This game gets an incredible 9/10 from me.

TOP FUN THINGS TO DO:
⭐️ Collecting the Lorestones.
⭐️ Solving puzzles.
⭐️ Just watch and listen.

THE UNIQUES:
💎 Feels like a movie.

PLAYER GAMING REQUIREMENTS:
💼 Story Rich.
💼 Mythology.
💼 Psychological.

PROS:
+ Voice acting is perfect!
+ Feels like a movie.
+ Doesn't feel like you're solving puzzles.
+ A very balanced game between fighting and story telling.
+ Graphics are great, even on a low graphics card.
+ HEADPHONES ARE A MUST!

CONS:
- Combat might be simple for some players.
- It's a bit short but the price makes it worth it.

VERDICT:
Well that was a journey I didn't expect on taking, but now that it's over, I fee like i'm suffering from withdrawal. The voices that you hear, makes you miss them when they're gone in a strange messed up way. None of the things Senua goes through are good but you're glad that you went through them with her. That's my take on the psychological trauma she battles through.

In the end, the game is mainly a story telling one, with a few simple puzzles and a nice handful of enemies to fight along the way. A lot of players didn't think there were enough fighting but that's just an opinion, try not to focus too much on the combat and more on the battling that's going on in Senua's head.
Total Score = 94/100.

GAMEPLAY:
Set in a dark fantasy world inspired by Norse mythology and Celtic culture, the game follows Senua, a Pict warrior who must make her way to Helheim by defeating otherworldly entities and facing their challenges, in order to rescue the soul of her dead lover from the goddess Hela.

135568550.review: Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice is a game that features really good storytelling, a compelling and unique protagonist, amazing audio design and graphics that still hold up after all these years. It's a short experience that doesn't overstay its welcome and manages to tell a simple yet emotional story with an in-depth look at a severe mental illness. It's hard to separate truth from fiction in Senua's Sacrifice but the journey the hero takes makes sense within the confines of the story. At face value it's a classic hero's journey to the depths of hell to find and save her lover's soul but the additional layers it provides with the psychosis angle adds depth that may not have been seen previously in a video game. It could have been a walking simulator that only features puzzles that are mostly fun and intuitive but I'm thankful Ninja Theory also decided to break up the exploration with a simple but fun combat system. And that it's a really solid experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression on the player.

135433018.review: The ending had me ready to tear up a little. Artistically speaking, this game succeeds with all its intentions. I've seen someone look at the ceiling and scream "shut up" at absolutely nothing. After finding myself aggravated by the constant voices in the game, I can see what would bring a person to react that way. It almost felt instinctive to pull my headphones off at some points because I wanted it to stop. The narrative and messages of the game began to feel a little scattered by the end, but the idea of confronting one's inner darkness was presented very well throughout the whole game. It was interesting to see the character face the camera and speak to the player, as if the developers were using soliloquy to draw the player further into the experience. I wanted to know how and why Senua was responsible for the destruction of her village. Maybe that was explained, but it felt like the story had some details that needed more presentation to stand out. Dillian's death, and how Senua came to possess his disembodied head, were vague points for me. I especially enjoyed the first scene in which Senua spoke to her mother through the statue with a face on it. The words "there is nothing wrong with seeing the world as you do" stuck out to me. I was reminded of something Jean-Paul Sartre called the problem of the Other, which is a way in which people separate each other from each other through an instinctive negative reaction. When a person sees another, they do not see an individual with their own subjective reality. The person viewing the other sees only an object to be overcome and dismissed. Further, I recalled R.D. Laing's criticism of how the medical community treated schizophrenics, which seemed centred on completely dismissing their hallucinations as irrational nonsense. Ongoing and extreme hallucinations can be as valid a part of anyone's reality as anything else. Perhaps through taking time to understand the nature and sources of these hallucinations and experiences, then treatment of the individual's psychosis would become easier. By disregarding their experiences we miss out on the human element of any sort of treatment. My primary complaints with the game come from the complete lack of explanation of combat, and the nature of some of the staring puzzles. Combat feels sluggish and repetitive to players who have not been given an understanding of the game's nifty combo system, the functionality of the jumping and kicking attacks, or to the point behind staring at objects or runes. Fighting and puzzles became fun around halfway through the game after I had deduced some of these things myself. The player should have been given a mention of these things, or a quick two minute introduction of sorts to these mechanics. Some of the places and objects at which one was supposed to stare felt pretty nebulous, even for a game intended to be that way. The lore stones were nice and seemed to parallel the main story, but attaching an achievement to finding all of them made the idea feel overused and a constant disruption to the immersion. I think the game could stand some optimisation as well. I was streaming this game with a nice quality gaming laptop, but still encountered a few glitches and a blue screen at one point. The game also made my fan run unusually fast, which shouldn't happen with my current hardware and a game that is six years old. This was a wonderful experience, and I've ended up playing it at a great time for myself. Well done, Ninja Theory. Thank you for this game.

135296837.review:
Hard to recommend this ASMR induced nightmare trip. It's difficult to not recommend it either. Alas, there is no mixed option.

Right, cons first;
-For a game you spend ton of your time walking, movement truly feels ridiculously clunky and it's not uncommon to get stuck between two slight bumps on the path and have to restart the game from last checkpoint. 
-FOV is so tiny that with ease I can count Senua's individual dandruffs, buddy I played with got motion sickness and had to stop watching couple of times. 
-Puzzles are boring and Lorestones as optional objective messes with the flow of the game as instead of progressing naturally you walk, painfully slowly, back to find the ones you've missed.
-Combat is passable, I guess, though it's inconsistent and becomes confusing in groups of enemies as there's no way to disengage to reposition so you mash dodge in hopes that maybe, just maybe, game will let you move to a spot that let's you see whatever the hell is happening.
-Game runs bad. Not always, just one second for every twentieth second it will slow to a crawl. Disorienting to say the least (thankfully this happens less and less as you progress). 
-Lastly, the story WANTS you to put the pieces together, I really like that it doesn't shove everything in your face and you naturally come to understand things leading to the game's events. Sadly, it's underwhelming. 

Reading all this you might say, well I should stay the hell away from this game. Maybe, maybe...but hear me out.

This game has an amazing sense of design and pacing (forgetting about Lorestones). It has a way to grip you from the start and drip-feed you context and story bites. Graphics are delight to look at and environments are so superbly made that you can't help but mess around in photo mode for every new area you step in. Sound design is fantastic and it achieves a delicious sense of dread all the way to the finish line. 

Tons of potential to this game, lots of great things in it, but as a standalone it bleeds out from hundred little cuts. So I will definitely check out to see if the sequel addresses some of the issues I've listed, mainly the story. So this review is subject to change.

**(if you like smoking a little giggle smoke, jolly green, la lechuga del diablo, dinkie dow, jazz cabbage; disregard all the cons listed and just enjoy the terrifying ride.)**

135057055.review:
Este es un titulo increíble , es un indie pero podría llegar a tener el estatus de un AA.
La banda sonora es brutal(una de las mejores,que he escuchado en mucho tiempo), la ambientación Nórdica(valla barbaridad), la historia que esta totalmente hilada con el juego y realmente me ha producido la sensación de caminar por paramos nórdicos... 
Este también expone varios puntos ,relatos y lugares de la mitología nórdica como el Helheim, el Niflheim, Midgard, sigmun y el dragon, Odin e imir ,entre muchos otros.

La historia de este titulo es muy cruda , nuestra protagonista Senua sufre y mucho tanto física como psicologicamente y nosotros mismo en este juego, ya que el titulo inicia con la premisa de que si morimos nuestra marca de oscuridad se extendería a nuestra mente y nos obligarían a empezar de 0(Lo juegas con las pelotas en la garganta,pura tensión); esto nos lo hacen para que sintamos lo mismo que siente nuestra protagonista al poseer un trastorno mental

El juego yo lo dividiría en cuatro partes a comentar por separado: 
-En primer lugar, sus cinemáticas , las cuales pueden parecer extensas pero son increíbles ; hilan bien la historia ;como si de "nornas" se tratasen; te lo explican todo de forma simple y entendible , por no hablar de su espectacular animación y mezcla entre personas reales y el propio personaje, las cuales quedan brutales y añaden un toque mas de diferencia con otros títulos.
-Por otra parte , se encuentra sus mecánicas de pelea ; la cual le da dinamismo a la historia, es un estilo muy sencillo y te resultara fácil aprender a usarlo.
-La exploración; es cierto que es limitada ya que no es un mapa abierto como tal , pero el juego te incentiva a explorar para escuchar mas historias sobre al mitología , las cuales si las obtienes todas , te desbloqueara un dialogo secreto.
-El tema puzzles , en general es bueno , al principio es repetitivo, pero, conforme vas avanzando en la historia estos se vuelven mas complejos y muy originales.

También me gustaría destacara que este juego tarta el tema de la psicosis, este es el tema principal de la obra, la cual padeció la madre de nuestra protagonista y nosotros en este juego, dándole trama a la historia de forma única, a esto añádele el contaste parloteo de voces en nuestra mente las cuales nos ayudan ,se contradicen entre ellas , nos retrasan y dañan.

En mi opinión juégalo tu mismo, ya que este es un titulo el cual solo tu mismo puedes decidir si te gusta o no

PARA MI 10/10

135044510.review:
I learnt the hard way to not be afraid of death, Senua. Because a life without loss is one without love. Turn your back on death and you only see the shadow that it casts. The longer you hide from it, the longer the shadow grows, until all you can see is darkness. When our time comes, we must look death in the eye and embrace it as a friend. Only then can we let go fear, and emerge from our darkness.

 At the end of the game, the psychological problems in Seuna's mind have grown so much that we can no longer understand what is real or how schizophrenic visuals are in her head, but the only point we are sure is that Seuna has now stopped bringing her lover back and realized that such a thing is impossible. Everything we've seen fighting for so long was actually Seuna's inner conflict, neither Valraven, it was all actually Seuna's own thoughts.

134996566.review:
Sometimes we stumble on games that are difficult to pinpoint in terms of recommendation and Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice fits right into that category. In game you play as Senua, a Celtic(could be wrong about her descent, my interpretation stems from her warpaint and her grudge against[spoiler]Norsemen[/spoiler])woman suffering from[spoiler]psychosis(!)[/spoiler]. She embarks on a journey to Helheim, in order to find[spoiler]her dead husband Dilion[/spoiler]. 

World representation and atmosphere are the strongest aspects of the game, both beautiful and horrific landscapes feel quite immersive and breathtaking. One of the major components of the game are voices you hear due to your mental state, they often insult you, taunt you however sometimes they can be useful, suggesting a useful hint to complete a puzzle. Music is also rather enjoyable. Puzzles are by far the weakest and most annoying part of the game, some them are outright unintuitive and boring, breaking the dynamic of game. Fighting is okay-ish, although it feels smooth some might find it bland but just mind this is not your average game where you play as buffed up hero. Representation of Norse mythology is done nicely without any cringe modern takes so it all adds up to the experience. Apart from puzzles it is quite short and linear(7-8 hrs) which is another con. 

At the end, would I recommended this game? For most people I recommend waiting for 75% or some kind of Bundle(got it myself from the Humble Bundle). However if you are into anything mentioned above go for it.

134943554.review: Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice es un juego que te hará sufrir y disfrutar al mismo tiempo. Es la historia de una guerrera celta que se enfrenta a sus demonios internos y externos para rescatar el alma de su amado. Pero no es un paseo por el parque, sino un viaje por el infierno nórdico, lleno de enemigos, acertijos y alucinaciones. El juego te pone en la piel de Senua y te hace escuchar sus voces, que te guían, te confunden o te critican según les dé. El combate es intenso y fluido, pero también tiene un riesgo: si mueres demasiadas veces, el juego se borra y tienes que empezar de nuevo. Así que más te vale estar atento y no distraerte con las vistas, que son espectaculares. Hellblade es un juego único y valiente, que explora temas como la psicosis, el trauma y el amor con una sensibilidad y una calidad artística impresionantes. Eso sí, no esperes reírte mucho con él, porque es más bien una tragedia griega con vikingos.

134570880.review:
With this game you are really in hell. Take a lot of boring, babbling dialogues (love story?) which you can naturally not skip, and spice it up with a bit science about psychosis. Add a lot of searching for spots in the environment to solve some runes (often I did not even know how I solved the puzzles) and the obligatory search for collectables which give some tiny bit of information about the norse gods. Add a fighting system and, of course, do not explain it completely. After all, you want to create a pseudo-intelectual game and  so the gamer has to  guess how to make for example a rush attack and what it means if your voices in the head are babbling about "using your focus".

Oh, and on top of all, they combined an autosave system (no manual save allowed) with a game-over system if you loose too many fights. Of course, they don't tell you, how many fights you can loose before game-over.

134280687.review: Absolutely stunning game both visual/audio and thematically. The gameplay is broken into two kind of experiences: a souls-likes hack/slash & a myst-like puzzler that requires environment investigation & some backtracking. The two experiences are interwoven together at pretty solid pacing. While you're solving puzzles, there are audio/narrative pieces that paint a picture of Senua's history/past & build her character as well as the story up. I enjoyed that chill part of the game more than the hack/slack aspect >.<; the boss-fights were probably the most fun and rewarding part of the hack-slash experience. Highly recommend. This game re-invigorated my interest in video games and gave me hope that there are still some good story-rich games out in the ether that is Steam. Great to see a unique, indie title of such caliber. Well done Ninja Theory.

134278639.review:
Hi, friends. This is gonna be a long one.
I don't often review games nor do I often feel the need to review games. But with Senua's Sacrifice I felt like I just had no choice. I was tempted to just leave a joke review, something like, "average day with ADHD", but Senua's deserves more than that.
I first bought this game three years ago on my Xbox One. Funnily enough my therapist, who's big into story games, is the one who recommended this to me. I'm a person who's dealt with schizophrenia for around 7 years at this point-- I'm 19 now, so if you can imagine a 12 year old trying to deal with that then you can try and sympathize. I wish there was more to say about it other than that I just woke up with it one day and it hasn't gone away since. It felt catastrophic at first. I felt like I could never know what was real-- like I never knew if I was still dreaming or not. That's probably the best way to put it. I was balancing my middle school and high school years with trying to cope with what felt like an undeserved punishment from God. Or that, there couldn't possibly be a God who would thrust this upon a child. But it got better. I got medicated, and with a lot of trial and error (and even more self-acceptance), I've gotten to a point in my life where I feel like it doesn't affect me. It comes in waves and now, thankfully, most of the time I'm all good. I haven't had a harmful episode in about two years, and with continued support from my psychiatrist and therapist, I know I will be able to live the rest of my (hopefully) many years on this planet. I'm at peace with myself, or at least I think.

I bought Senua's Sacrifice three years ago, like I said. This was immediately following a pretty bad episode that led to a lot of discord in my family. A few of my ties with family members were really strained and they still haven't really healed yet. I had gotten on new medication and it helped tremendously. I didn't know much about Senua's when I bought it-- all I knew was that it was meant to represent what having schizophrenia was like, or something like that. My therapist thought that it might help me deal with what I was feeling at the time, knowing that games can be a good escape from reality. So, I opened the game and sat through the opening scene, where Senua is in the boat. Or at least, I tried to. After most of the way through, I had tears welling up in my eyes and I felt my heart beating out of my chest. I threw my headphones off and cried in my bed for half an hour. I couldn't stop thinking about the voices in the game: "Go back!", and "What is she doing?" kept ringing in my head. Those two lines really hit close to home. After I pulled myself back together, I shut the game off and forgot about it to play some more Overwatch. I tried my very hardest to completely forget about Senua's Sacrifice.

Fast forward a year later and I'm scrolling through my Xbox library and find Senua's eyes staring at me from the menu. I was hit with the memories of her voices talking to you through the screen and felt like crying again. But it had been a year, and I thought I was ready. So, I started the game back up and managed to get through the opening scene without freaking out. But that was where it stopped-- the tears came back in full effect once she got off the log raft. But that didn't stop me from playing. I kept through the tutorial area with tears in my eyes, but fully invested in the game. I knew the voices weren't mine, as much as they sounded like it. I knew they were Senua's, and I wanted to be here to experience them for her. Honestly, I played through the game with tears in my eyes for most of it. I had never in my life felt so connected to a game before. Every voice, every doubt, every encouragement-- I felt it deep in my soul. While obviously I can't speak for every schizophrenic person, and while the game certainly stylizes some things for the sake of gameplay: this game is a heart-rending masterpiece, a melancholic and beautiful representation of something I've lived with for so long. And I hope other people who live with schizophrenia will play this game, if they can get past the very triggering aspects that it certainly does have. Thank you, Ninja Theory, for creating something that so masterfully represents a thing that almost no one can explain.
[b] And for any schizophrenic person who's reading this, whoever you are, do not forget about your support system. I know it is easy to forget them when you're having an episode, so write it down somewhere you'll see every day. There are people who love you and will treat you as a person no matter how you might sound to them. And they will be there for you, whether or not you know you need it. [/b]

In summary, please buy this game. I bought it on Steam just so I could experience it again with the new graphical update. Senua's Sacrifice is an experience everyone needs to have-- even, and perhaps especially, those who don't experience psychosis. This game does such a beautiful job of respectfully and wholly representing a community of people who are often disregarded.

134145785.review: I started playing Hellbalde without any idea of what I was going for, and it was a happy surprise. The game follows Senua a character with mental illness, as you play it you see the world through their eyes while you understand how scary these visions and voices can be. I usually play RPG with a lot of in-game collectibles that don't contribute any to the game, with complex systems of gear or skill upgrades, but to my surprise, this game had none of these things. I would like to say that for me, this game was more than a game and more like an experience. A lot of puzzles showing the true challenges of a mentally ill person and for the true gamer experience the hard difficulty gave me an incredible combat challenge that scales along the game. I strongly recommend this game for the ones who like a good story with Nordic mythology and very fun combat and puzzles.

134099246.review:
Played this game years back now and revisited a few times since. It's an experience that will stay with you. The suggestion to play with headphones makes the game even more immersive. This is truly a psychological bender where a lot of the development is coming from the protagonists inner monologue. 

The combat is not very nuanced or challenging, but combat is not the main draw here. The peppering of Norse mythology help in keeping the tense atmosphere, because there are some genuinely disorienting moments. Just like Senua, the player is never really reeled back to a feeling of normalcy. Ninja Theory did an awesome job of having the environment tell as much as any character. While short, I highly recommend this one for anyone who is looking for an experience.

133824652.review:
Wow. I mean… wow. The only similar medium that managed to present me a mental illness so well was only a book Welt im Rücken by Thomas Melle where the writer describes his own experience with his own mental illness (bipolar disorder). But unlike a book, a game has much more means to deliver you the message and experience. And creators of Senua's Sacrifice used all their means to the max. The sounds, the voices "in your head", the visual sensations, the hellish surroundings… I just could feel all the professional counselling behind the game and the decision to stay true to it till the end. Only this new life experience, this possibility to "live" through such a unique life and to see and hear the world differently would be worth of buying. 

But Senua's Sacrifice added more: simple yet very strong story everyone can at least partially identify themselves with, tons of emotions, Nordic myths, imaginative (and quite horrifying) settings, great dub, great sound effects and music, amazing acting. I loved the main character - a woman that is incredibly strong yet still feeling, caring, gentle. Oh, and it's the third game in my life that made me cry like a little girl. 

+ unique life experience which most game don't even try to deliver (and which Senua delivered excellently) 
+ story 
+ characters
+ settings
+ music and sounds
+ fights
+ puzzles

- nothing. Not a single negative thing in entire game. 

~ one point I cannot really figure out how I feel about. It's a literally game-experience changing information, so don't read if you are not really, really sure, you don't mind super-big spoilers. 
[spoiler]The permanent death hoax the game gives you on it's beginning. On one hand, it made every fight incredibly intense and I was really proud of myself when I didn't died. I never felt like it actually matters whether I do a mistake or not in a game before and I enjoyed the fights much less after I learn the truth by mistake. On the other hand, it was the reason why I nearly didn't bought the game, postponed it for a year, and then played it for several months. Only AFTER I watched most of it on Youtube. I'm a bad gamer and I simply didn't believed I had a chance. If the perma-death wasn't there, I would enjoy it without spoilers with single-hand experience (which is a big thing for me). If the perma-death was real, I could be proud of myself for how far I would get even if I didn't finish the game. But this middle way… I really don't know how to feel about it. [/spoiler]

This game is more like a work of art than a game. It offers a surreal experience that feels like a constant cinematic sequence. As you control Senua, you feel like one of the voices in her head, spectating her journey.

The combat is okay. The puzzles can sometimes feel like a chore that needs to be done to progress the story. However, even during the puzzles, the immersion is great thanks to the voices in Senua's head. They mock her, cheer for her, and give her hints, adding an extra layer of immersion to the game.

To emphasize on this, those voices (best experienced with headphones) are so haunting that I often felt like not engaging with the collectable Norse story bits just so it doesn't overlap with them. I often used to walk instead of running for the next objective just to enjoy that immersion.

133342611.review:
One of the most beautiful and harrowing pieces of media I've ever experienced. I usually joke around in my reviews but I can't here; I'm too impressed by the ways in which this game manages to immerse me into the experience of psychosis. By the end of the game you feel like you better understand what it's like for people with hallucination and delusion-based mental illnesses, especially as the game merges those experiences with regular video game mechanics. Finding the Nordic runes in shadows, branches, poles etc. representing the ways psychotic patients see patterns others don't is SO clever, as is the decision to have the voices both help Senua in combat and belittle or threaten her. You feel so closely with Senua and her experience/mindset by the end that seeing her realize Dillion is truly gone despite all our best efforts is as heartbreaking for you as it is for her. 

Judging it through the lens of a video game, it has a nice variation of beautiful locales you can pass through--it has a very linear progression so that you can't really explore, but it fits with Senua's goal (she's not there to wander). Valravn's area is particularly impressive despite him being the "first" boss--Hela totally pales in comparison to that creepy, twitchy floating creature who disappears when you pass around a tree trunk, and his chants as you close in are terrifying. The illusion gates and lining up the raven symbols were so cool and really emphasized his theme of nothing really being real. The other puzzles were also fun and diverse, especially the Trials (the Blind trial could have been its own horror game omfg, WHAT WERE THOSE GROWLY BLOB THINGS). I also REALLY like the [spoiler----->] decision to lie to the player by saying if you die too much, the game resets; it's just another one of the many ways the game puts you in Senua's mindset, because if she fails, everything is lost. 

The only cons I could think of is that 1) it's far too short, I beat in ~8 hours, and 2) the combat system is simplistic and a bit clunky. The auto-target is a minor frustration because you can't choose which Northman Senua attacks, so she'll book it for the guy across the room when she's got a berserker to the left swinging axes at her. The bosses had some cool combat mechanics, but the Northmen started to get repetitive after a while. For some reason the Sea of Corpses (another area with incredible design) had this one fight with like 10+ enemies in a row that was harder than anywhere else in the game despite being the midpoint. Story has always been a priority over gameplay for me though so at most this is a blip on an otherwise perfect experience.

I cannot recommend this highly enough. When Hellblade 2 comes out, it'll be one of the few video games I'll ever pay full price for.

133147920.review:
I think this game should be described as a mental health counseling session, using video games. Is it a unique and cool idea? YES! TOTALLY! Was it fun to play? NO. I think the developers achieved their goal and people seem to like it, so that's great and I'm happy for them. But for me, it was a waste of a day and I'm glad I didn't pay full price. If I would have paid $50 for 8 hours of game play (half of which is cinematic) I would have been MAD.

+ Story is well written, albeit SHORT
+ Sound is OUTSTANDING. Some of the best of any game!! 
+ Great message, tackling mental health challenges
+ Tricking you with the threat of permadeath was a GENIUS idea. You don't actually die and have to start over, but they make you THINK you do, just so you are afraid of it. So they are messing with your mind the whole game. THIS IS AWESOME. HAHA!

- Combat system is terrible
- Graphics are great in some areas and really bad in others
- Her human visions are of real life faces, not game models. This was super weird and off putting
- Puzzles were boring and repetitive
- Monsters were very limited. You fought the same ones end game as you do at the beginning
- Gameplay was 8 hours
- Nothing to explore or check out. Just follow the path. I can't stand when games are that linear

6.5/10

132722757.review:
It is fantastic when I buy a game without much knowledge about it but based on good reviews and then discover what an incredibly enjoyable game it is. That was the case with Enslaved: Odyssey to the West. So when I read reviews of Hellblade and saw that it was by the same developer I had to buy it, and was filled with anticipation of repeating the experience. Unfortunately I was disappointed. There is much to be impressed with about Hellblade, and the included documentary video confirms that the efforts of the developers were laudable. However maybe the efforts were misdirected?

Most games have long periods where the player has total control over the protagonist, interspersed with story-driving "cut-scenes" where the player has limited or no control. I don't mind cut-scenes as long as they are not too long and don't take over the protagonist's actions too much. Indeed cut-scenes involving a player decision for branching a game story are great because they maintain player involvement. In contrast for me Hellblade is a long cut-scene interspersed with periods of game play where the player has limited control of the protagonist.

Much of the game is a mostly linear walking simulator with puzzles which start interesting, but soon become repetitive. Then there are interludes of combat using mechanics which feel very QTE driven. In fact I soon learnt that there is a strategy to combat involving the right timing of dodge, block and attack which made the encounters become repetitive and rather boring, especially right at the end. There is a lot of Norse mythology to be listened to, although it forced a slower pace of the game to hear it all, especially with the other dialogue going on.

The "experience" part of Hellblade was good, but the game part was lacking, and that is why this is one of the rare times that I have to give it the thumbs down. The experience, and the story that the developers where trying to convey, would have been better delivered as 3D animated movie, something that I would have been happy to watch on Netflix. If the developers want to make more games then I suggest that they return to the style of Enslaved: Odyssey to the West.

132716709.review: A masterpiece of interactive storytelling and a must-play for any fan of the action-adventure genre. The game's depiction of mental illness and its impact on the protagonist, Senua, is both powerful and poignant. The combat system is well-designed, providing a challenging but satisfying experience. The game's narrative, which is steeped in Norse mythology, is both captivating and thought-provoking, and the character development of Senua is truly inspiring. A triumph of game design and a shining example of how video games can be art.

132661182.review:
I'm a bit conflicted about this game.  On the one hand, its story, presentation, and voice acting are all top-notch, and can make for a gripping experience.  I'm not an expert in mental health, but from what I've heard, the game portrays psychosis very well.  On the other hand, the experience of actually playing the game is just as often fiddly, frustrating, or just plain tedious.  Overall, I'd probably recommend it, but with some reservations.

First of all, the game makes a really interesting choice in minimizing non-diagetic elements.  It has very few UI elements, and instead delivers information through the voices in Senua's head.  This is a good decision, I think, in that it helps bring us into Senua's perspective better, but it does come at a cost.  In particular, the game often doesn't communicate certain things very clearly at all, to the point where I wasn't even aware I could do certain things until I looked up the controls in the menu.  This problem contributes to some other problems, as we'll see below.

The combat is fairly engaging at first.  Unfortunately, even though it's used fairly sparingly over this not-particularly long game, by the end I felt that it overstayed its welcome.  The problem is that there's not much enemy variety, so the only way the game can increase the challenge is by making you fight a bunch of enemies in a row, or by throwing a bunch of them at you at once.  Fighting a bunch in a row doesn't make things more difficult, but it does increase the amount you have to play through again if you do screw up, which can be pretty frustrating.  As for fighting multiple at once, usually they move slowly enough that you can fight them one at a time, so it ends up being more or less like fighting them in a row.  However, near the end, the game starts throwing so many at you that you end up fighting the camera, and its need to focus on only one enemy at all times, as much as you fight the enemies themselves.  Enemies in general also have too much health, making combat last longer than it should, IMO.  There was one boss in particular that took fooorreeevveeerrr, because beating it meant doing the same dodge-attack combo at least 50 times, and it deals quite a bit of damage itself, so if you screw up you have to start all over again.  After a few tries, I just turned the difficulty down to easy, and the fight still took way too long.

As for the puzzles, roughly 40% of them had fairly obvious solutions, 40% required actual thought to solve, and 20% made me want to strangle whoever designed them.  The main problem is that the game is fairly bad at introducing new mechanics, so whenever there's a new one it's a bit of a guessing game to figure out what the hell the game wants you to do (I could go on a long rant about how the game introduces certain gates that cause something in the environment to change, but I won't).  Overall, the best puzzles were the ones where you had to form certain symbols by looking at things int eh environment from specific angles, because they helped represent Senua's psychosis in trying to find patterns where none exist.  However, there was a problem that you could often see the symbol in multiple places, and even when you found the correct collection of objects, you could see it from a range of angles, and so you had to find the exact one that would trigger the solution (the game in general has a bad habit of requiring you to stand in a super specific place to interact with things).

It feels a bit strange to recommend a game where I only enjoyed maybe half of my time playing it.  Still, it is a kind experience that you very rarely see from games (much less from big-budget ones).  It's also fairly short, and often on sale, which helps.  Overall, I'm glad I played Hellblade, but I don't think i'll ever play it again.
